{{Infobox person |name = Dr. Bennet Omalu |honorific_suffix = |image = Omalu_Picture_(7).jpg |alt = |caption = Bennet Omalu in 2015 |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1968|9}} |birth_place = Nnokwa, [[Idemili South]], Anambra State, [[Nigeria]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = [[Lodi, California]] |nationality = Nigerian and naturalized US citizen |other_names = |alma_mater = [[University of Nigeria, Nsukka]] ([[MBBS]], 1990)
[[University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public Health]]
(MPH, Epidemiology, 2004)
[[Carnegie Mellon University]]
(MBA, 2008) |occupation = Medical Doctor, Forensic Pathologist, Professor, Medical Examiner |years_active = |known_for = The first to discover and publish findings of chronic traumatic encephalopathy in American football players while working at the Allegheny County Coroner's Office in Pittsburgh. |notable_works = ''Truth Doesn't Have a Side: My Alarming Discovery about the Danger of Contact Sports'' |spouse = Prema Mutiso |children = 3 |birth_names = |website = {{URL|www.bennetomalu.com/}} }} '''Bennet Ifeakandu Omalu''' (born September 1968[http://bennetomalufoundation.org/about-bennet-omalu/ "About Bennet Omalu"], Bennet Omalu Foundation website.) is a [[Nigerian Americans|Nigerian-American]] physician, [[forensic pathologist]], and [[neuropathologist]] who was the first to discover and publish findings of [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE) in [[American football]] players while working at the [[Allegheny County Medical Examiner|Allegheny County Coroner's Office]] in [[Pittsburgh]].{{cite web | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-doctor-the-nfl-tried-to-silence-1448399061?mod=e2tw | title=The Doctor the NFL Tried to Silence | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=24 November 2015 | accessdate=25 November 2015 | last=Laskas|first= Jeanne Marie| authorlink= Jeanne Marie Laskas | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151125020721/http://www.wsj.com/articles/the-doctor-the-nfl-tried-to-silence-1448399061 | archivedate =25 November 2015| deadurl=no}} He later became the chief [[medical examiner]] for [[San Joaquin County, California]], and is a professor at the [[University of California, Davis]], Department of Medical Pathology and Laboratory Medicine. == Early life == Omalu was born in Nnokwa, [[Idemili South]], [[Anambra]] in southeastern [[Nigeria]] on September 30, 1968, the sixth of seven siblings. He was born during the [[Nigerian Civil War]], which caused his family to flee from their home in the predominantly [[Igbo people|Igbo]] village of [[Enugwu Ukwu|Enugu-Ukwu]] in southeastern Nigeria. They returned two years after Omalu's birth.{{Cite book|title = Concussion|publisher = Random House Trade Paperbacks|date = 2015-11-24|isbn = 9780812987577|first = Jeanne Marie|last = Laskas}} Omalu's mother was a [[seamstress]] and his father a civil [[mining engineer]] and community leader in Enugu-Ukwu. The family name, Omalu, is a shortened form of the surname, Onyemalukwube, which translates to "he who knows, speak." ==Education and career== Omalu began primary school at age three and earned entrance into the [[Federal Government College Enugu]] for secondary school. He attended medical school starting at age 16 at the [[University of Nigeria, Nsukka]]. After graduating with a [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery|Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery]] (MBBS) in June 1990, he completed a clinical internship, followed by three years of service work doctoring in the highland city of [[Jos]]. He became disillusioned with Nigeria after presidential candidate [[Moshood Abiola]] failed to win the Nigerian presidency during an [[Nigerian presidential election, 1993|inconclusive election]] in 1993 and began to search for scholarship opportunities in the United States. Omalu first came to [[Seattle]], Washington in 1994 to complete an [[epidemiology]] fellowship at the [[University of Washington]]. In 1995, he left Seattle for [[New York City]], where he joined [[Columbia University]]'s [[Harlem Hospital Center]] for a residency training program in [[anatomic pathology|anatomic]] and [[clinical pathology]]. After residency, he trained as a forensic pathologist under noted forensic consultant [[Cyril Wecht]] at the [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|Allegheny County]] Coroner's Office in Pittsburgh. Omalu became particularly interested in [[neuropathology]]. Omalu holds eight advanced degrees and [[board certification]]s, later receiving fellowships in pathology and neuropathology through the [[University of Pittsburgh]] in 2000 and 2002 respectively, a [[Professional degrees of public health|Master of Public Health]] (MPH) in epidemiology in 2004 from [[University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public Health]], and a [[Master of Business Administration]] (MBA) from [[Tepper School of Business]] at [[Carnegie Mellon University]] in 2008.[https://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/pathology/our_team/faculty/OmaluB/BennetIOmaluMD,MBA,MPH,CPE,CurriculumVitaeAndTestimonies,August2015.pdf "CV: Bennet Omalu"], UC Davis Medical Center Omalu served as chief [[medical examiner]] of [[San Joaquin County, California]] from 2007 until he resigned in 2017 after accusing the county's Sheriff, who doubles as Coroner, of repeatedly interfering with death investigations to protect law enforcement officers who killed people.{{cite news |last = Small |first = Julie |title = Autopsy Doctor Resigns, Says Sheriff Overrode Death Findings to Protect Officers |newspaper = KQED |date = December 4, 2017 |url = https://ww2.kqed.org/news/2017/12/04/autopsy-doctors-sheriff-overrode-death-findings-to-protect-law-enforcement/ |access-date = 2017-12-11 }} An assistant forensic pathologist who joined the office for the opportunity to work with Omalu resigned a few days earlier citing similar allegations.{{cite news |last = Small |first = Julie |title = Autopsy Doctor Quits, Alleges Sheriff Interfered in Death Probes |newspaper = KQED |date = November 27, 2017 |url = https://ww2.kqed.org/news/2017/11/27/autopsy-doctor-quits-alleges-sheriff-interfered-in-death-probes/ |access-date = 2017-12-11 }} Omalu is a professor in the [[UC Davis]] Department of Medical Pathology and Laboratory Medicine.{{cite web|title=Bennet Omalu, M.D., M.B.A., MPH, CPE, DABP-AP, CP, FP, NP|url=http://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/pathology/our_team/faculty/OmaluB.html|publisher=University of California, Davis Department of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine|accessdate=1 September 2015}} ==Research on CTE== {{Main article|Concussions in American football|Concussions in sport|Chronic traumatic encephalopathy|l3=Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)}} Omalu's autopsy of former [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] player [[Mike Webster]] in 2002 led to the re-emergence of awareness of a neurologic condition associated with chronic head trauma called [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]], or CTE, which had been previously described in boxersSabharwal RK, Sanchetee PC, Sethi PK, Dhamija RM. Chronic traumatic encephalopathy in boxers. J Assoc Physicians India. 1987 Aug;35(8):571-3. and other professional athletes. Webster had died suddenly and unexpectedly following years of struggling with cognitive and intellectual impairment, destitution, mood disorders, depression, drug abuse, and suicide attempts. Although Webster's brain looked normal at autopsy, Omalu conducted independent and self-financed tissue analyses. He suspected that Webster suffered from [[dementia pugilistica]], which is a form of dementia that is induced by repeated blows to the head, a condition found previously in boxers. Using specialized staining, Omalu found large accumulations of [[tau protein]] in Webster's brain, which affect mood, emotions, and [[executive functions]] similar to the way that clumps of [[Amyloid beta|beta-amyloid protein]] contribute to [[Alzheimer's disease]]. Together with colleagues in the Department of Pathology at the [[University of Pittsburgh]], Omalu published his findings in the journal ''[[Neurosurgery (journal)|Neurosurgery]]'' in 2005 in a paper titled "Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy in a National Football League Player." In it, Omalu called for further study of the disease: "We herein report the first documented case of long-term neurodegenerative changes in a retired professional NFL player consistent with chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). This case draws attention to a disease that remains inadequately studied in the cohort of professional football players, with unknown true prevalence rates."{{Cite journal|title = Chronic traumatic encephalopathy in a National Football League player|journal = Neurosurgery|date = 2005-07-01|issn = 1524-4040|pmid = 15987548|pages = 128-134; discussion 128-134|volume = 57|issue = 1|first = Bennet I.|last = Omalu|first2 = Steven T.|last2 = DeKosky|first3 = Ryan L.|last3 = Minster|first4 = M. Ilyas|last4 = Kamboh|first5 = Ronald L.|last5 = Hamilton|first6 = Cyril H.|last6 = Wecht|doi=10.1227/01.neu.0000163407.92769.ed}} Omalu believed the [[National Football League]] (NFL) doctors would be "pleased" to read it and that his research could be used to "fix the problem." The paper received little attention initially, but members of the NFL's [[National Football League concussion committee|Mild Traumatic Brain Injury (MTBI) Committee]] later called for its retraction in May 2006.{{cite web|title = Timeline: The NFL's Concussion Crisis – League of Denial: The NFL's Concussion Crisis - FRONTLINE|url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/sports/league-of-denial/timeline-the-nfls-concussion-crisis/#2006|website = FRONTLINE|publisher = PBS |accessdate = 2015-11-09}} Their letter requesting the retraction characterized Omalu's description of CTE as "completely wrong" and called the paper "a failure." Omalu later partnered with Julian Bailes, a neurosurgeon, concussion researcher, and then chairman of the Department of Neurosurgery at [[West Virginia University School of Medicine]], and West Virginia attorney Robert P. Fitzsimmons to found the [[Brain Injury Research Institute]] which established a brain and tissue bank. In November 2006, Omalu published a second ''Neurosurgery'' paper based on his findings in the brain of former NFL player [[Terry Long (American football)|Terry Long]], who suffered from depression and committed suicide in 2005. Though Long died at 45, Omalu found tau protein concentrations more consistent with "a 90-year-old brain with advanced Alzheimer's." As with Mike Webster, Omalu asserted that Long's football career had caused later brain damage and depression.{{Cite journal|title = Chronic traumatic encephalopathy in a national football league player: part II|journal = Neurosurgery|date = 2006-11-01|issn = 1524-4040|pmid = 17143242|pages = 1086-1092; discussion 1092-1093|volume = 59|issue = 5|doi = 10.1227/01.NEU.0000245601.69451.27|first = Bennet I.|last = Omalu|first2 = Steven T.|last2 = DeKosky|first3 = Ronald L.|last3 = Hamilton|first4 = Ryan L.|last4 = Minster|first5 = M. Ilyas|last5 = Kamboh|first6 = Abdulrezak M.|last6 = Shakir|first7 = Cyril H.|last7 = Wecht}} Omalu also found evidence of CTE in the brains of retired NFL players [[Justin Strzelczyk]] (d. 2004 at 36 years old), [[Andre Waters]] (d. 2006 at 44), and [[Tom McHale (American football)|Tom McHale]] (d. 2008 at 45). In summer 2007, Bailes presented his and Omalu's findings to NFL Commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] at a league-wide concussion summit. Bailes later said that the research was "dismissed". The NFL's MTBI committee chair, [[Ira Casson|Dr. Ira Casson]], told the press: "In my opinion, the only scientifically valid evidence of a chronic encephalopathy in athletes is in boxers and in some Steeplechase jockeys." The NFL did not publicly acknowledge the link between concussions sustained in football and long-term neurological effects until December 2009, seven years after Omalu's discovery. However, as late as 2013, the annual meeting of the American Academy of Clinical Neuropsychology (AACN) included a debate between two sports concussion experts regarding the validity (or existence) of CTE.[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/06/130619132354.htm "Sports concussions debate: Does CTE really exist?"]. [[Science Daily]]. Loyola University Health System. June 19, 2013. Finally, in March 2016, the NFL's senior vice president for health and safety policy, Jeff Miller, testified before congress that the NFL now believed that there was a link between football and CTE.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/16/sports/nfl-concussions-cte-football-jeff-miller.html|title=N.F.L. Shifts on Concussions, and Game May Never Be the Same|last=Belson|first=Ken|date=2016-03-15|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-03|last2=Schwarz|first2=Alan|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Omalu has also discovered CTE in the brains of military veterans, publishing the first documented case in a November 2011 article.{{Cite journal|title = Chronic traumatic encephalopathy in an Iraqi war veteran with posttraumatic stress disorder who committed suicide|journal = Neurosurgical Focus|date = 2011-11-01|issn = 1092-0684|pmid = 22044102|pages = E3|volume = 31|issue = 5|doi = 10.3171/2011.9.FOCUS11178|first = Bennet|last = Omalu|first2 = Jennifer L.|last2 = Hammers|first3 = Julian|last3 = Bailes|first4 = Ronald L.|last4 = Hamilton|first5 = M. Ilyas|last5 = Kamboh|first6 = Garrett|last6 = Webster|first7 = Robert P.|last7 = Fitzsimmons}} Omalu found evidence of CTE in a 27-year-old [[Iraq War]] veteran who suffered from [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) and later committed suicide. Omalu's paper links PTSD to the CTE spectrum of diseases and calls for further study. Omalu is lead author in a study published in November 2017{{cite journal |last = Omalu |first = Bennet |author2 = et al |title = Postmortem Autopsy-Confirmation of Antemortem [F-18]FDDNP-PET Scans in a Football Player With Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy |journal = Neurosurgery |date = 2017 |doi = 10.1093/neuros/nyx536 }} that for the first time confirmed CTE in a living person. A chemical [[Radioactive tracer|tracer]], FDDNP, binds to tau proteins, detectable by [[positron emission tomography]], and associated with the distinctive topographical distributions characteristic of CTE. Tested on at least a dozen former NFL players, it was confirmed postmortem in former linebacker [[Fred McNeill]].{{cite news |last = Kounang |first = Nadia |title = Ex-NFL player confirmed as 1st case of CTE in living patient. He resigned his coroner position in 2017. |newspaper = CNN |date = November 16, 2017 |url = https://www.cnn.com/2017/11/16/health/cte-confirmed-in-first-living-person-bn/ |access-date = 2017-12-11 }} == Stephon Clark report == {{Main article|Shooting of Stephon Clark}} In March 2018 Omalu conducted an independent autopsy of [[Shooting of Stephon Clark|Stephon Clark]], who had been shot by [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] Police officers. On March 30, he released his findings, stating that Clark had been shot eight times from the back or side, adding, "You could reasonably conclude that he received seven gunshot wounds from his back."{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2018/03/30/stephon-clark-independent-autopsy-results-announced-friday/472507002/|title=Stephon Clark shot 8 times, mostly in back, independent autopsy finds|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-04-01|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/30/us/stephon-clark-independent-autopsy.html|title=Stephon Clark Was Shot 8 Times Primarily in His Back, Family-Ordered Autopsy Finds|last=Robles|first=Frances|date=2018-03-30|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-01|last2=Real|first2=Jose A. Del|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} ==In popular media== Omalu's efforts to study and publicize CTE in the face of NFL opposition were reported in a ''[[GQ]]'' magazine article in 2009 by journalist [[Jeanne Marie Laskas]].{{Cite news|title = Game Brain: Football Players and Concussions|url = https://www.gq.com/story/nfl-players-brain-dementia-study-memory-concussions|work = [[GQ]]| last=Laskas|first= Jeanne Marie|accessdate = 9 November 2015| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151111053002/http://www.gq.com/story/nfl-players-brain-dementia-study-memory-concussions | archivedate= 11 November 2015| deadurl=no}} The article was later expanded by Laskas into a book, ''Concussion'' (Penguin Random House, 2015), and adapted into a [[Concussion (2015 film)|film of the same name]] where Omalu, portrayed by [[Will Smith]], is the central character. The film has been criticized for not being truthful to the actual events.Engber, Daniel (December 21, 2015). [http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/sports_nut/2015/12/the_truth_about_will_smith_s_concussion_and_bennet_omalu.html "''Concussion Lies'': The film about the NFL's apparent CTE epidemic feeds the pervasive national myths about head trauma."]. ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''.[http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2015/12/17/concussion-bennet-omalu-nfl/ "'Concussion' Subject Bennet Omalu Exaggerated His Role, Researchers Say"]. [[CBS New York]]. December 17, 2015. Nevertheless, the movie's production led to the creation of a foundation named after Omalu to advance CTE and concussion research.{{cite web|title = About the Foundation {{!}} Bennet Omalu Foundation|url = http://bennetomalufoundation.org/about-the-foundation/|website = bennetomalufoundation.org|accessdate = 2015-12-25}} In September 2016, Omalu attracted media attention when he suggested on [[Twitter]] that [[Hillary Clinton]] was possibly poisoned and advised members of her [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]] to "perform toxicologic analysis of Ms. Clinton's blood." He further tweeted, "I do not trust Mr. [[Vladimir Putin|Putin]] and Mr. [[Donald Trump|Trump]]. With those two, all things are possible."{{cite web|last=Boren |first=Cindy |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2016/09/12/the-man-who-discovered-cte-thinks-hillary-clinton-may-have-been-poisoned/ |title=The man who discovered CTE thinks Hillary Clinton may have been poisoned |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2016-09-13}} Omalu's book ''Truth Doesn't Have a Side: My Alarming Discovery about the Danger of Contact Sports'' was published in August 2017 by [[HarperCollins]].{{cite news|last1=Peterson|first1=Gary|title=Why it took a foreign-born doctor to blow the whistle on the NFL's concussion epidemic |url=http://www.eastbaytimes.com/2017/08/24/bennet-omalu/|work=Bay Area News Group|date=August 24, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Almond|first1=Elliott|title='Concussion' doc's six sports kids should never play|url= http://www.eastbaytimes.com/2017/08/25/the-concussion-docs-six-sports-kids-should-never-play/|work=Bay Area News Group|date=August 25, 2017}} He previously wrote ''Play Hard, Die Young: Football Dementia, Depression, and Death'', published in 2008. == Personal life == Omalu is married to Prema Mutiso, originally from [[Kenya]]. They live in Elk Grove, CA and have two children, Ashly and Mark. He is a practicing [[Catholicism|Catholic]] and became a naturalized U.S. citizen in February 2015.{{cite web|title = Bennet Omalu Foundation launches in Pittsburgh|url = http://www.pghcitypaper.com/Blogh/archives/2015/12/16/bennet-omalu-foundation-launches-in-pittsburgh|website = Pittsburgh City Paper|accessdate = 2016-01-05}} == See also == * [[List of whistleblowers]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.bennetomalu.com/ Official site] ** [https://twitter.com/bennetomalu9168 Twitter] * {{IMDb name|id=6013992}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Omalu, Bennet}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century Nigerian medical doctors]] [[Category:University of Nigeria, Nsukka alumni]] [[Category:University of Pittsburgh alumni]] [[Category:Tepper School of Business alumni]] [[Category:American forensic pathologists]] [[Category:Nigerian pathologists]] [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Nigerian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:University of California, Davis faculty]] [[Category:Concussion activists]] [[Category:American football controversies]] [[Category:Nigerian Roman Catholics]] [[Category:American people of Nigerian descent]] [[Category:American people of Igbo descent]] [[Category:Igbo physicians]] [[Category:People of the Nigerian Civil War]] [[Category:21st-century American physicians]] [[Category:People from Anambra State]] [[Category:20th-century American physicians]] [[Category:American physicians]] [[Category:People with acquired American citizenship]] [[Category:People from Lodi, California]] [[Category:Whistleblowers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Boa Sr | image = Boa-Sr.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = [[Circa|c.]] 1925 | birth_place = [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]], [[India]] | death_date = 26 January 2010 | death_place = [[Port Blair]], [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]], [[India]] | occupation = | residence = | alma_mater = | religion = | spouse = | parents = | children = }}
'''Boa Sr''' (''[[circa]]'' 1925 – 26 January 2010) was an [[India]]n [[Great Andamanese]] elder. She was the last person fluent in the [[Aka-Bo language]].<ref name=guardian/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.survivalinternational.org/news/5509 |title=Andaman tribe’s extermination complete as last member dies |date=4 February 2010 |accessdate=2016-07-27 |quote= |publisher=[[Survival International]] }}</ref>
Boa Sr is not to be confused with another Great Andamanese tribal member, Boa Jr; the two women were not directly related. Boa Jr's late mother, Boro (who was also the last speaker of her language, [[Aka-Kora language|Aka-Kora]]) was Boa Sr's best friend and named her daughter in her honor.
==Biography== Boa was born around 1925.<ref>{{cite news |author=Alastair Lawson |coauthors= |title=Last speaker of ancient language of Bo dies in India |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8498534.stm |quote=The last speaker of an ancient language in India's Andaman Islands has died at the age of about 85, a leading linguist has told the BBC. |work=[[BBC]] |date=February 4, 2010 |accessdate=2010-08-12 }}</ref> Her mother, To, belonged to the [[Bo people (Andaman)|Bo people]] and her father, Renge, belonged to the [[Jeru people]]. Boa's early life was spent in [[Mayabunder]], a town on [[Middle Andaman Island]]. She was married at a young age to Nao, another member of her father's people, although both he and their children predeceased her. She regarded the [[Jeru language]] as her mother tongue.<ref name=adam/><ref name="andamanese1">{{cite web|url=http://www.andamanese.net/generalia.html|title=Boa Sr. profile|publisher=Andamanese.net |date=2009-02-22 |accessdate=2010-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100208214255/http://www.andamanese.net/generalia.htm |archivedate=February 8, 2010 }}</ref>
Boa Sr. lived through the [[epidemic]] brought by the British to the [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]], which devastated the Great Andamanese population, and also through the [[Japanese occupation of the Andaman Islands]] during World War II.<ref name=adam>{{cite web|url=http://www.andamanese.net/BoaSr_Obituary.html |title=Bo Sr.'s obituary |publisher=Andamanese.net |date= |accessdate=2010-05-14}}</ref> In the 1970s, she and other Great Andamanese was forcibly relocated by the government of India to [[Strait Island]], a small tribal reserve east of [[Baratang Island]].<ref name=adam/>
Boa Sr. worked with [[Anvita Abbi]], a professor of [[linguistics]] at [[Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi|Jawaharlal Nehru University]] in [[Delhi]], since 2005. Abbi studied and recorded Boa's language and songs.<ref name="andamanese1"/> Other members of the Great Andamanese speech community had difficulty understanding the songs and narratives which she knew in Bo.<ref name="andamanese1"/> She also spoke the Andamanese [[dialect]] of [[Hindi]], as well as [[Great Andamanese creole]], a mix of the ten indigenous languages of Andamans.
Boa Sr. survived the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]] by climbing a tree. She later explained her escape from the [[tsunami]] saying, "We were all there when the [[earthquake]] came. The eldest told us the [[Earth]] would part, don't run away or move."<ref name=telegraph>{{cite encyclopedia|first=|title=Boa Sr. |encyclopedia=Lives Remembered |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/7207731/Lives-Remembered.html|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=2010-02-10 |accessdate=2010-02-22}}</ref>
Her husband, Nao Jer, died several years before she did and the couple had no children. She suffered from some vision loss during her later life, but was considered to be in good health until shortly before her death in 2010.<ref name=telegraph/>
Boa Sr. died at a hospital in [[Port Blair]] on 26 January 2010.<ref name=telegraph/> Boa Sr., who was approximately 85 years old, was the oldest living member of the Great Andamanese tribes at the time.<ref name=telegraph2>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Language lost as last member of Andaman tribe dies |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/india/7161422/Language-lost-as-last-member-of-Andaman-tribe-dies.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=|date=2010-02-05 |accessdate=2010-02-22}}</ref> Boa Sr.'s death left just 52<ref name=telegraph/> surviving Great Andamanese people in the world, none of whom remember any Bo. Their population is greatly reduced from the estimated 5,000 Great Andamanese living in the Andaman Islands at the time of the arrival of the British in 1858.<ref name=telegraph/>
==Legacy== [[Stephen Corry]], director of the [[United Kingdom|British]]-based [[NGO]] [[Survival International]], issued a statement saying, "With the death of Boa Sr. and the extinction of the Bo language, a unique part of human society is now just a memory. Boa's loss is a bleak reminder that we must not allow this to happen to the other tribes of the Andaman Islands."<ref name=guardian>{{cite news|author=Jonathan Watt |title=Ancient tribal language becomes extinct as last speaker dies |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/feb/04/ancient-language-extinct-speaker-dies|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=|date=2010-02-04 |accessdate=2010-02-22}}</ref> Linguist Narayan Choudhary also explained what the loss of Boa Sr. meant in both academic and personal terms, "Her loss is not just the loss of the Great Andamanese community, it is a loss of several disciplines of studies put together, including [[anthropology]], [[linguistics]], [[history]], [[psychology]], and [[biology]]. To me, Boa Sr. epitomised a totality of humanity in all its hues and with a richness that is not to be found anywhere else."
== References == {{Portal|India|Biography|Languages}} {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Boa Sr}} [[Category:1920s births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Last known speakers of a language]] [[Category:People from North and Middle Andaman district]] [[Category:Andamanese languages]]

{{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox politician | honorific-prefix = | name = Cyd Ho Sau-lan | native_name = {{nobold|何秀蘭}} | native_name_lang = zh-hk | image = Cyd Ho at January 2013 protest (cropped).jpg | imagesize = 180px | caption = Ho campaigning for the [[Hong Kong legislative election, 2012|2012 Hong Kong Legislative Council Election]]. |office=Member of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong|Legislative Council]] |constituency=[[Hong Kong Island (constituency)|Hong Kong Island]] |term_start=1 October 2008 |term_end=30 September 2016 |successor=''Seat abolished'' |predecessor=[[Rita Fan]] |constituency1=[[Hong Kong Island (constituency)|Hong Kong Island]] |term_start1=1 October 2000 |term_end1=30 September 2004 |predecessor1=[[Christine Loh]] |successor1=[[Ma Lik]] |constituency2=[[New Territories East (constituency)|New Territories East]] |term_start2=1 July 1998 |term_end2=30 June 2000 |predecessor2=''New parliament'' |successor2=[[Wong Sing-chi]] | ancestry = [[Nanhai]], Guangdong, China | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1954|07|24}} | birth_place =Hong Kong | nationality = | spouse = | party = [[United Ants]] {{small|(1993–1996)}}
[[The Frontier (Hong Kong)|The Frontier]] (1996–2004)
[[Civic Act-up]] (2003–2012)
[[Labour Party (Hong Kong)|Labour Party]] (2012–present) | residence = | alma_mater = [[University of Waterloo]] | occupation = [[Legislative Councillor]] | profession =}} {{Infobox Chinese |order= |showflag= |t=何秀蘭 |j=Ho4 Sau3 laan4 |y=Hòh Sau làahn }} '''Cyd Ho Sau-lan''' ({{zh|first=t|t=何秀蘭}}) is a former member of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] (Legco) for the [[Hong Kong Island (constituency)|Hong Kong Island constituency]]. She is a founding member of the [[Labour Party (Hong Kong)|Labour Party]], since December 2011, and currently holds the position of vice-chairwoman. Previously, she was a founding member of [[The Frontier (Hong Kong)|The Frontier]], another pro-democracy [[political group]]. Since 2006, she has been a founding councillor of the [[World Future Council]]. She has garnered a reputation for promoting universal suffrage, rule of law, human rights, and equal opportunity, as well as advancement in the interests of women, homosexuals and other minority groups. ==Education== Ho studied at the [[University of Waterloo]], Canada. She worked in the textile trading industry from 1979 to 1995. ==Career== In 1991, Ho helped [[Emily Lau]] during the election campaign, the first open direct election of Legco in Hong Kong. In 1993, she founded the liberal pressure group "United Ants" with other pro-democracy political activists. In 1995, she worked as an assistant to [[Margaret Ng]], a lawmaker representing the [[legal profession]] in Legco. In 1996, along with other political activists, she founded [[The Frontier (Hong Kong)|The Frontier]]. She was elected a legislative councillor for the geographical constituency of [[New Territories East (constituency)|New Territories East]] in 1998 in the first Legco election since the [[transfer of sovereignty over Hong Kong]] from the UK to China. She was re-elected in the c in 2000. She chaired bills committees such as the 2004 Education (Revised) Bill and the 2004 Examination Authority Bill, and was vice-chair of the panel on environmental affairs. She chaired the Sub-committee under the Home Affair Panel to study questions of discrimination based on sexual orientation between 2000 and 2004. She was elected as a [[District Council of Hong Kong|District Council]] member of the Central and Western district via the Kwun Lung (觀龍) constituency in November 2003, unseating veteran [[Ip Kwok-him]] of the [[Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong|DAB]] with a margin of 64 votes. She also supported members of other pro-democracy political groups such as Civic Act-up, which were also contesting seats in the Wanchai district council. In 2004, she, together with [[James To Kun Sun]], [[Frederick Fung Kin Kee]], [[Wong Sing Chi]], [[Mak Kwok Fung]], attempted to cross the border and meet Beijing officials at [[Shenzhen]], to request a faster pace of [[democratisation]] in Hong Kong. ==2004 Legco election== The [[Hong Kong Legislative Council election, 2004|2004 Legislative Council election]] returned candidates to office based on a party-list [[proportional representation]] system. There were four viable tickets running for election for the [[Hong Kong Island (constituency)|Hong Kong Island constituency]]. The left was represented by the [[Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong]]'s ticket, consisting of [[Ma Lik]] and [[Choy So-yuk]]; and the centrist ticket was represented by [[Rita Fan]]. The pan-democratic camp decided, after strategising, to put up two tickets for election: the [[Democratic Party (Hong Kong)|Democratic Party]]'s ticket with [[Martin Lee]] and [[Yeung Sum]], and [[Audrey Eu]] and Cyd Ho's ticket. The thinking was that the remainder vote on both these tickets was sufficient to return all four candidates to office, providing that voters in the pan-democratic camp were coordinated effectively. Cyd Ho was defeated by a slim margin (815 out of a total of about 350,000, or 0.23%) to her nearest DAB rival, Choy So-yuk. Originally, the slogan "1+1=4" was taken as a way to strategically allocate votes between the two pan-democratic camp tickets, namely that a spouse from each couple would vote for each ticket. Conspiracy theorists claim that, during the final days leading up to the election, the Democratic Party believed it could secure a seat for their third candidate, Lai Chi-Keung. The Democratic Party hence allegedly requested all supporters of the pan-democratic camp in the Hong Kong Island geographical constituency to vote for them, claiming that Audrey Eu's star presence on the other ticket was strong enough to skew votes to the other ticket. In the end, Lai ended up a few hundred votes short of Cyd Ho, costing them both the chance for a seat. This ultimately benefited Cyd Ho's DAB rival Choy So-yuk. A number of disgruntled voters of the pan-democratic camp demanded that then-DP chairman Yeung Sum and Founding chairman Martin Lee Chu-ming both step down in consequence. {{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} ==Post-election== In addition to remaining as a key member of the Frontier until 2006, Ho hosted weekly radio programmes on two local radio stations in 2006 – on [[RTHK]] and [[PRHK]]. She hosted a radio show on the [[internet radio]] station My Radio on Thursday nights (2200–2300 HKT). In 2006, she quit the Frontier and became the chairperson of the [[Hong Kong Human Rights Monitor]] and the co-convener of Project Civil Referendum, a scheme to pilot and promote the idea of holding a [[referendum]] in Hong Kong. In 2007, when the death of [[Ma Lik]] vacated a Hong Kong Island Legislative Council seat, she originally decided to run in the by-election, but later she decided against. Also, she declined to stand again for her district council seat to prepare for her 2008 Legco election campaign. ==2008 Legco election== Ho stood for and was returned in the Hong Kong Island geographical constituency for the [[Hong Kong legislative election, 2008]]. She finished with the fifth highest number of vote in the six-member constituency, 30,887, or 9.85%. Her running mate in 2004, Audrey Eu of the Civic Party, obtained 30,362. == Labour Party == In December 2011, after The Frontier had failed to pass its own resolution to dissolve, she joined with [[Lee Cheuk-yan]], [[Cheung Kwok-che]] and others to form the Labour Party, taking up the position of vice-chairwoman. She was re-elected in 2012 elections. == LGBT rights == In 2012, soon after Ho re-elected as member of Legco, she put forward a proposal calling for public consultation on legislation to outlaw discrimination based on sexual orientation. This proposal was supported by most of the pro-democrats and some pro-Beijing lawmakers, but was veto by Democratic Party lawmaker [[James To]] (who voted abstained) and pro-Beijing conservative parties.[http://www.scmp.com/comment/insight-opinion/article/1083187/lawmakers-opposition-gay-rights-law-shames-hong-kong?login=1 Lawmakers' opposition to gay rights law shames Hong Kong]. ''South China Morning Post'' During her terms, Ho is one of only few legislators to openly support [[same-sex marriage]] and other [[LGBT rights]], conservative parties and groups criticized her on this issue. Though most of the pro-democrats support non-discrimination laws, they are less openly discuss and talk about this issue, as the pro-democrats have many supporters with many social conservative views. ==2016 Legco election== She lost in the [[Hong Kong legislative election, 2016]] with 19,376 votes, placed ninth in the Hong Kong Island constituency, along with the former party chairman [[Lee Cheuk-yan]], leaving the Labour Party only one representative in the legislature. ==See also== *[[Politics of Hong Kong]] *[[List of political parties in Hong Kong]] ==References== ==External links== {{Commons category|Ho Sau Lan, Cyd}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040521213045/http://www.cydho.org.hk/ Official website of Cyd Ho] *[http://www.legco.gov.hk Official website of Legislative Council] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090525234526/http://worldfuturecouncil.org/cyd_ho.html Councillor at World Future Council] {{S-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{S-new|rows=2|party}} {{s-ttl|title=Convenor of [[The Frontier (Hong Kong)|the Frontier]]|years=1996}} {{s-aft|after=[[Emily Lau]]}} {{S-ttl|title=Chairman of [[Civic Act-up]]|years=2003–2012}} {{s-non|reason=Merged into [[Labour Party (Hong Kong)|Labour Party]]}} {{s-par|hk}} {{s-bef|before=[[Rita Fan]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of Legislative Council |district=[[Hong Kong Island (constituency)|Hong Kong Island]] |years=2008–2016}} {{s-non|reason=Seat abolished}} {{end}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ho, Cyd}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hong Kong politicians]] [[Category:District councillors of Central and Western District]] [[Category:Hong Kong social democrats]] [[Category:University of Waterloo alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of Hong Kong Baptist University]] [[Category:LGBT rights activists from Hong Kong]] [[Category:Charter 08 signatories]] [[Category:The Frontier (Hong Kong) politicians]] [[Category:Labour Party (Hong Kong) politicians]] [[Category:HK LegCo Members 1998–2000]] [[Category:HK LegCo Members 2000–04]] [[Category:HK LegCo Members 2008–12]] [[Category:HK LegCo Members 2012–16]]

#REDIRECT [[List of duels]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Petinella, Diambra de}} [[Category:Female duellists]] [[Category:Duellists]]

{{Infobox criminal | name = Farid Fata | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Farid T. Fata | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1965}} | birth_place = [[Lebanon]] | occupation = [[Hematologist]], [[Oncologist]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Oakland Township, Michigan]] | cause = | resting_place = | alias = | charge = [[Health care fraud]], conspiracy to pay and receive [[kickback (bribery)|kickbacks]], [[money laundering]] | conviction = September 20, 2014 (pleaded guilty) | conviction_penalty = 45 years in federal prison | conviction_status = Incarcerated at [[Federal Correctional Institution, Williamsburg]]; [[Salters, South Carolina]]; earliest possible release October 19, 2052 | spouse = Samar Fata (divorced)<ref name=Dateline/> | children = }} '''Farid T. Fata''' ({{Lang-ar|فريد فتى, born 1965) is a [[Lebanon|Lebanese]]-born former [[hematology|hematologist]]/[[oncology|oncologist]] and the admitted mastermind of one of the largest [[health care fraud]]s in American history. He was the owner of Michigan Hematology-Oncology (MHO), one of the largest [[cancer]] practices in [[Michigan]]. He was arrested in 2013 on charges of prescribing [[chemotherapy]] to patients who were either perfectly healthy or whose condition did not warrant chemotherapy, then submitting $34 million in fraudulent charges to [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] and private health insurance companies over a period of at least six years. He pleaded guilty in 2014 to charges of health care fraud, conspiring to pay and receive [[kickback (bribery)|kickbacks]], and [[money laundering]]. On July 10, 2015, he was sentenced to 45 years in federal prison.<ref>{{cite web|title=Detroit Area Doctor Sentenced to 45 Years in Prison for Providing Medically Unnecessary Chemotherapy to Patients|url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/detroit-area-doctor-sentenced-45-years-prison-providing-medically-unnecessary-chemotherapy|website=US Department of Justice|publisher=US Department of Justice|accessdate=23 July 2015|date=July 10, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Moghe|first1=Sonia|title=Patients give horror stories as cancer doctor gets 45 years|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/10/us/michigan-cancer-doctor-sentenced/index.html|website=CNN|publisher=Cable News Network|accessdate=23 July 2015|date=July 11, 2015}}</ref>
==Early life and career== Fata was born in Lebanon in 1965, to a [[Melkite]] Catholic family. After obtaining a medical degree there in 1992, he emigrated to the United States to begin his medical career. He served a [[medical residency|residency]] at [[Maimonides Medical Center]] in [[Brooklyn]] from 1993 to 1996. From 1996 to 1999, he was a fellow in hematology-[[oncology]] at [[Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center]] in [[Manhattan]]. He was an attending physician at [[Geisinger Medical Center]] in [[Danville, Pennsylvania]] from 2000 to 2003.
He struck out on his own in 2003, opening Michigan Hematology-Oncology (MHO) in [[Rochester Hills, Michigan]]. Over the next decade, it grew to seven locations located throughout [[Metro Detroit]]—in Rochester Hills, [[Bloomfield Hills, Michigan|Bloomfield Hills]], [[Clarkston, Michigan|Clarkston]], [[Sterling Heights, Michigan|Sterling Heights]], [[Troy, Michigan|Troy]], [[Lapeer, Michigan|Lapeer]] and [[Oak Park, Michigan|Oak Park]].<ref name=sentencingmemo>[http://www.justice.gov/usao-edmi/file/623456/download Sentencing memorandum for Fata] submitted by U. S. Attorney for Eastern District of Michigan</ref> He became a naturalized U. S. citizen in April 2009.<ref name=Indictment>[http://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/usao-edmi/legacy/2014/01/15/Dr%20Fata%204th%20SS%20Ind.pdf Federal indictment against Fata]</ref>
Fata specialized in treating blood cancer. He owned his own lab, pharmacy and radiation treatment facility. At his height, he was treating 17,000 patients at his clinics. He acquired a sterling reputation as one of the best cancer specialists in Metro Detroit. He was known for his aggressive approach, which gave higher doses of chemo drugs more frequently—a protocol he called "European protocol."<ref name=Dateline>{{cite episode|title=Do No Harm|url=http://www.nbc.com/dateline/video/dateline-0117b/2966610?onid=209511|series=[[Dateline NBC]]|date=2015-01-17|network=[[NBC]]}}</ref>
Fata's wife, Samar, helped run the business side of his practice as Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of his companies.<ref>[https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/local/million-dollar-question-for-judge-in-fata-bond-hearing-9-million-or-25000]</ref> She moved back to Lebanon after her husband's arrest; they have since divorced.<ref name=Dateline/>
==Fraud revealed== Concerns about Fata cropped up as early as 2007, when Maggie Dorsey sued Fata for malpractice. She'd been diagnosed with cancer in 2004, and seven months of chemo made it difficult for her to walk. She learned that she did not have cancer. The case was settled out of court in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/dateline/video/treated-for-cancer-she-never-had-602775619570|title=Treated for cancer she never had|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=2016-01-15}}</ref> In 2010, veteran oncology nurse Angela Swantek went to MHO for an interview, but was stunned to see practices that her experience told her were "plain wrong." She believed that Fata was pumping patients with drugs specifically to bill their insurance for more money—a classic fraud scenario. She complained to state authorities, but got no response until 2011, when she got a form letter saying that there was no evidence to support an investigation.<ref name=Dateline/>
In 2013, Fata diagnosed 54-year-old Monica Flagg with [[multiple myeloma]]—a condition that required a lifetime of chemo for her to have any chance to survive. On July 1, hours after her first round of chemotherapy, she broke her leg in two places. Fata was on vacation in Lebanon at the time. One of the doctors at MHO, Soe Maunglay, saw her in the hospital that day, and was stunned to see that her readings were completely normal. As he put it, he could tell "just by looking at the chart" that Flagg's numbers were not consistent with an active cancer patient.<ref name=Dateline/>
The next day, Maunglay went to Fata's clinic and reviewed Flagg's records, and could find nothing in Flagg's test results that could justify a chemo regimen.<ref name="Dateline" /> He later told ''[[The Detroit News]]'' that myeloma can start with minor changes in blood chemistry—minor enough that a dishonest doctor can use chemotherapy to avoid detection. He estimated that if another doctor had seen Flagg within two months, she would have appeared to be in remission. He also believed that since Flagg was far healthier on paper than a typical myeloma patient, the insurance payments would continue flowing to Fata for the rest of his life. Maunglay went to see Flagg the following day, and told her she did not have cancer. He further advised her to get her records right away and find another doctor, and that she should never go back to Fata again.<ref name=Maunglay>{{cite news|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/special-reports/2015/06/10/whistle-blower-doctor-uncovered-medical-nightmare/71027690/ |title=Whistle-blower: How doctor uncovered nightmare|last=Berman|first=Laura|publisher=[[The Detroit News]]|date=2015-06-10}}</ref>
Maunglay was already due to leave MHO the following month after catching Fata red-handed lying about the clinic's enrollment in a professional quality program. However, after discovering that a perfectly healthy woman was being treated with chemotherapy, he felt that he needed to stop Fata. Knowing that Flagg's case, even as egregious as it was, would not be enough to shut Fata down, he needed to find more evidence of misconduct. Maunglay investigated MHO's patient records, and found numerous instances of unethical and potentially illegal behavior. For instance, Fata was treating several patients with [[IVIG]], a drug intended to treat patients with specific immune deficiencies, when there was no apparent medical basis for it. Maunglay persuaded a nurse and a nurse practitioner to confront Fata. When Fata agreed to curb the use of IVIG, Maunglay believed that this was further evidence that Fata was a fraud. He told the ''News'' that an honest doctor would never cut back on his own protocol solely because of staff and physician objections. On July 16—the same day that he learned Fata had stopped the IVIG treatments, Maunglay took his suspicions to office manager George Karadsheh.<ref name=Maunglay/>
Karadsheh didn't believe Maunglay at first, since he was aware that Maunglay was leaving in August. However, Karadsheh recalled that many nurses and others had expressed concerns about Fata's aggressive regimen. Maunglay had also specifically suggested that Karadsheh check on Fata's use of IVIG. Karadsheh asked a nurse and she confirmed Maunglay's previous report; most of the patients who were being treated with IVIG didn't qualify for it.<ref name=Dateline/> Karadsheh knew what health care fraud smelled like; he'd exposed a fraud at a Detroit clinic in 1996. He took his findings to the Detroit office of the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] and sued Fata, MHO and several related entities under the [[False Claims Act]] on August 5; he was thus entitled to a significant financial reward.<ref name=Karadshehsuit>{{Cite web|url = http://www.theoaklandpress.com/article/OP/20150625/NEWS/150629709|title = Lawsuit filed against convicted Oakland Township oncologist by employee unsealed|date =2015-06-25 |publisher = [[The Oakland Press]]|last = Phillips|first = Dave}}</ref> Maunglay said that Karadsheh did "a great service" because of his past experience detecting fraud.<ref name=Maunglay/><ref name="Berman: Savvy tipster was key in Dr. Fata’s fall">{{cite news|last1=Berman|first1=Laura|title=Savvy tipster was key in Dr. Fata’s fall|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/opinion/columnists/laura-berman/2015/07/29/savvy-tipster-cancer-doctor-fata/30865735/|accessdate=24 January 2016|publisher=[[The Detroit News]]}}</ref> Fata was arrested the next day for health care fraud.<ref name=Maunglay/>
===Indictment=== Fata was originally held on $170,000 bond, but after federal authorities found evidence that Fata and his wife had assets of $9 million not yet seized and worried that the high liquidity of these assets could make him a high flight risk, they persuaded federal judge [[Sean Cox]] to raise his bond to $9 million.<ref>[https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/local/million-dollar-question-for-judge-in-fata-bond-hearing-9-million-or-25000]</ref><ref>[https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/local/govt-fights-to-keep-dr-farid-fata-in-jail-with-9m-bond]</ref> He was confined to jail pending trial; had he been released, he would have been confined to his home in [[Oakland Township, Michigan|Oakland Township]] and barred from practicing medicine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archive.freep.com/article/20130813/NEWS03/308130110/Fata-bond-hearing-cancer|title=Judge orders $9-million bond for cancer doctor, says he can't practice medicine|last=Baldas|first=Tresa|publisher=[[Detroit Free Press]]|date=2013-08-13}}</ref>
Federal investigators amassed evidence that Fata had bullied or deceived 553 people into getting chemotherapy treatments they didn't need, leaving the patients' insurance companies and Medicare stuck with $34 million in fraudulent and unnecessary claims. They also found that Fata took kickbacks from two local hospices, and poured Medicare and private insurance proceeds into his own diagnostic testing facility, where he ordered unnecessary diagnostic tests. On the basis of these findings, [[Barbara McQuade]], the [[United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan]], won a series of superseding indictments against Fata. They culminated in a 23-count indictment charging Fata with health care fraud, conspiring to take and receive kickbacks, money laundering, and unlawfully procuring naturalization. The last charge was added because McQuade contended Fata had concealed the extent of his fraud from immigration authorities when he applied for citizenship. If convicted on all charges, Fata faced a maximum of 175 years in prison, plus the prospect of having his naturalization revoked.<ref name=sentencingmemo/><ref name=Indictment/>
===Guilty plea=== Facing the prospect of a lifetime in prison and possible [[deportation]] to Lebanon, Fata pleaded guilty before federal judge [[Paul Borman]] on September 20, 2014. He pleaded guilty to 13 counts of health care fraud, one count of conspiracy to pay and receive kickbacks, and two counts of money laundering. In return, the immigration charges were dropped.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.clickondetroit.com/news/michigan-cancer-doctor-farid-fata-pleads-guilty-to-16-counts_20151201033528331|title=Michigan cancer doctor Farid Fata pleads guilty to 16 counts|publisher=[[WDIV]]|date=2014-09-20}}</ref> Nonetheless, McQuade sought the maximum possible sentence of 175 years in prison. Her office argued that the egregiousness of Fata's crimes far exceeded that of [[Bernard Madoff]], and denounced him as "the most egregious fraudster in the history of this country."<ref name=sentencingmemo/>
===Sentencing=== Fata's sentencing hearing began on July 3, 2015. At the hearing, dozens of Fata's victims revealed how the unnecessary chemo treatments had harmed them. For example, Robert Sobieray lost nearly all of his teeth after being falsely diagnosed with blood cancer, and still twitched uncontrollably. Patty Hester lost much of her hair after being falsely told she was terminally ill with [[myelodysplastic syndrome]], and the stress of finding out about Fata's deceit gave her high blood pressure. Another patient, "C. C.," said that due to 177 unnecessary chemo treatments, she had problems with her bladder, bowel and kidneys so serious that she could no longer perform basic tasks.<ref name=sentencingmemo/>
On July 10, 2015, Fata addressed the court for the first time. He said he was "horribly ashamed" at his behavior, and admitted giving in to a "self-destructive" quest for power and wealth. Borman was unmoved, and sentenced Fata to 45 years in prison, saying that Fata had committed "huge, horrific" crimes. The sentence Borman imposed is barely one-fourth of what prosecutors sought, and was deemed insufficient by many of Fata's victims. Nonetheless, at Fata's age, it is very likely that he will die in prison. McQuade publicly thanked Maunglay and Karadsheh for exposing what she described as "the most serious fraud case in the history of the country."<ref name="Berman: Savvy tipster was key in Dr. Fata’s fall" /><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/local/oakland-county/2015/07/10/farid-fata/29955103/|title = Cancer doctor gets 45 years for 'huge, horrific' crimes|last = Brand-Williams|first = Oralandar|date =2015-07-10 |publisher=[[The Detroit News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/farid-fata-gets-45-years-prison-scamming-hundreds-cancer-patients-n389956|title=Farid Fata Gets 45 Years in Prison for Scamming Hundreds of Cancer Patients|author1=Kathryn Nathanson|author2=Anna Schechter|author3=Jon Schuppe|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=2015-07-10}}</ref> Fata also faces myriad civil suits.<ref name=Dateline/> Karadsheh announced in January 2016 that he had reached a $1.7 million settlement.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.theoaklandpress.com/article/OP/20160105/NEWS/160109833|title = Ex-employee settles suit against Dr. Fata, oncologist who mistreated many|last = |first = |date =2016-01-05 |publisher =[[The Associated Press]] |access-date = |via = [[The Oakland Press]]}}</ref> Maunglay, who didn’t file a lawsuit, will not take any financial reward.<ref name="Berman: Savvy tipster was key in Dr. Fata’s fall" />
Fata, [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]] inmate number 48860-039, is serving his sentence at [[Federal Correctional Institution, Williamsburg]] in [[Salters, South Carolina]]. His earliest possible release will be October 19, 2052, when he will be 87 years old.
Fata requested that his guilty plea be tossed in May 2018. His claim is based on the assertion that he received poor legal advice that resulted in his guilty plea and that he has always maintained his innocence, despite his admission of guilt during his sentencing hearing. He stated in the filing "My guilty pleas were not the result of my actually being guilty. From day one to the present, I have steadfastly maintained my innocence."{{cite news |last=Baldas |first=Tresa |date=May 22, 2018 |title=Cancer doctor: I was duped into guilty plea, toss my conviction |url= https://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/detroit/2018/05/22/cancer-doctor-farid-fata-guilty/632820002/ |access-date=July 21, 2018 }}
==Other== Fata's story appeared in the crime show [[American Greed]] in September 2016 as part of season 10, episode 18.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/09/15/greed-report-the-diagnosis-is-bad-should-a-second-opinion-be-your-first-step.html |title=Greed Report: The diagnosis is bad. Should a second opinion be your first step? |last=Cohn |first=Scott |date=15 September 2016 |website=CNBC |publisher=NBC Universal |access-date=14 December 2016 |quote=}}</ref> A 2018 episode of ''Whistleblower'' covered the Fata case with an emphasis on Karadsheh's and Maungley's roles in exposing the fraud.<ref name="whistle">"[https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/whistleblower-exposes-doctor-farid-fata-accused-of-prescribing-chemotherapy-to-patients-without-cancer/ "Whistleblower exposes doctor accused of prescribing chemotherapy to patients who don't have cancer]," ''CBS This Morning'' (preview of ''Whistleblower''), 20 July 2018.</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fata, Farid}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Lebanese people]] [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:People from Oakland County, Michigan]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of the United States federal government]] [[Category:American hematologists]] [[Category:American fraudsters]]

{{Infobox person |honorific_prefix = |name =Francesco Daverio |honorific_suffix = |native_name = |native_name_lang = |image =Bust of Francesco Daverio (1815 - 1849), by Salvatore Buemi .jpg |image_size = |alt =Bust of Francesco Daverio on the
[[Statues and monuments of patriots on the Janiculum|Janiculum in Rome]] |caption =Bust of Francesco Daverio on the
Janiculum in Rome |birth_name = |birth_date ={{Birth date|1815|04|03}} |birth_place =[[Varese]], Italy |disappeared_date = |disappeared_place = |disappeared_status = |death_date ={{Death date and age|1849|06|03|1815|04|03}} |death_place =Rome, Italy |death_cause = |body_discovered = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |monuments = |residence = |nationality =Italian |other_names = |ethnicity = |citizenship = |education = |alma_mater =[[University of Pavia]] |occupation = |years_active = |employer = |organization = |agent = |known_for = |notable_works = |style = |influences = |influenced = |home_town = |salary = |net_worth = |height = |weight = |television = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |movement =''[[Italian unification|Il Risorgimento]]''
(Unification of Italy) |opponents = |boards = |religion = |denomination = |criminal_charge = |criminal_penalty = |criminal_status = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents =Giovan Battista and Maria Cerutti. |relatives = |callsign = |awards = |signature = |signature_alt = |signature_size = |module = |module2 = |module3 = |module4 = |module5 = |module6 = |website = |footnotes = |box_width = }} '''Francesco Daverio''' (April 3, 1815 in Varese – June 3, 1849 in Rome) was a patriot of the Italian unification, Chief of Staff of the [[Roman Republic (19th century)|Roman Republic]], and an engineer, who died on the [[Janiculum]] defending the ''Casino dei quattro venti''. Daverio took part in the [[Five Days of Milan]] in March 1848. In August 1848, he was sent by [[Giuseppe Mazzini]] to guide [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]] in the campaign in Varese. He fought in [[Luino]] and [[Morazzone]] in 1848. In 1849 he fought in [[Velletri]] and defended the [[Roman Republic (19th century)|Roman Republic.]] == Early years == Daverio was born in Varese on April 3, 1815, to the farmer Giovan Battista, and his wife, Maria Cerutti.{{cite web|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/francesco-daverio_(Dizionario_Biografico)/ |title=Francesco Daverio in Dizionario Biografico – Treccani |publisher=Treccani.it |date= |accessdate=2012-02-09}} He completed his pre-college studies in [[Parabiago]] and Varese. In 1834, he entered [[University of Pavia]] and on January 4, 1839 he graduated with a degree in Engineering and Architecture. He worked as an engineer at the Ponti engineering studio in Varese and at the prestigious Gerli engineering studio in Milan. He also was the director and superintendent of the assets of the noble Della Sala family of Varese. He worked for [[Ospedale Maggiore]] in Milan, where he also participated in the Five Days of Milan.{{cite web|url=http://xoomer.virgilio.it/fercova/diz%20artisti%20va/def_artvav_sito.htm |title=def artvav sito |publisher=Xoomer.virgilio.it |date= |accessdate=2012-02-09}} == With Garibaldi == Daverio's first meeting with Garibaldi took place on August 13, 1848, at [[Castelletto sopra Ticino]]. Garibaldi, who had arrived in June or May via [[Nice]] and [[Uruguay]], started the Provisional Government of Lombardy, gathering 1300 volunteers to begin an uprising in [[Varese]]. [[File:22 Francesco Daverio.jpg|thumb|left|Bust of Daverio]] On August 9, 1848, Austria and Piedmont had signed the Salasco Armistice, which Garibaldi found unacceptable. Garibaldi was waiting for aid from Switzerland; Mazzini had promised him guns and 180 men. Only Daverio, the 33-year-old engineer from Varese, had arrived. Mazzini had sent him as a guide. The small army marched during the night from Castelletto sopra Ticino to [[Arona (NO)|Arona]]. Garibaldi seized the steamboats ''San Carlo'' and ''Verbano'' in the port, which had been used by the postal service on the lake. They also seized nine other boats on the lake. They lade small pieces of artillery, 1,286 rations of bread and twenty bags of rice and landed in Luino at eight o'clock in the evening of August 14 with 800 men. [[File:Lugano.jpeg|thumb|Lugano in the early 20th century]] The campaign lasted fifteen days and, after the riots of Luino on August 15 and Morazzone on the 26th, revolution was in the air. Of the 800 men who had gone with him, only seventy followed Garibaldi to [[Switzerland]]. Daverio proved invaluable in guiding the retreat of the forces through the [[Campo dei Fiori di Varese|Campo dei Fiori]] in [[Brusimpiano]], past the shores of Lake Lugano, and out of the country. With a long trip past [[Buguggiate]], [[Capolago]], Varese, Morosolo, [[Casciago]], [[Usmate Velate|Velate]], St. Ambrose, Bregazzana, the German Alps, and Borgnana Cavagna, the patrol arrived in the late evening of August 27 at Casamora, an isolated area between Brusimpiano and Porto. A plaque is still visible from the road along the lake showing the house Garibaldi, exhausted from the long march, slept in. The next night, Brusimpianesi barges carried a troop thinned to about thirty volunteers, defying the Austrian gunboat patrols. Garibaldi went to Agno and then [[Lugano]]. Those who had lost him would eventually reach Switzerland in small groups. Garibaldi's volunteers were not yet ready to take Italy. In Lugano, Daverio didn't waste time and got in touch with his contacts from the uprising in [[Lombardy]]. After the riots started in the fall in [[Val d'Intelvi]], he left Locarno on October 31 and landed in [[Germignaga]], on the Lombardy side of [[Lake Maggiore]], where it reaches [[Luino]]. He was greeted by the ''giunta nazionale d’insurrezione.'' Two Austrian columns rushed from Varese, the uprising failed, and Daverio retreated on the lake from which he came, this time destined for [[Piedmont]].http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/francesco-daverio_(Dizionario-Biografico)/ [[Image:Roma 1849 casino quattro venti.jpg|thumb|left|The debris of the ''Casino dei quattro venti'' after the Siege of Rome]] == 1849 and death == In March 1849 he reappeared in [[Velletri]]. He died, defending Rome at the ''Casino dei quattro venti'' on June 3, 1849,. Almost at the same time, another Varese [[Enrico Dandolo (patriot)|Enrico Dandolo]] died at the [[Palazzo Corsini, Rome|Palazzo Corsini]]. Another young patriot and Varese native, [[Emilio Morosini]], would also die on the Janiculum in June 1849. == Legacy == The Varese technical institute for surveyors is named after him. There are streets named after him in Rome,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5WgWAAAAIAAJ&q=francesco+daverio&dq=francesco+daverio&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rT40T5CZF6fb0QGTp5WjAg&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBDgK |title=WCOTP annual report - World Confederation of Organizations of the Teaching Profession - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-09}} Varese,{{cite web|url=http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/way/20595889 |title=Way | Via Francesco Daverio (20595889) |publisher=OpenStreetMap |date=2010-08-12 |accessdate=2012-02-09}} and Milan.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VaQ6AQAAIAAJ&q=francesco+daverio&dq=francesco+daverio&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rT40T5CZF6fb0QGTp5WjAg&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgK |title=OECD-ICVA directory; development aid of non-governmental non-profit ... - Edwin Eggins, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, International Council of Voluntary Agencies - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-09}} == See also == * [[Italian unification]] * [[Statues and monuments of patriots on the Janiculum]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.isdaverio.va.it/start/ Istituto statale di istruzione secondaria superiore "francesco daverio" istituto tecnico commerciale e per geometri varese] * [http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/francesco-daverio_(Dizionario_Biografico)/ Francesco Daverio in Dizionario Biografico – Treccani] * {{YouTube|M4Zzu59mAWY|Garibaldi a Luino4: Francesco Daverio affianca Garibaldi}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Daverio, Francesco}} [[Category:1815 births]] [[Category:1849 deaths]] [[Category:Italian irredentism]] [[Category:Italian people of the Italian unification]] [[Category:Italian revolutionaries]] [[Category:Italian sailors]] [[Category:People from Varese]] [[Category:People of the Revolutions of 1848]] [[Category:Italian military personnel killed in action]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Gene F. Franklin |image = Gene F. Franklin.jpg |caption = Gene F. Franklin |birth_date = {{Birth date|1927|7|25}} |birth_place = [[Banner Elk, North Carolina]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2012|8|9|1927|7|25}} |death_place = [[Palo Alto]] |residence = [[United States]] |citizenship = [[United States|American]] |nationality = |ethnicity = |fields =[[Electrical Engineering]] {{small|([[Control theory|Controls]])}} |workplaces =[[Stanford University]]
[[NASA]] |alma_mater =[[Georgia Institute of Technology]]
[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]
[[Columbia University]] |doctoral_advisor =[[John R. Ragazzini|John Ralph Ragazzini]] |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for =[[Systems engineering|Systems]] [[Control engineering]] and [[Automatic control|Automatic control theory]]
[[Us space program|U.S. space program]] ([[Apollo program|Apollo mission]]) |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = [[Richard E. Bellman Control Heritage Award]] (2005) |religion = |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Gene F. Franklin''' (July 25, 1927 – August 9, 2012) was an American [[Electrical engineering|electrical engineer]] and [[Control theory|control theorist]] known for his pioneering work towards the advancement of the [[control systems engineering]] – a subfield of [[electrical engineering]]. Most of his work on [[control theory]] was adapted immediately into [[NASA]]'s [[Us space program|U.S. space program]], most famously in the control systems for the [[Apollo program|Apollo missions]] to the [[moon]] in [[History of the United States (1964–80)|1960s–70s]].{{cite web|last1=Stanford University Press|first1=Engineering|title=Gene F. Franklin, Professor Emeritus of Electrical Engineering, dies at 85|url=https://engineering.stanford.edu/news/gene-f-franklin-professor-emeritus-electrical-engineering-dies-85|website=School of Engineering|publisher=Stanford University Press|accessdate=26 June 2017|language=en|date=9 June 2016}} He is also noted for his authorship of influential texts on the [[control system]], most notably, ''Feedback Control of Dynamic Systems'', which has been translated into numerous of languages and has received literary prizes as the best book in the [[Engineering disciplines|discipline]] of [[Control theory|controls]]. ==Biography== Franklin was born in [[Banner Elk]] in [[North Carolina]], [[United States]], on July 25, 1927. His father was a professor of [[mathematics]] at the local college, and his mother was a [[Registered Nurse|nurse]], an [[Registered Nurse|RN]] at the local hospital. He joined the [[United States Navy]] in 1945, serving in [[World War II]], and was assigned to Navy's [[Radar in World War II|radar systems]]. He lost his enthusiasm for the navy after [[President of the United States|President]] [[Harry S. Truman|Truman]]'s decision of [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|atomic bombings]] of Japanese cities of [[Hiroshima]] and [[Nagasaki]]. He took a transfer to study electronics and taught a course on electronics at the [[Great Lakes Naval Training Center]]. He took a discharge from the navy on medical grounds and joined [[Georgia Institute of Technology]].{{cite web|title=Gene F. Franklin —American Automatic Control Council|url=http://a2c2.org/awards/richard-e-bellman-control-heritage-award/2005-00-00t000000/gene-f-franklin|website=a2c2.org|publisher= American Automatic Control Council|accessdate=26 June 2017|language=en}} He received his [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] degree in [[electrical engineering]] from the [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] in 1950, his [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in electrical engineering from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] in 1952, and his [[Doctor of Engineering|D.E.]] [[Science|Sc.]] degree from [[Columbia University]] in 1955. Franklin's 1958 doctoral thesis “''Sampled-Data Control Systems''” (co-authored by Franklin's dissertation advisor, [[John R. Ragazzini]]) introduced digital control to a discipline which had previously operated almost exclusively in the analog domain.{{cite web|title=Gene Franklin - The Mathematics Genealogy Project|url=https://www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=107323|website=www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu|publisher=The Mathematics Genealogy Project|accessdate=27 June 2017}} This breakthrough allowed control systems to become much more precise and reliable. He taught at [[Columbia University]] from 1955 to 1957 before moving to [[Stanford University]], where he was professor emeritus of electrical engineering until his death in August 2012. His research encompassed all aspects of control incorporating digital logic, including adaptive control of both nonlinear systems and systems with multiple-data sampling. He was a recipient of the [[Richard E. Bellman Control Heritage Award]] in 2005 for "fundamental contributions to the theory and practice of digital, modern, adaptive, and multivariable control".{{cite web|url=http://a2c2.org/awards/richard-e-bellman-control-heritage-award |title=Richard E. Bellman Control Heritage Award |publisher=[[American Automatic Control Council]] |accessdate={{Format date|2013|2|10}}}} On August 9, 2012, he died at [[Stanford Hospital]] in [[Palo Alto]] at the age of 85.[http://engineering.stanford.edu/obituary/gene-f-franklin-professor-emeritus-electrical-engineering-dies-85 Gene F. Franklin, professor emeritus of electrical engineering, dies at 85] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508055310/http://engineering.stanford.edu/obituary/gene-f-franklin-professor-emeritus-electrical-engineering-dies-85 |date=2013-05-08 }}, ''[[Stanford University School of Engineering]] ==Notes== ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080429200800/http://www.a2c2.org/awards/bellman/index2004_2008.php#2005 AACC page] {{Richard E. Bellman Control Heritage Award}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Franklin, Gene F.}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:American electrical engineers]] [[Category:Control theorists]] [[Category:Georgia Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Richard E. Bellman Control Heritage Award recipients]] [[Category:NASA people]] [[Category:United States Navy officers]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox person |name= Hanna Gharib
حنا غريب |image=HannaGharib1.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1953|09|28|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Halba, Lebanon|Halba]], [[Akkar]] |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = [[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese]] |other_names = |education = |employer = |occupation = Politician |home_town = [[Beirut]] |title = General Secretary |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = [[Lebanese Communist Party]] |boards = |religion = |spouse = Wafaa Bitar |partner = |children = |parents = |relatives = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Hanna Gharib''' ({{lang-ar|حنا غريب}}; born 28 ٍSeptember 1953) is a [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] politician and the current general secretary of the [[Lebanese Communist Party]] (LCP).{{cite news|url=http://www.annahar.com/article/366286-%D8%AD%D9%86%D8%A7-%D8%BA%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A8-%D8%A3%D9%85%D9%8A%D9%86%D8%A7-%D8%B9%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7-%D9%84-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D9%8A%D9%88%D8%B9%D9%8A-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D8%B2%D9%83%D9%8A%D8%A9|title= حنا غريب أميناً عاماً للحزب الشيوعي بالتزكية |newspaper=Annahar Newspaper|date=26 April 2016}} ==Early life and education== He was born in September 1953 in the city of [[Tripoli]] in Northern [[Lebanon]] to a poor family of six children. His father was a Lebanese army soldier. After the retirement of his father from the army, the family moved to [[Rahbeh]], their original town in [[Akkar]] in the north where he joined its official primary and secondary school. [[File:HannaGharib3.jpg|thumb|Gharib in the Union of Lebanese Democratic Youth]] During this period he joined the [[Union of Lebanese Democratic Youth]], a [[secular]] left-wing youth organization where he met with communists who attracted him with their ideas of social justice and equality. He continued his university studies in the [[Lebanese University]] in [[Beirut]] where he studied [[Chemistry]] at the faculty of education.{{cite news|url=http://www.mc-doualiya.com/articles/20160427-%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D8%B0%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%AD%D9%86%D8%A7-%D8%BA%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%B2%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D9%8A%D9%88%D8%B9%D9%8A-%D9%84%D8%A8%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%86|title=من هو حنا غريب الأمين العام للحزب الشيوعي |newspaper=Monte Carlo News|date=27 April 2016}} ==Career== After graduation, Gharib became a public secondary teacher in [[Chemistry]] first in the city of [[Sidon|Saida]] in the south where he taught [[Ibrahime Al-Amine]], the current general director of [[Al Akhbar (Lebanon)|Akhbar]] newspaper.{{cite news|url=http://al-akhbar.com/node/179152|title=حنا غريب |newspaper=Akhbar Newspaper|date=11 March 2013}} Afterwards, he moved to teach in Beirut in the public and the private sectors. He remained an active teacher despite the big load that he had after becoming the Leader of the League of Public Secondary Teachers and later the coordinator of the Syndicate Coordination Committee that was formed between the union and leagues of public and private teachers and the public employees. Under his leadership, the unions organized continuous demonstrations demanding increases in the wages and proposing progressive taxes and more taxation on the interests and real estate companies. The popular movements lasted from 2012 till 2015 with diverse actions including sit-ins, demonstrations, and general strikes.{{cite news|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/15195|title= The never ending wages battle |newspaper= Akhbar English|date=6 March 2015}} In addition to the governmental and presidential palaces, the ministry of finance and the ministry of education, the demonstrations reached the economic ports of the country like the sea port and the airport.{{cite news|url=http://www.saidaonline.com/en/news.php?go=fullnews&newsid=44714|title= Unions to expand sit-ins to Beirut Airport and port|newspaper= Saida Online|date=13 March 2013}} [[File:HannaGharib2.jpg|thumb|Gharib leading a demonstration for teachers and public employees]] Due to escalating discourse and action against the government and persisting stances on the rights of the teachers and employees, the political parties loyal to the government formed a large coalition in the teachers syndicate elections to defeat Hanna Gharib and they succeeded in doing so {{cite news|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/164667|title= Parties Defeat Hanna Gharib in Teachers Elections|newspaper= Naharnet News|date=25 January 2015}} after forming a list supported by 11 parties against the list of Gharib which got 46% of the votes despite all odds. This ended Gharib's career in the leadership of the unions. During this time, Gharib was a leading member of the [[Lebanese Communist Party]] where he raised in ranks to its central committee then its political bureau for two terms. With increased public presence and media coverage, he was a well-known public figure in [[Lebanon]] especially among the communists and left-wing supporters. After the party's 11th conference in April 2016, Gharib was elected by consensus as the general secretary of the party. He is the seventh leader of the party after [[Fuad Shemali]], [[Farajallah el-Helou]], Nicolas Shawi, [[George Hawi]], Farouk Dahrouj and [[Khaled Hadadi]]. ==Personal life== Hanna Gharib is married to Wafaa Bitar, the daughter of Isber Bitar who was one of the historical figures of the [[Lebanese Communist Party]]. He has a son and a daughter named Walid and Hala. ==See also== * [[Lebanese Communist Party]] * [[Union of Lebanese Democratic Youth]] * [[Politics of Lebanon]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gharib, Hanna}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Lebanese Communist Party politicians]] [[Category:Trade unionists]] [[Category:Lebanese left-wing activists]] [[Category:Lebanese University alumni]]
