{{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = Count | name = Honoré Joseph Antoine Ganteaume | image = Ganteaume.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1755|4|13|df=yes}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1818|7|28|1755|4|13|df=yes}} | placeofburial_label = Place of burial | placeofburial = | birth_place = [[La Ciotat]] | death_place = [[Aubagne]] | placeofburial_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | nickname = | allegiance = {{flag|France}} | branch = [[French Navy]] | serviceyears = | rank = [[Vice Admiral]] | unit = | commands = | battles = ;[[American Revolutionary War]] *[[Capture of Grenada]] *[[Siege of Savannah]] ;[[French Revolutionary Wars]] * [[Glorious First of June]] {{WIA}} * [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]] * [[Battle of Hyères Islands]] * [[Battle of the Nile]] {{WIA}} * [[Ganteaume's expeditions of 1801]] ;[[Napoleonic Wars]] | awards = | relations = | laterwork = }} Count '''Honoré Joseph Antoine Ganteaume''' (13 April 1755 in [[La Ciotat]]<ref name=levot206>Levot, p.206</ref> – 28 July 1818 in [[Aubagne]]<ref name=levot208>Levot, p.208</ref>) was a [[France|French]] Navy officer and Vice-admiral.
Ganteaume started sailing on Indiamen, before serving during the [[American War of Independence]] in the fleets of Admiral [[Charles Hector, comte d'Estaing|d'Estaing]] and [[Pierre André de Suffren de Saint Tropez|Suffren]]. At the French Revolution, he was promoted to command the 74-gun [[French ship Trente-et-un Mai|''Trente-et-un Mai'']], taking part in the [[Glorious First of June]] and the [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]].
Ganteaume took part in the Expedition to Egypt, narrowly escaping death during the [[Battle of the Nile]]. There, he formed a personal relationship with General Bonaparte, who supported his promotion. He was made a Rear-Admiral and given command of a squadron to supply the Army of Egypt, but in [[Ganteaume's expeditions of 1801]], he engaged in months of complicated maneuvers to elude the Royal Navy and eventually failed his mission.
He supplied the French forces of the [[Saint-Domingue expedition]]. During the [[Trafalgar Campaign]], Ganteaume was to lead his squadron to the Caribbean to reinforce [[Pierre-Charles Villeneuve|Villeneuve]] and [[Édouard Thomas Burgues de Missiessy|Missiessy]], but he was blockaded by British squadrons. Ganteaume held various offices during the late [[First French Empire]], and gave his loyalty to [[Louis XVIII of France|Louis XVIII]] at the [[Bourbon Restoration]].
== Career == Ganteaume was born in [[La Ciotat]], into a family of merchant sailors. He started sailing at the age of 14<ref name=michaud98>Michaud, p.98</ref> on a merchantman commanded by his father,<ref name=levot206 /> and by the time he reached the age of 22, Ganteaume had accomplished five campaigns in the Middle East and two in the Caribbean.<ref name=levot206 /><ref name=michaud98 /> He served on the [[Mississippi Company]] Indiaman [[French ship Fier Rodrigue|''Fier Rodrigue'']].<ref name=michaud98 />
=== Service in the American War of Independence === In 1778, with the intervention of [[France in the American Revolutionary War]], Ganteaume enlisted in the French Royal Navy as an auxiliary officer,<ref name=levot206 /> while ''Fier Rodrigue'' was purchased into naval service as a 54-gun [[ship of the line]].<ref name=michaud98 /> ''Fier Rodrigue'' escorted a convoy to America, and attached to a division under [[Toussaint-Guillaume Picquet de la Motte|Lamotte-Picquet]]<ref name=granier437>Granier, p.437</ref> in the fleet of Admiral [[Charles Hector, comte d'Estaing|d'Estaing]].<ref name=michaud98 />
In the fleet of Admiral d'Estaing, Ganteaume took part in the [[Capture of Grenada]] and in the [[Siege of Savannah]].<ref name=levot206 /> In 1781, he was promoted to auxiliary Frigate Lieutenant,<ref name=michaud98 /> and appointed to command the fluyt ''Marlborough'' in a convoy bound for the [[Indies]] and escorted by [[Pierre André de Suffren de Saint Tropez|Suffren]].<ref name=michaud98 />
From 1781 to 1785, Ganteaume served on the frigate [[French frigate Surveillante (1778)|''Surveillante'']]<ref name=michaud98 /><ref group=note>Michaud (p.98) also mentions the "frigate ''Apollon''", but no ship name [[French ship Apollon|''Apollon'']] was in service in the French Navy between 1758 and 1788 (furthermore, ''Apollon'' is an unlikely name for a frigate and more suitable for a ship of the line).</ref> He was promoted to Fireship Captain<ref group=note>''Capitaine de brûlot''</ref> in 1784, and sub-Lieutenant<ref group=note>''Sous-lieutenant de vaisseau''</ref> in 1786.<ref name=michaud98 />
Upon his return at the peace, Ganteaume was granted permission to return to the service of the Mississippi Company.<ref name=michaud98 /> He successively commanded the Indiamen ''Maréchal de Ségur'', bound for Chian, and ''Prince de Condé'' and ''Constitution'', bound for the Indies.<ref name=michaud98 /> In 1793, he was captured on an Indiaman<ref name=granier437 /> and imprisoned by the British;<ref name=levot206 /> released, he returned to the Navy, with the rank of Lieutenant.<ref name=levot206 /><ref name=michaud98 /> He served on the 74-gun [[French ship Jupiter (1789)|''Jupiter'']] for a campaign in the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name=michaud98 />
=== Service on ''Trente-et-un Mai'' === [[File:Mb-vista-entera-min.jpg|thumb|The 74-gun [[French ship Trente-et-un Mai|''Trente-et-un Mai'']], which Ganteaume commanded between 1794 and 1795]] Ganteaume was promoted to Captain in 1794,<ref name=levot206 /> and was appointed to command the 74-gun [[French ship Trente-et-un Mai|''Trente-et-un Mai'']].<ref name=levot206 /> During the [[Atlantic campaign of May 1794]], he attempted to attach to the French fleet under [[Louis Thomas Villaret de Joyeuse|Villaret-Joyeuse]], but only joined late in the [[Glorious First of June]]; he took part in the last throes of the battle, where he was thrice wounded.<ref name=levot206 />
In the winter, Geanteaume led ''Trente-et-un Mai'' in the [[Croisière du Grand Hiver]], and notably rescued the crew of the stricken [[French ship Saint-Esprit (1766)|''Scipion'']].<ref name=levot207>Levot, p.207</ref>
In 1795, ''Trente-et-un Mai'' sailed to the Mediterranean, and cruised off [[Catalonia]];<ref name=michaud98 /> she sustained a two-hour battle against a Spanish ship of the line.<ref name=michaud98 /> On 18 April 1795,<ref>Roche, p.313-314</ref> ''Trente-et-un Mai'' was renamed ''Républicain''. She attached to the fleet under Vice-Admiral [[Pierre Martin (French Navy officer)|Martin]], and took part in the [[Battle of Hyères Islands]].<ref name=levot207 />
In late 1795, Ganteaume was appointed to command a division in an [[Ganteaume's expedition of 1795|expedition to Smyrna]], comprising one ship of the line, four frigates and four corvettes. He sailed to [[Smyrna]], where he lifted the blockade on [[Pierre-Charles Villeneuve|Villeneuve]]'s squadron,<ref name=michaud98 /> and captured the frigate [[HMS Nemesis (1780)|HMS ''Nemesis'']].<ref name=granier437 />
In 1796, returned to the Ocean,<ref name=michaud98 /> Ganteaume successful ran the British blockade of Brest and sailed a convoy carrying munitions into the harbour.<ref name=levot207 />
=== Service in Egypt === Appointed [[Chief of staff]] to Rear-Admiral and [[List of Naval Ministers of France|Navy Minister]] [[Étienne Eustache Bruix|Bruix]],<ref name=levot207 /> Ganteaume took part in the [[French campaign in Egypt and Syria]] on the flagship [[French ship Orient (1791)|''Orient'']].<ref name=michaud98 /> He took part in the [[Battle of the Nile]], where he was wounded,<ref name=michaud98 /> and narrowly escaped death when he left the burning ''Orient''<ref name=levot207 /> on a boat.<ref name=granier437 /> ''Orient'' exploded soon after.
Promoted to Rear-Admiral upon request of General [[Napoléon I of France|Bonaparte]],<ref name=levot207 /> Ganteaume led the flotilla of small ships of the Nile River, taking part in the [[Siege of Jaffa]], the [[Siege of Acre (1799)|Siege of Acre]] and the [[Battle of Abukir (1799)|Battle of Abukir]].<ref name=michaud98 />
On 22 August 1799, Ganteaume departed Alexandria with the frigates [[French frigate Muiron|''Muiron'']] and [[HMS Carrere (1801)|''Carrère'']], the [[aviso]] ''Revanche'' and a [[tartane]],<ref name=michaud98 /> ferrying General Bonaparte back to France.<ref name=levot207 /> Bonaparte ordered the ships to sail close to the shore of Africa to elude British squadrons, and landed in Corsica, to finally arrive at [[Fréjus]] on 2 October.<ref name=michaud98 />
After arriving in France, Bonaparte, as [[First Consul]], appointed Ganteaume to the Council of State, in which he presided the section of the Navy.<ref name=michaud98 />
=== Ganteaume's expeditions of 1801 === {{main|Ganteaume's expeditions of 1801}} In 1801,<ref name=michaud98 /> Ganteaume was appointed to command a seven-ship division in Brest, tasked with ferrying supplies and 5000 soldiers to the French Army of Egypt.<ref name=levot207 /> After successfully crossing British-held [[Gibraltar]], Ganteaume cruised in the Mediterranean for six months to elude the British fleet.<ref name=levot207 />
Ganteaume returned to Toulon to resupply and repair his ships.<ref name=levot207 /> In the following months, he attempted three sorties, once arriving off Alexandria without landing:<ref name=levot207 /> when he finally arrived near Egypt, actually [[Derna, Libya]], in June 1800, the troops did not land, due to the hostility of the locals and the British naval threat.<ref>Mackesy, [https://books.google.com/?id=gQAOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA162 p.162]</ref><ref>Strathern, [https://books.google.com/?id=yTYrggiKvgcC&pg=PA418 p. 418]</ref>
Ganteaume eventually renounced and defiantly returned to Toulon, after capturing [[Elba]] and four British ships,<ref name=michaud98 /> including the 38-gun frigate [[HMS Success (1781)|HMS ''Success'']], and in the [[Action of 24 June 1801]], the 74-gun [[HMS Swiftsure (1787)|HMS ''Swiftsure'']], but failing his mission to supply the French armies in the Middle East.
Ganteaume's tergiversations motivated the satirical poem:<ref name=michaud98 /> {| width=800px |- |''<poem> ::Vaisseaux lestés, tête sans lest, ::Ainsi part l'amiral Ganteaume; ::Il s'en va de Brest à Bertheaume, ::Et revient de Bertheaume à Brest.</poem> |<poem> :Loaded ships, head without weight, :Thus departs Admiral Ganteaume; :He sails off from Brest to Bertheaume, :And sails back from Bertheaume to Brest.</poem> |}
=== Service in Saint-Domingue and the Trafalgar Campaign === After the [[Treaty of Lunéville]] ended the [[War of the Second Coalition]] in early 1801, Ganteaume was tasked with supporting the French forces involved in the [[Saint-Domingue expedition]].<ref name=levot207 /> In 1802, Ganteaume was appointed [[Maritime Prefect]] for Toulon.<ref name=michaud98 />
At the outbreak of the [[War of the Third Coalition]] the year after, and with the [[Coronation of Napoleon I]] and the advent of the [[First French Empire]] on 2 December 1804, Ganteaume was promoted to [[Vice-Admiral]],<ref name=levot207 /> made a [[Count of the Empire]],<ref name=levot207 /> and appointed to command the fleet in Brest.<ref name=levot207 />
In 1805, after the death of Vice-Admiral [[Louis-René Levassor de Latouche Tréville|Latouche-Tréville]] and the outbreak of the [[Trafalgar Campaign]], Napoléon briefly considered entrusting Ganteaume with an expedition to land an 18 000-man army in [[Ireland]],<ref name=levot207 /> in a move similar to what had been attempted in 1796 with the ill-fated [[Expédition d'Irlande]]; eventually, Ganteaume was ordered to the Caribbean to land reinforcements there and return to Europe with the fleets under Rear-Admiral [[Édouard Thomas Burgues de Missiessy|Missiessy]] and Vice-Admiral [[Pierre-Charles Villeneuve|Villeneuve]].<ref name=levot207 />
Adverse weather prevented Ganteaume from leaving Brest, and he finally departed one month after Missiessy.<ref name=levot207 /> In transit, Ganteaume bumped into the British [[Channel Fleet]] under Admiral [[William Cornwallis|Cornwallis]] and retreated to Brest, where he ended up hermetically blocked.<ref name=levot207 /> Informed of the [[Battle of Cape Finisterre (1805)|Battle of Cape Finisterre]], Ganteaume was ordered to break into the Ocean by force to make his junction with Villeneuve;<ref name=levot207 /> however, Villeneuve's port call to Cadiz thwarted this plan.<ref name=levot208 />
=== Later career === In 1808, Ganteaume took command of the French squadrons of Toulon and Rochefort, joined together at Toulon, with the aim to ferry supplies to Corfu, then blockaded by the Royal Navy.<ref name=levot208 /> He departed Toulon in early February, successfully escorted his convoy into Corfu harbour, and returned to Toulon in April.<ref name=michaud98 /> In February on the following year, he authorised the frigates [[French frigate Pénélope (1806)|''Pénélope'']] and ''[[French frigate Pauline (1807)|Pauline]]'' to chase [[French frigate Proserpine (1809)|HMS ''Proserpine'']], yielding the [[Action of 27 February 1809]] in which ''Proserpine'' was captured and brought to Toulon.<ref name=michaud98 />
In June 1808, Ganteaume was appointed General Inspector of the Coasts of the Ocean.<ref name=levot208 /> From 1809 to 1810, Ganteaume was appointed to command the fleet in Toulon, but attacks to [[gout]] kept him increasingly away from the sea.<ref name=levot208 /> In 1810, he joined the Council of the Admiralty.<ref name=levot208 /> On 1 August 1811, Napoléon appointed Ganteaume to command the battalion of the [[Marins de la Garde]] in the [[Imperial Guard (Napoleon I)|Imperial Guard]] as a Colonel.<ref name=marineimperiale>[http://marine-imperiale.pagesperso-orange.fr/amiraux/ganteaume.htm Comte Honoré Joseph Antoine GANTEAUME]</ref> In 1813, he defended Toulon.<ref name=granier437 />
In 1814, at the first [[Bourbon Restoration]], Ganteaume supported the [[Acte de déchéance de l'Empereur]], and in consequence did not return to command during the [[Hundred Days]];<ref name=michaud98 /> immediately after the [[Battle of Waterloo]], he ordered the Royalist white flag hoisted in Toulon;<ref name=levot208 /> this act got him almost killed.<ref name=levot208 />
Restored to power again, [[Louis XVIII of France|Louis XVIII]] made Ganteaume a [[Peerage of France|Peer of France]] in recognition for his support.<ref name=levot208 /> In December 1815,<ref name=michaud98 /> he was promoted to Commander in the [[Order of Saint Louis]],<ref name=levot208 /> and appointed General Inspector of the Classes.<ref name=levot208 /> In his capacity of Peer of France, Ganteaume took part in the trial of Marshal [[Michel Ney|Ney]], and voted for his execution.<ref name=granier437 /><ref name=marineimperiale />
Ganteaume died at his property of Pauline, near Aubagne, on 28 September 1818.<ref name=levot208 />
==Notes and references ==

=== Bibliography === * {{cite book|title=Histoire des Marins français 1789-1815|first=Hubert|last=Granier|others=illustrations by Alain Coz|publisher=Marines éditions|year=1998|isbn=2-909675-41-6}} * {{cite book|title=Les gloires maritimes de la France: notices biographiques sur les plus célèbres marins|last=Levot|first=Prosper|authorlink=Prosper Levot|year=1866|publisher=Bertrand|url=https://books.google.com/?id=08O_XGLO43QC|language=French}} * {{cite book|title=British victory in Egypt, 1801: the end of Napoleon's conquest|last=Mackesy|first=Piers|year=1995|publisher=Routledge|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gQAOAAAAQAAJ|isbn=0-415-04064-7}} * {{cite book|title=Biographie universelle, ancienne et moderne|last1=Michaud|first1=Joseph François|authorlink1=Joseph François Michaud|last2=Michaud|first2=Louis Gabriel|year=1838|publisher=Michaud|location=Paris|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h2AJAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA98|language=French|volume=65|page=98|chapter=Ganteaume|oclc=7840944}} * {{cite book|first=Jean-Michel|last=Roche|year=2005|title=Dictionnaire des bâtiments de la flotte de guerre française de Colbert à nos jours|isbn=978-2-9525917-0-6|oclc=165892922|publisher=Group Retozel-Maury Millau|volume=1}} * {{cite book|first=Paul|last=Strathern|year=2008|title=Napoleon in Egypt|isbn=978-0-553-80678-6|publisher=Bantam Books|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/?id=yTYrggiKvgcC}}

{{use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox military person |name=Ibn al-Khattab
ابن الخطاب |birth_date={{birth date|1969|4|14|df=y}} |death_date={{death date and age|2002|3|20|1969|4|14|df=y}} |allegiance=[[File:Flag of Jihad.svg|22px]] [[Mujahideen|Mujahideen of Afghanistan]]
[[File:Flag of Chechen Republic of Ichkeria.svg|22px]] [[Chechen Republic of Ichkeria]]
{{flagicon|Bosnia and Herzegovina|1992}} [[Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
[[United Tajik Opposition]] (Loyalty was to the Islamic factions in Tajikistan) |commands=[[Arab Mujahideen in Chechnya]]
[[Islamic Peacekeeping Brigade]] |birth_place=[[Arar, Saudi Arabia]] |death_place=[[Chechnya]] |image=Ibnkhattab.jpg |nickname=Khattab |rank=General |battles=[[Soviet–Afghan War]]
[[Tajikistan Civil War]]
[[Bosnian War]]
[[First Chechen War]]
[[Dagestan War]]
[[Second Chechen War]] |awards=}} '''Samir Saleh Abdullah''' ({{lang-ar|سامر صالح عبد الله }}; 14 April 1969 – 20 March 2002), more commonly known as '''Ibn al-Khattab''' or '''Emir Khattab''' (also transliterated as [[Amir]] Khattab and Ameer Khattab, meaning Commander Khattab, or Leader Khattab), was a [[Saudi Arabia]]n-born leader in the [[First Chechen War]] and the [[Second Chechen War]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ctc.usma.edu/v2/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/CTC_Khattab-Jihadi-Bio-February2015-3.pdf |title=Khattab |publisher=Combating Terrorism Center |accessdate=2015-03-05 |author=Muhammad al-`Ubaydi |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150814143452/https://www.ctc.usma.edu/v2/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/CTC_Khattab-Jihadi-Bio-February2015-3.pdf |archivedate=14 August 2015 }} The origins and real identity of Khattab remained a mystery to most until after his death, when his brother gave an interview to the press.{{cite web|url=http://www.islamawareness.net/Persecution/Chechnya/khattab.html|title=Khattab, the man who died for the cause of Chechnya|work=Islam Awareness|accessdate=20 May 2015}} He died on 20 March 2002 following exposure to a poison letter delivered via a courier who had been recruited by Russia's [[Federal Security Service]]. ==Biography== Khattab was born in [[Arar, Saudi Arabia]] and of partial [[Circassians|Circassian]] origin. ===Central Asia and the Balkans=== At the age of 18, Khattab left Saudi Arabia to participate in the fight against the [[Soviet Union]] during the [[Soviet invasion of Afghanistan]]. During this time, he permanently incapacitated his right hand and lost several fingers after an accident with [[improvised explosive]]s. The injury was [[Prophetic medicine|treated]] with [[Honey#Religious significance|honey]] by Khattab on himself.{{cite book|author=Paul J. Murphy|title=The Wolves of Islam: Russia and the Faces of Chechen Terror |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bu7sAAAAIAAJ&q=khattab+honey+russians&dq=khattab+honey+russians&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwibzMfRhIjPAhUBXR4KHXndAHEQ6AEIJDAB|year=2004|publisher=Brassey's|isbn=978-1-57488-830-0|page=35}} Khattab, while the leader of [[Islamic International Brigade]], publicly admitted that he spent the period between 1989 and 1994 in Afghanistan and that he had met [[Osama Bin Laden]]. In March 1994, Khattab arrived in Afghanistan and toured [[Afghan training camp|fighter training camps]] in [[Khost province]]. He returned to Afghanistan with the first group of Chechen militants in May 1994. Khattab underwent training in Afghanistan and had close connections with [[al-Qaeda]]. Several hundred Chechens eventually trained in al-Qaeda camps in Afghanistan.Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1267 (1999) concerning Al-Qaida and the Taliban and Associated Individuals and Entities[https://www.un.org/sc/committees/1267/NSQE09903E.shtml QE.I.99.03. ISLAMIC INTERNATIONAL BRIGADE (IIB)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514193822/http://www.un.org/sc/committees/1267/NSQE09903E.shtml |date=14 May 2011 }} "Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1267 (1999) concerning Al-Qaida and the Taliban and Associated Individuals and Entities" [[Armenia]]n sources claim that in 1992 he was one of many Chechen volunteers who aided [[Azerbaijan]] in the embattled region of [[Nagorno-Karabakh]], where he allegedly met [[Shamil Basayev]]. However, the Azerbaijani [[Ministry of Defense (Azerbaijan)|Ministry of Defense]] denied any involvement by Khattab in the [[Nagorno-Karabakh war]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eurasianet.org/departments/insight/articles/eav051402.shtml|title=Chechen Fighter's Death Reveals Conflicted Feelings in Azerbaijan|work=EurasiaNet|accessdate=20 May 2015}}{{cite news|title=Terror in Karabakh: Chechen Warlord Shamil Basayev's Tenure in Azerbaijan |url=http://ermeni.org/english/chechen-terrorists-azerbaijan.htm |accessdate=2007-02-15 |publisher=The Armenian Weekly On-Line: AWOL |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070214081307/http://ermeni.org/english/chechen-terrorists-azerbaijan.htm |archivedate=14 February 2007 }} From 1993 to 1995, Khattab left to fight alongside [[Islam]]ic opposition in the [[Tajikistan Civil War]]. Before leaving for [[Tajikistan]] in 1994, al-Khattab gave [[Abdulkareem Khadr]] a pet rabbit of his own, which was promptly named Khattab. In an interview, Khattab once mentioned he had also been involved in the [[War in Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. The fragment of this interview in which he makes this statement can be found in the 2004 [[BBC]] documentary ''The Smell of Paradise'', though he did not specify his exact role or the duration of his presence there.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YYP7D3p44Ak |title=BBC Four - The Smell of Paradise |publisher=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=3 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009115604/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YYP7D3p44Ak |archivedate=9 October 2015 }} ===First Chechen War=== According to Khattab's brother, he first heard about the Chechen conflict on an Afghan television channel in 1995; that same year, he entered Chechnya, posing as a television reporter. He was credited as being a pioneer in producing video footage of Chechen rebel combat operations in order to aid [[fundraising]] efforts and [[morale|demoralize]] the enemy. During the [[First Chechen War]], Khattab participated in fighting [[Russia]]n forces and acted as an intermediary financier between foreign [[Muslim]] funding sources and the local fighters. To help secure funding and spread the message of resistance, he was frequently accompanied by at least one cameraman. His units were credited with several devastating [[ambush]]es on Russian columns in the Chechen mountains. His first action was the October 1995 ambush of a Russian convoy which killed 47 soldiers.''The Wolves of Islam: Russia and the Faces of Chechen Terror'', Murphy, Paul J., 2004 Khattab gained early fame and a great notoriety in Russia for his April 1996 [[Shatoy ambush|ambush of a large armored column]] in a narrow gorge of Yaryshmardy, near [[Shatoy]], which killed up to 100 soldiers and destroyed some two or three dozen vehicles. In another ambush, near [[Vedeno]], at least 28 Russian troops were killed.[http://edition.cnn.com/WORLD/9604/01/russia_chechnya/ Russian fighting ceases in Chechnya; Skeptical troops comply with Yeltsin order] [[CNN]] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080313101520/http://edition.cnn.com/WORLD/9604/01/russia_chechnya/ |date=March 13, 2008 }} . In the course of the war, [[Shamil Basayev]] became his closest ally and personal friend. He was also associated with [[Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev]], who gave Khattab two of the highest Chechen military awards, the Order of Honor and the Brave Warrior medal, and promoted him to the rank of [[general]]. A senior Chechen commander by the name of Izmailov told press how Khattab urged restraint, citing the [[Koran]], when at the end of the war the Chechens wanted to shoot those they considered traitors.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C02EFD81F30F934A25753C1A96F958260 Muslim Fighter Embraces Warrior Mystique], ''The New York Times'', 17 October 1999 ===Chechnya=== After the conclusion of the war, Khattab, by then wanted by [[Interpol]] on Russia's request, became a prominent [[warlord]] and commanded the [[Arab Mujahideen in Chechnya]], his own [[private army]] with a group of Arabs, Turks and other foreign fighters who had come to participate in the war. He set up a network of [[paramilitary]] camps in the mountainous parts of the [[republic]] that trained not only Chechens, but also [[Muslim]]s from the [[North Caucasus|North Caucasian]] Russian republics and [[Central Asia]]. On 22 December 1997, over a year after the signing of the [[Khasav-Yurt Accord|Khasav-Yurt treaty]] and the end of the first war in Chechnya, the Arab mujahideen and a group of Dagestani rebels raided the base of the 136th Armoured [[Brigade]] of the 58th Division of the [[Russian Ground Forces|Russian Army]] in [[Buinaksk]], [[Dagestan]]. ===Dagestan War=== In 1998, along with [[Shamil Basayev]], Khattab created the [[Islamic International Peacekeeping Brigade]] (IIPB) group (also known as the Islamic Peacekeeping Army). In August–September 1999, they led the [[Dagestan War|IIPB's incursions into Dagestan]], which resulted in the deaths of at least several hundred people and effectively started the [[Second Chechen War]]. ===1999 bombings in Russia=== A [[Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation]] (FSB) investigation named Khattab as the mastermind behind the September 1999 [[Russian apartment bombings]].{{cite book |title=The Wolves of Islam: Russia and the Faces of Chechen Terror |last=Murphy |first=Paul |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2004 |publisher=Potomac Books Inc. |location= |isbn=978-1-57488-830-0 |page=106 }} However, on 14 September 1999, Khattab told the Russian [[Interfax]] news agency in [[Grozny]] that he had nothing to do with the [[Moscow]] explosions; he was quoted as saying, ''"We would not like to be akin to those who kill sleeping civilians with bombs and shells."''{{cite web|url=http://www.ict.org.il/articles/articledet.cfm?articleid%3D94 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=19 December 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050410090541/http://www.ict.org.il/articles/articledet.cfm?articleid=94 |archivedate=10 April 2005 }} The conclusion by the FSB remains controversial. Some researchers, such as [[Johns Hopkins University]]/[[Hoover Institute]] scholar [[David Satter]],Satter, David. ''Darkness at Dawn: The Rise of the Russian Criminal State''. [[Yale University Press]]:2003, {{ISBN|0-300-09892-8}} came to conclusion that the bombings were in fact a "[[false flag]]" attack perpetrated by the FSB in order to legitimate the resumption of military activities in Chechnya.{{cite book |title=Putin, Russia's choice |last=Sakwa |first=Richard |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2008 |edition=2nd |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-0-415-40765-6 |pages=333–334 }} ===Second Chechen War=== During the course of the war, Khattab participated in leading his [[militia]] against Russian forces in Chechnya, as well as managing the influx of foreign fighters and money (and, according to the Russian officials, also planning of attacks in Russia). He led or commanded several devastating attacks, such as [[Battle of Hill 776|the mountain battle]], which killed at least 84 [[Russian Airborne Troops|Russian paratroopers]], and the [[Zhani-Vedeno ambush|attack on the OMON convoy]] near Zhani-Vedeno, which killed at least 52 Russian Interior Ministry troops. ===Death and legacy=== "Khattab was falsely reported dead when [[Guantanamo captive]] [[Omar Mohammed Ali Al Rammah]] faced the allegations that he witnessed Khattab being killed in an ambush in [[Duisi]], a village in the [[Pankisi Gorge]] of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] on 28 April 2002." {{cite web|url=http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/detainees/csrt_arb/ARB_Round_1_Factors_000794-000894.pdf#42 |title=Unclassified Summary of Evidence for Administrative Review Board in the case of Al Rammah, Omar Mohammed Ali |date=16 September 2005 |pages=42–44 |author=[[OARDEC]] |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] |accessdate=2008-01-08 |quote=The detainee witnessed the ambush that killed [[Ibn al Khattab]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214102939/http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/detainees/csrt_arb/ARB_Round_1_Factors_000794-000894.pdf |archivedate=14 December 2007 |df= }} {{cite web| url=http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/detainees/csrt_arb/ARB_Round_2_Factors_900-1009.pdf#25| title=Unclassified Summary of Evidence for Administrative Review Board in the case of Al-Rammah, Omar Mohammed Ali| date=26 May 2006| pages=25–27| author=[[OARDEC]]| publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]| accessdate=2008-01-08| quote=The detainee was captured in a violent road ambush by [[Georgia Security Forces]] in {{illm|Duisi, Georgia|ka|დუისი}} on 28 April 2002.| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226202803/http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/detainees/csrt_arb/ARB_Round_2_Factors_900-1009.pdf#25| archivedate=26 February 2008| df=dmy-all}} Khattab later survived a heavy-calibre bullet wound to the stomach and a [[landmine]] explosion. He was killed during the night of 19–20 March 2002, when a Dagestani messenger hired by the Russian [[Federal Security Service (Russia)|FSB]] gave Khattab a [[poison]]ed letter. Chechen sources said that the letter was coated with "a fast-acting nerve agent, possibly [[sarin]] or a derivative".{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/21/world/europe/moscow-kremlin-silence-critics-poison.html|title=More of Kremlin's Opponents Are Ending Up Dead|date=21 August 2016|work=The New York Times}}{{cite journal|url=http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~hsp/bulletin/cbwcb56.pdf|title=The chemical weapons convention and OPCW: the challenges of the 21st century|author=Ian R Kenyon|date=June 2002|journal=The CBW Conventions Bulletin|publisher=Harvard Sussex Program on CBW Armament and Arms Limitation|issue=56|page=47}} The messenger, a Dagestani double agent known as Ibragim Alauri, was turned by the FSB on his routine courier mission. Khattab would receive letters from his mother in Saudi Arabia, and the FSB found this to be the most opportune moment to kill Khattab. It was reported that the operation to recruit and turn Ibragim Alauri to work for the FSB and deliver the poisoned letter took some six months of preparation. Alauri was reportedly tracked down and killed a month later in [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] on [[Shamil Basayev]]'s orders.[https://www.webcitation.org/5zi1n5XGW?url=http://www.jamestown.org/programs/nca/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D%3D18627%26tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D%3D184%26no_cache%3D1]=18627&tx_ttnews[backPid]=184&no_cache=1 "Who Ordered Khattab's Death?"], [[Jamestown Foundation]], quoting Russian press sources Ibn Al-Khattab was succeeded by Emir [[Abu al-Walid]].{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} "[[Khattabka]]" (хаттабка) is now a popular Russian and Chechen name for a homemade [[hand grenade]]. ==Links to Osama bin Laden== According to [[Fawaz Gerges]] who cited [[Abu Walid al Masri]]'s diaries, Ibn al-Khattab and [[Osama bin Laden]] operated separate groups, as they defined the enemy differently, but tried to pull each other to their own battle plans. A part of bin Laden's interest was trying to obtain [[dirty bomb]]s from the Russian arsenal through al-Khattab's contacts.pp. 57-60, [[Fawaz Gerges|Fawaz A. Gerges]], ''The Far Enemy: Why Jihad Went Global'' (2005), Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0521737435}} According to [[Richard A. Clarke]], "[[Osama bin Laden|Bin Laden]] sent Afghan Arab veterans, money, and arms to fellow Saudi ibn Khatab in Chechnya, which seemed like a perfect theater for jihad."p. 136, [[Richard A. Clarke]], ''[[Against All Enemies: Inside America's War on Terror]]'' (2004), Free Press. {{ISBN|978-0743260459}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://www.webcitation.org/5zi1avwZK?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/1952053.stm BBC notice of Khattab's death] * [https://www.webcitation.org/5zi1WfE2T?url=http://www.kavkaz.org.uk/eng/photo/amir_khattab/page1.shtml Khattab info from Kavkaz Center] (in Russian) * [https://www.webcitation.org/5zi1SSXco?url=http://www.jamestown.org/programs/gta/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D%3D658%26tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D%3D181%26no_cache%3D1]=658&tx_ttnews[backPid]=181&no_cache=1 The Rise and Fall of Foreign Fighters in Chechnya], The Jamestown Foundation ===Video=== * [https://archive.org/details/Shatoi Khattab's video of the Shatoy battle] * [https://archive.org/download/biographyofkhattab1/biographyofkhattab1.mpg Biography of Khattab Part 1] * [https://archive.org/download/biographyofkhattab2/biographyofkhattab2.mpg Biography of Khattab Part 2] {{Chechen wars}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Khattab}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths by poisoning]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in Russia]] [[Category:Foreign volunteers in Chechnya]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian militants]] [[Category:Warlords]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian emigrants to Russia]] [[Category:Assassinated Saudi Arabian people]] [[Category:Leaders of Islamic terror groups]] [[Category:Salafi jihadists]]
