{{for|former lawn bowler|Kenny Logan (bowls)}} {{BLP sources|date=July 2010}} {{Infobox rugby biography | name = Kenny Logan | image = | caption = | birth_name = Kenneth McKerrow Logan | nickname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972| 04|03|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Stirling]], [[Scotland]] | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{convert|1.85|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} | ru_position = [[Wing (rugby union)|Wing]] | ru_amateuryears = 1989–1997 | ru_amateurclubs = [[Stirling County RFC|Stirling County]] | ru_amupdate = | ru_nationalteam = [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] | ru_nationalyears = 1992–2003 | ru_nationalcaps = 70 | ru_nationalpoints = (220) | ru_ntupdate = | ru_clubyears = 1996–1997
1997–2004
2004–2005
2005 | ru_proclubs = {{nowrap|[[Glasgow Warriors|Glasgow]]
[[Wasps RFC|London Wasps]]
[[Glasgow Warriors|Glasgow]]
[[London Scottish F.C.|London Scottish]]}} | ru_clubcaps = 5
115
20 | ru_clubpoints = (31)
(862)
(25) | ru_clubupdate = | ru_currentclub = | ru_province = {{nowrap|[[Glasgow District (rugby union)|Glasgow District]]}} | ru_provinceyears = | ru_provincecaps = | ru_provincepoints = | ru_provinceupdate = | ru_sevensnationalyears = | ru_sevensnationalteam = | ru_sevensnationalcaps = | ru_sevensnationalpoints = | ru_sevensupdate = | ru_coachclubs = | ru_coachyears = | ru_coachupdate = | other = | occupation = | family = | spouse = [[Gabby Logan|Gabby Yorath]] (2001–present) | children = 2 | relatives = | school = | university = }} '''Kenneth McKerrow "Kenny" Logan''' (born 3 April 1972) is a retired [[Scottish people|Scottish]] [[rugby union]] player who played [[wing (rugby union)|wing]] for [[Stirling County RFC]] and [[Glasgow District (rugby union)|Glasgow District]] at amateur level; [[Glasgow Warriors]], [[Wasps RFC]] and [[London Scottish F.C.|London Scottish]] at professional level; and [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] at international level. He won three [[English Premiership (rugby union)|English Premierships]] with [[Wasps RFC]]; and one Scottish Premiership title with [[Stirling County RFC]] in 1995, just before the game turned professional. == Early life == Logan was born on 3 April 1972 in [[Stirling]], Scotland. As a schoolboy, Logan had [[Association football|football]] trials as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]] and [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]]. He left school at sixteen and began his rugby career with his hometown club [[Stirling County RFC|Stirling County]], making his senior debut at 17.{{cite web|title=Stirling County - History|url=http://www.stirlingcounty-rfc.co.uk/history/|publisher=stirlingcounty-rfc.co.uk}}{{failed verification|date=February 2017}} ==Club career== Logan played for the amateur provincial side [[Glasgow District (rugby union)|Glasgow District]]. In [[1996–97 Glasgow Warriors season|1996]] the professional era began and the side became [[Glasgow Rugby]]. He played for the newly professional team in the three matches of the [[1996–97 Scottish Inter-District Championship]] as well as 2 matches in that season's European Challenge Cup, the European Conference. In 1997, he joined [[Wasps RFC|Wasps]] for his first season in English rugby. Logan was with Wasps for seven seasons. In 2004, he re-signed for [[Glasgow Warriors|Glasgow]] before joining [[London Scottish F.C.|London Scottish]] after a season. He retired from playing in 2005.{{cite news|title=Logan to end career against Scots|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/international/4467141.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=20 April 2005}} == International career == Logan played for Scotland A.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby-union-munro-a-power-in-scots-scrum-1565897.html |title=Rugby Union: Munro a power in Scots scrum |first=Bill |last=Leith |work=[[The Independent]] |date=29 December 1992 |accessdate=11 February 2017}} Logan made his [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] debut in 1992 against [[Australia national rugby union team|Australia]] at the age of 19. He was in and out of the side before cementing a position in the starting XV at the [[1994 Five Nations Championship]]. He played in the [[2003 Rugby Union World Cup|2003 World Cup]]. He won 70 caps over a 13-year period, scoring 20 tries in the process. He retired from international rugby union after the 2003 World Cup. == Personal life == Logan was diagnosed with [[dyslexia]] as a child and found solace in playing sports.{{cite news|title=Learning to read at 34 is Kenny Logan's best win|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/international/scotland/2291315/Learning-to-read-at-34-Kenny-Logans-best-win.html|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=9 February 2008}} He attended [[Wallace High School, Stirling|Wallace High School]] but left without sitting for his final exams.{{cite news|title=My best teacher - Kenny Logan |first=Rob |last=Maul|url=http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=6019868|publisher=[[Times Educational Supplement]]|date=7 August 2009}} Logan dated newsreader [[Kirsty Young]] and moved to London,{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/hot-news-kirstys-in-vogue-1145069.html |title=Hot news: Kirsty's in Vogue |first=Rob |last=Brown |work=[[The Independent]] |date=16 February 1998 |accessdate=11 February 2017}} before the couple separated in 1999 after three years.{{Cite news|last=Vallely |first=Paul |title=Kirsty Young: Island queen |newspaper=The Independent |date=1 July 2006 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/kirsty-young-island-queen-6096622.html |accessdate=12 February 2017}} In July 2001 he married television presenter [[Gabby Logan|Gabby Yorath]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/1448334.stm |title=Logan's love match |work=BBC News |date=20 July 2001 |accessdate=11 February 2017}} The couple live in [[Kew]], south west London.{{cite news | url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/esmagazine/gabby-logans-my-london-8206713.html | title=My London | work=[[Evening Standard]] magazine | date=12 October 2012 | accessdate=13 October 2012 | author=Conway, Juliet | location=London}} After undergoing [[IVF]] treatment they had twins, who were born on 28 July 2005.{{Cite news|last=Tweedie |first=Katrina |title=Our First Family Christmas: Kenny and Gabby Logan |newspaper=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] |date=9 November 2005 |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/tm_objectid=16347920&method=full&siteid=66633&headline=our-first-family-christmas--kenny-and-gabby-logan-name_page.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609234414/http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/tm_objectid%3D16347920%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D66633%26headline%3Dour-first-family-christmas--kenny-and-gabby-logan-name_page.html |archivedate= 9 June 2011 |df=dmy }} Logan and his wife took part in the fifth series of the [[BBC]] celebrity dancing programme ''[[Strictly Come Dancing (Series 5)|Strictly Come Dancing]]''. Kenny was partnered with [[Ola Jordan|Ola]] and Gabby was partnered with [[James Jordan (dancer)|James Jordan]]. Logan ended in 5th place. Gabby finished in 12th place. {{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} Kenny and his wife are past presidents of the children's charity [[Sparks (charity)|Sparks]].[http://www.sparks.org.uk/NetCommunity/Page.aspx?pid=309&srcid=449 ] {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} In 2009, Logan and Sparks joined forces to organise an annual mass-participation event entitled [[Logan's Challenge]]. In August 2014, Logan was one of 200 public figures who were signatories to a letter to ''[[The Guardian]]'' expressing their hope that Scotland would vote to remain part of the United Kingdom in September's [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|referendum on that issue]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/07/celebrities-open-letter-scotland-independence-full-text |title=Celebrities' open letter to Scotland – full text and list of signatories |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=7 August 2014 |accessdate=26 August 2014}} Logan supports [[Rangers F.C.]]{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/rangers-celebrity-supporters-out-in-force-976295|title=Rangers' celebrity supporters out in force for UEFA Cup final|work=Daily Record|date=3 May 2008|accessdate=3 May 2008|location=Glasgow|first=John|last=Ferguson}} == Honours == * [[Scottish Premiership (rugby)|Scottish Premiership]]: 1994−95 * [[English Premiership (rugby union)|English Premiership]]: [[1996–97 English Premiership (rugby union)|1996−97]], [[2002–03 English Premiership (rugby union)|2002−03]], [[2003–04 English Premiership (rugby union)|2003−04]] == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * {{cite book|last=Logan|first=Kenny|title=Just for Kicks: The Autobiography|publisher=[[Headline Publishing]]|isbn=9780755319701|year=2010}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110605084759/http://www.wasps.co.uk/PlayerDisplaySS.ink?skip=20&squadno=1410&season=02%2F03&seasonl=2002%2F2003&Playertype=P Wasps profile] * {{ESPNscrum|11239}} * [http://www.sporting-heroes.net/rugby-heroes/displayhero.asp?HeroID=6798 Sporting Heroes entry for Kenny Logan] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XQBNTrV1AkY Participant in Leading Works 'Sporting Legends Programme'] - Leading Works Enjoy Making an Impact {{Scotland Squad 1995 Rugby World Cup}} {{Scotland Squad 1999 World Cup}} {{Scotland Squad 2003 World Cup}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Logan, Kenny}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Glasgow Warriors players]] [[Category:Wasps RFC players]] [[Category:Scottish rugby union players]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Stirling]] [[Category:London Scottish F.C. players]] [[Category:Stirling County RFC players]] [[Category:Scottish footballers]] [[Category:Scotland international rugby union players]] [[Category:People diagnosed with dyslexia]] [[Category:Association footballers not categorized by position]]

{{COI|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Lauritz Dippenaar | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1948|10|25}} | birth_place = | residence = [[Johannesburg]], South Africa | alma mater = [[University of Pretoria]] | networth = [[United States dollar|$]] 650 million <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/lauritz-laurie-dippenaar/|title=Lauritz (Laurie) Dippenaar|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref> | nationality = [[South African]] | occupation = Businessman | known_for = Dippenaar Scholarship | children = Three }}
'''Lauritz Laurie Dippenaar''' is a South African self made millionaire businessman,investor & banker who is the Chairman of [[FirstRand]] financial Group. He is also well known for his philanthropic activities and runs a scholarship programme through his generous endowments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstrand.co.za/csi/Pages/laurie-dippenaar-scholarship.aspx|title=Pages - laurie dippenaar scholarship|website=Firstrand.co.za|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref>
==Biography== Lauritz Dippenaar graduated from [[Pretoria University]] with a [[Master of Commerce]], qualified as a [[South_African_Institute_of_Chartered_Accountants|Chartered Accountant]] with [[KPMG]], and spent three years with the Industrial Development Corporation of South Africa. In 1977, Dippenaar founded FirstRand's predecessor, Rand Consolidated Investing along with Paul Harris and [[Gerrit Ferreira]].He served as executive chairman of RMB from 1992 until the formation of FirstRand in 1998. He was appointed as the first chief executive of [[FirstRand]] and held this position until the end of 2005 when he was selected as a chairman for a non-executive role in 2008.
==Philanthropy== He sponsors the Laurie Dippenaar Postgraduate Scholarship for International Study. The scholarship is awarded annually and is available to a South African citizen, for study outside South Africa in any discipline at the internationally recognized University of their choice for a Postgraduate degree. It has a value R350 000 ($37,000) per annum for a maximum of two years.
==Personal life== Dippenaar is married with three children. His hobbies include watching rugby, Canoeing and cycling.
==Financial and legal controversies== A press release dated August 27, 2014 featured that US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) issued an order filing and settling charges against FirstRand Bank Ltd (under the chairmanship of Lauritz Laurie Dippenaar) and imposed a $150,000 civil monetary penalty for executing unlawful prearranged, non-competitive trades involving corn and soybean futures contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT), a designated contract market of the CME Group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/pr6985-14|title=CFTC Orders FirstRand Bank, Ltd. to Pay $150,000 Civil Monetary Penalty for Unlawfully Executing Prearranged, Noncompetitive Trades on the CBOT|website=Cftc.gov|access-date=2017-07-18}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dippenaar, Lauritz}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Afrikaner people]] [[Category:White South African people]] [[Category:South African businesspeople]]

CBS released the names of the sixteen new contestants on ''[[Big Brother 19 (U.S.)|Big Brother 19]]'' on June 19, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/news/1007201/meet-the-new-big-brother-season-19-cast-before-anyone-else/|title=Meet The New Big Brother Season 19 Cast Before Anyone Else|work=CBS|date=June 12, 2017|accessdate=June 14, 2017}}</ref> After the temptation twist was used, a former houseguest returned to the game. ==Alex== '''Alexandra Rose “Alex” Ow''' (born December 20, 1988), 28, is an eco-friendly marketing representative from [[Camarillo, California]]. Originally from [[Thousand Oaks, California|Thousand Oaks]], she enjoys knitting, crocheting, baking, going to the gym, going out with friends, hanging out with her family, watching [[Netflix]], hiking, dating, and being lazy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/|title=Alex Ow|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 9, after Megan self-evicted, Cody named Alex as the replacement nominee for eviction. On Day 10, she won the first POV competition. On Day 17, Paul nominated her for eviction. On Day 23, Alex won her first HOH. On Day 24, she nominated Jessica and Dominique for eviction. On Day 51, Alex won her second HOH of the season. On Day 52, Alex nominated Jason and Elena. On Day 55, Alex replaced Jason with Cody after Matt used the POV on Jason. On Day 73, Alex was nominated alongside Jason for eviction. On Day 76, Alex was saved after Paul used the POV to take her off from the block. On Day 79, Alex won her third HOH of the season. She nominated Kevin and Raven for eviction. On Day 80, she was nominated alongside Kevin for eviction. On Day 84, she was evicted by a 2-1 vote and became the seventh member of the Jury. Alex voted for Josh to be the winner.
==Cameron== '''Cameron Heard''' (born August 27, 1992), 24, is a microbiologist from [[Woodridge, Illinois]]. Originally from [[North Aurora, Illinois|North Aurora]], he enjoys riding his bike, solving [[Rubik's Cube]]s, playing online chess, snowboarding, and scuba diving. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122712/cameron-heard/|title=Cameron Heard|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 1, Cameron was evicted by an 8-3-2 vote after not being saved by Paul and then losing the safety competition. On Day 30, Cameron competed against Jillian, Cody, and Dominique in the Battle Back Showdown. He came in second during the first round and progressed to round two, where he lost in a head-to-head battle against Cody.
==Christmas== '''Christmas Joye Abbott''' (born December 20, 1981), 35, is a fitness superstar from [[Raleigh, North Carolina]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/living/health-fitness/article154718079.html |title=Fitness star: Being a ‘badass’ is about so much more than half-naked pics |last=Janes |first=Theoden |date=2017-06-06 |website=[[The News & Observer|newsobserver.com]] |language=en |access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref> Originally from [[Lynchburg, Virginia]], she enjoys working out, playing sports, cooking, and working.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122713/christmas-abbott/|title=Christmas Abbott|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref> She is the first female [[NASCAR]] [[pit stop|pit crew]] member.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2013/3/15/4108122/christmas-abbott-nascar-pit-crew-member|title=Meet Christmas Abbott, NASCAR's first female pit crew member|date=15 March 2013|publisher=SBNation|last=Sharp|first=Andrew}}</ref>
On Day 1, Christmas was not picked by Paul for safety and subsequently lost the safety competition, resulting in her becoming one of three nominees for eviction. She received only 2 out of the 13 votes cast to evict and was saved. On Day 12, Christmas was named as a replacement nominee after Alex removed herself from the block. On Day 13, Christmas had to leave the Big Brother house temporarily after suffering a foot injury and returned later that day. On Day 17, Christmas was voted into the Den of Temptation and chose to accept the Ring of Replacement. She also got to choose Cody, Jessica, and Jason as the recipients of that week's curse. On Day 23, Christmas had to leave the house to get foot surgery done in a hospital. Because of this, on Day 24, she became the first houseguest in the history of ''Big Brother (U.S.)'' to cast an eviction vote via phone call from outside of the house. She was also absent for that week's HOH competition. On Day 46, Christmas used the Ring of Replacement to take Cody's place in the veto competition, though she ended up being unable to compete due to her injury. On Day 58, Christmas won the HOH competition. On Day 59, she nominated Jason and Matt for eviction. On Day 62, Christmas replaced Jason with Mark after Jason used the POV on himself. On Day 73, Christmas nominated Jason and Alex for eviction. On Day 76, Christmas nominated Kevin as a replacement nominee after Paul chose to use the POV to save Alex from the block. On Day 86, she cast her sole vote to evict Kevin. On Day 92, after Josh became the Final HOH, he chose to evict Christmas, and she became the 9th and final Jury member. Christmas voted for Paul to win.
==Cody== {{Main|Cody Nickson}} '''Cody Lee Nickson''' (born April 13, 1985), 32, is a [[United States Marine Corps]] [[MOS 0311|0311]] from [[Plano, Texas]] who did combat tours in both the [[Iraq War|Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]] wars. Originally from [[Lake Mills, Iowa]], he joined the [[United States Air Force]] at the age of 17 where he would serve as a [[2M0X1|2M0X2]] and then a [[1N0X1]] before joining the Marines. He enjoys surfing and riding his motorcycle. He and his former girlfriend have a daughter named Paisley Nickson.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122714/cody-nickson/|title=Cody Nickson|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 1, Cody won the safety competition after Paul did not choose him as one of the 8 houseguests to be awarded safety. Later that week, Cody won the first HOH competition and nominated Megan and Jillian for eviction. On Day 9, Cody picked Alex as a replacement nominee after Megan self-evicted. On Day 12, Cody tried to nominate Paul after Alex took herself off the block. However, Paul revealed his Pendant of Protection, so Cody chose to nominate Christmas instead. On Day 17, Christmas named Cody as a recipient of the Ve-toad curse after accepting a temptation. On Day 20, Paul saved Josh with the POV and named Cody as the replacement nominee. On Day 23, Cody was evicted from the house by a 7-3-0 vote, but on Day 30, he returned to the house after winning three rounds of the Battle Back Showdown. On Day 38, Paul nominated Cody for eviction alongside Jessica. On Day 44, Jessica used the Halting Hex during the live show, sparing both her and Cody from eviction. On Day 45, Cody won the second Temptation Competition and became safe for the week. On Day 55, Alex put him up as the replacement nominee after Matt won the POV and used it on Jason. On Day 58, Cody was evicted from the house by a 7-0-0 vote and became the first member of the Jury. Cody voted for Josh to win. Cody also won America's Favorite Houseguest and takes home $25,000.
On September 27, 2017, it was revealed by CBS that Cody, with Jessica, would be one of the teams racing on [[The Amazing Race 30|the 30th season of ''The Amazing Race'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/amazing_race/news/1007641/big-brother-19-s-jessica-and-cody-bring-their-showmance-to-the-amazing-race/|title=Big Brother 19's Jessica And Cody Bring Their Showmance To The Amazing Race |publisher=CBS|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> The two became engaged on February 13, 2018.<ref name="JessicaCody">{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/914308/big-brother-s-jessica-graf-and-cody-nickson-get-engaged-ahead-of-the-amazing-race-finale|title=Big Brother's Jessica Graf and Cody Nickson Get Engaged Ahead of The Amazing Race Finale|publisher=E! Online|accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>
Cody and Jessica went on to become the winners of Amazing Race 30 and took home the $1,000,000 prize along with the $5,000 prize they won earlier during the race
On September 5, 2018, Cody was nominated for [[44th People's Choice Awards|2018 People's Choice Awards]] for ''The Competition Contestant of 2018''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://deadline.com/2018/09/peoples-choice-awards-new-categories-nomination-voting-e-channel-1202457202/|title=People’s Choice Awards Unveils New Categories; Opens Nomination Voting|last=Ramos|first=Dino-Ray|date=2018-09-05|work=Deadline|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Dominique== '''Dominique Charde Cooper''' (born July 11, 1986), 30, is a government nuclear engineer from [[Woodbridge, Virginia]]. Originally from [[Tuskegee, Alabama]], she enjoys eating and trying new restaurants, attending [[happy hour]]s, running, creative writing, speaking, and reading books.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122715/dominique-cooper/|title=Dominique Cooper|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 24, Alex nominated Dominique for eviction alongside Jessica. On Day 30, Dominique was unanimously evicted from the house by a 10-0 vote. She competed in the Battle Back Showdown against Cameron, Jillian, and Cody. She was eliminated in the first round.
==Elena== '''Elena Ce'Anne Davies''' (born August 19, 1990), 26, is a radio personality from [[Dallas, Texas]]. She used to work on ''[[The Kidd Kraddick Morning Show]]''. Originally from [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]], she enjoys [[Instagram]], listening to live music, napping, [[Tailgate party|tailgating]], and shaking her booty.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122716/elena-davies/|title=Elena Davies|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 45, Josh nominated Elena and Mark for eviction. On Day 52, Alex nominated Elena and Jason for eviction. On Day 53, Elena took first place in the veto competition but opted to take a $5,000 prize over the POV. On Day 58, during the double eviction, Jason became HOH and nominated Elena and Mark. Later that night, Elena was evicted from the house by a 6-1-0 vote and became the second member of the Jury. Elena voted for Josh to win.
==Jason== '''Jason Lance Dent''' (born July 12, 1979), 37, is a rodeo clown from [[Humeston, Iowa]]. He enjoys rodeo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122717/jason-dent/|title=Jason Dent|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref> He performs under the name Whistle-Nut with his bull Ole. He is married to his wife Holly and they have a young son named Gatlin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corydontimes.com/printer_1587.shtml|title=Jason and Holly Dent ride from one adventure to the next|last=Selby|first=Jason|publisher=Times-Republican|date=December 8, 2014|accessdate=July 1, 2017}}</ref>
On Day 17, Christmas chose Jason as the recipient of the Ve-toad curse after accepting a temptation. On Day 25, Jason won the Power of Veto. On Day 37, Jason became a third nominee after losing the first Temptation Competition. On Day 41, Paul removed Jason from the block after winning the Power of Veto. On Day 52, Alex nominated Jason and Elena for eviction. On Day 55, Matt chose to remove Jason from the block with the POV. On Day 58, Jason won the HOH competition during the double eviction and nominated Mark and Elena. When Mark won the POV, Jason named Matt as the replacement nominee. On Day 59, Christmas nominated Jason and Matt for eviction. On Day 61, Jason won the Power of Veto. On Day 62, he removed himself from the block. On Day 65, Jason won his second HOH competition of the season. He later nominated Matt and Raven for eviction. On Day 66, Jason won the Power of Veto. On Day 73, Christmas nominated Jason and Alex for eviction. On Day 79, Jason was evicted by a 3-2 vote by Christmas breaking the tie-breaking vote and became the fifth member of jury. Jason voted for Josh to win.
Jason came under fire for a comment he made regarding Kevin's family. Speaking to Paul and Alex, Jason stated that he would engage in sexual intercourse with Kevin's wife after tying up his daughters to force them to watch. Jason would do this while laughing at his idea claiming he would say it to Kevin's face if Kevin nominated him. A lot of fans called for Jason to be expelled after this incident, though no comment has been made on the matter.
==Jessica== {{Main|Jessica Graf}} '''Jessica Furtado Graf''' (born December 11, 1990), 26, is a VIP concierge from [[Los Angeles, California]]. Originally from [[Cranston, Rhode Island]], she enjoys going out to eat long meals with great people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122718/jessica-graf/|title=Jessica Graf|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 17, Christmas named Jessica as a recipient of the Ve-toad curse after accepting a temptation. On Day 24, Alex nominated Jessica for eviction alongside Dominique. On Day 29, Jessica was presented with the third and final temptation from America. She chose to accept the Halting Hex, which allows her to cancel any of the four subsequent evictions, resetting that week. On Day 30, Jessica won the HOH competition. She chose to nominate Josh and Ramses for eviction. On Day 31, Jessica won the veto competition. On Day 38, Paul nominated Jessica for eviction alongside Cody. On Day 44, she used the Halting Hex during the live show, sparing both her and Cody from eviction. On Day 45, Jessica finished the Temptation Competition in last place and became the third nominee. On Day 51, Jessica was evicted by a 7-1-0 vote. On September 27, 2017, it was revealed by CBS that Jessica, with Cody, would be one of the teams racing on [[The Amazing Race 30|the 30th season of ''The Amazing Race'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/amazing_race/news/1007641/big-brother-19-s-jessica-and-cody-bring-their-showmance-to-the-amazing-race/|title=Big Brother 19's Jessica And Cody Bring Their Showmance To The Amazing Race |publisher=CBS|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> The two became engaged on February 13, 2018.<ref name="JessicaCody"/>
Jessica and Cody went on to win The Amazing Race 30 and the grand prize of $1,000,000 along with the $5,000 they won on a previous leg.
==Jillian== '''Jillian Nicole Parker''' (born May 12, 1993), 24, is a timeshare sales representative from [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]. Originally from [[Celebration, Florida]], she enjoys rock climbing and ropes courses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122719/jillian-parker/|title=Jillian Parker|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 1, Jillian was not picked by Paul for safety and subsequently lost the safety competition, resulting in her becoming one of three nominees for eviction. She received only 3 out of 13 votes to evict and was saved. Later that week, Cody won the first HOH competition and nominated her for eviction. On Day 16, Jillian was evicted from the house 8-4, after Cody faced immense trouble securing a target for eviction; Jillian initially agreed to be a pawn up against Megan, but due to Megan suddenly quitting the game and circumstances beyond his control (Alex being vetoed off the block and Paul revealing his Pendant of Protection), Cody cycled through four different nominees next to Jillian and was eventually forced to put up Christmas as the last of these, and the majority of the house wanted to keep her, resulting in Jillian's role as a pawn backfiring when she became the dispensable player. On Day 30, Jillian competed against Cameron, Cody, and Dominique in the Battle Back Showdown, where she was eliminated in the first round.
==Josh== '''Joshua “Josh” Martinez''', (born January 4, 1994), 23, is a haircare salesman from [[Homestead, Florida]]. Originally from [[Miami]], he enjoys playing sports, going to the gym, reading, hiking, traveling, meeting new people, being an adrenaline junkie, and having new experiences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122720/josh-martinez/|title=Josh Martinez|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
During the first HOH competition, Josh won safety for the week after retrieving a golden apple, at the expense of his teammates' chances at winning HOH. On Day 17, Paul nominated him for eviction. On Day 20, Paul chose to save Josh with the POV and replaced him with Cody. On Day 31, Jessica nominated Josh for eviction and kept the nominees the same. On Day 44, Josh won HOH. On Day 45, he nominated Elena and Mark for eviction. On Day 79, Josh won the POV during the second Double Eviction and decided to not use it. On Day 79, Josh won his second HOH. On Day 80, he nominated Alex and Kevin. On Day 84, Josh cast the tie-breaker vote to evict Alex. On day 86, Martinez won the final HOH of the season and decided to evict Christmas. Moments later, Josh was crowned the winner of Big Brother 19, and the sole winner of the $500,000 prize, by a vote of 5-4, receiving the votes of jury members Alex Ow, Jason Dent, Mark Jansen, Elena Davies and Cody Nickson. Martinez is the first Hispanic-American winner in the show's history. Josh is the third Hispanic person to make finals after Ivette Corredero and Natalie Martinez.
{{s-start}} {{s-bef | before = [[Nicole Franzel]]}} {{s-ttl | title = [[Big Brother (U.S.)|Big Brother U.S.]] winner | years = [[Big Brother 19 (U.S.)|Season 19 (2017)]]}} {{s-aft | after = [[List_of_Big_Brother_20_houseguests_(U.S.)#Kaycee|Kaycee Clark]]}} {{end}}
==Kevin== '''Kevin Francis Schlehuber''' (born August 7, 1961), 55, is a stay-at-home dad from [[Boston|Boston, Massachusetts]]. He has 7 children, (6 girls, 1 boy) one of whom is part of a YouTube channel that Kevin has appeared in videos for.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e3n0liuBodw</ref> He enjoys hanging out with his family, watching movies, going to the beach, exercising, and playing pool or darts with the kids.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122721/kevin-schlehuber/|title=Kevin Schlehuber|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 1, Kevin was the first houseguest to buzz in to give into the first temptation and thus won $25,000 in exchange for the BB Swap twist and his own ineligibility to win the first HOH competition. On Day 25, Kevin chose to go for the mystery cash prize during the veto competition and won $27. On Day 76, Christmas named Kevin as the replacement nominee after Paul used the POV to save Alex from the block. On Day 79, he was nominated alongside Raven for eviction. On Day 80, he was nominated alongside Alex for eviction. On Day 85, he was nominated alongside Josh for eviction. On Day 86, Kevin was evicted, the sole vote being cast by Christmas, and became the 8th member of the jury. Kevin voted for Paul to win. He is also the oldest person of the season.
==Mark== '''Mark Gordon Jansen''' (born June 13, 1991), 26, is a personal trainer from [[Grand Island, New York]]. He enjoys lifting weights, hiking, watching movies, and relaxing on a beach.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122722/mark-jansen/|title=Mark Jansen|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 37, Mark won the first Temptation Competition and became safe for the week. On Day 45, Josh nominated Mark and Elena for eviction. On Day 46, Mark won the Power of Veto. On Day 52, Mark won the third and final Temptation Competition. On Day 58, Jason nominated Mark and Elena for eviction during the double eviction. Later that night, Mark won the Power of Veto and chose to save himself. On Day 62, Mark was named as Christmas replacement nominee after Jason uses the POV on himself. On Day 65, Mark was evicted from the house by a 4-2 vote and became the third member of the Jury. Mark voted for Josh to win.
==Matt== '''Matthew John “Matt” Clines''', (born March 31, 1984), 33, is a renovation consultant from [[Arlington, Virginia]]. He enjoys watching funny animal videos, eating, sleeping, and lifting weights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122723/matthew-clines/|title=Matthew Clines|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
On Day 52, Matt lost the third Temptation Competition and became the third nominee for eviction. On Day 53, Matt won the POV. He chose to use the veto on Jason. On Day 58, Jason named Matt as the replacement nominee after Mark saved himself with the POV. On Day 59, Christmas nominated Matt and Jason for eviction. On Day 66, Jason nominated Matt and Raven for eviction. When Jason won the "Hide and Go Veto" POV on Day 68, he did not use it to save either of them, resulting in a heated argument where Matt blasted Jason's decision and for going back on his word and forgetting a promise to take Raven off the block. In an effort to keep his showmance partner Raven from being evicted, Matt attempted to martyr his own game by inciting as many penalty votes as possible (an act that would prove unnecessary when he was unanimously voted out of the house). On Day 69, Matt decided to break the Have-Not rules and eat food other than slop, resulting in him receiving an automatic penalty vote against him at the upcoming eviction. He later proceeded to take hot showers and slept outside of the Have-Not room. On Day 72, Matt was evicted by a 6-0 vote with the one penalty vote and became the fourth jury member. Matt voted for Paul to win.
Matt's time in the house was criticized due to his lack of involvement in the game as a major competitor on his own, almost entirely spent entering into a relationship with Raven and serving as Paul's ally, with Josh later remarking in the "Everybody's a Wiener" HOH Competition that his civil dispute with Alex and Jason for needlessly dragging out the competition (over sixty days into the game) was the first time he had a voice in the game. In general, he was known for eating an excessive amount a cereal, his tendency to shower longer than he needed to, and an uproarious laugh that became the subject of ridicule. His showmance with Raven was referred to as "Maven", and the rest of the Jury would later balk at the clueless nature of the duo when they claimed they were in control of the season after doing virtually nothing and even ending up evicted without realizing how it meant they had been defeated and felt comfortable with throwing their games to Paul and losing in that respect.
==Megan== '''Megan Ann Lowder''' (born March 7, 1989), 28, is a dog walker from [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. Originally from [[Cathedral City, California]], she enjoys playing video games, Harry Potter, and watching South Park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122724/megan-lowder/|title=Megan Lowder|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
In week 1, Cody nominated Megan alongside Jillian for eviction, due to their alliance. On Day 9, upon the start of the live feeds, it was revealed by fellow houseguests that Megan had quit the game the day before. The next day, she released a statement citing PTSD from a sexual assault during her time in the Navy as the reason for her self-eviction and inability to cope with multiple confrontations inside the house.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.desertsun.com/story/life/entertainment/television/2017/06/30/megan-lowder-ptsd-previous-assault-reason-she-left-big-brother-house-early/444830001/|title=Megan Lowder: PTSD from previous assault reason she left the 'Big Brother' house early|last=Pena|first=Xochitl|publisher=The Desert Sun|date=June 30, 2017|accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref> Following this, Megan's presence in the season was almost completely purged from the show out of respect for her need to disconnect and distance herself from the atmosphere that reawakened her past trauma; none of the subsequent competitions paid mention to her (such as not having an illustrated cover for BB Comics Week), nor did Megan return as a guest for the finale.
==Paul== {{Main|Paul Abrahamian}} '''Paul Raffi Abrahamian''' (born June 13, 1993), 24, is a fashion designer from [[Tarzana, California]]. His hobbies are playing music, going to shows and concerts for the crowd surfing, mosh pits, stage diving, traveling and hiking. He is a graduate of [[Pepperdine University]]. He was the runner-up on ''[[Big Brother 18 (U.S.)|Big Brother 18]]'' in 2016.
On Day 1, Paul entered the house as a consequence for someone buzzing in to accept a $25,000 temptation. He was also granted safety from the first eviction and got to save 8 additional houseguests from having to compete for their safety that night. In week 1, Paul was the first houseguest to be voted into the Den of Temptation by America. He accepted the Pendant of Protection, which grants him immunity for the next three evictions. On Day 12, this power was revealed to his fellow houseguests when Cody tried to name him as the replacement nominee. On Day 16, Paul won the second HOH competition. On Day 17, Paul nominated Alex and Josh for eviction. On Day 18, Paul won the POV competition. On Day 20, he chose to take Josh off the block and replaced him with Cody. On Day 30, the house voted for Paul to face off against Cody in the final round of the Battle Back Showdown. Paul lost, which meant that Cody would re-enter the house. On Day 37, Paul won the HOH competition. He decided to nominate Cody and Jessica for eviction. On Day 40, Paul won the POV. On Day 74, Paul won his third POV of the season. On Day 81, Paul won his fourth POV of the season. On Day 84, he won his third HOH of the season. On Day 85, he won his fifth consecutive POV of the season. On day 86, Paul won part 1 of the Final HoH. On Day 92, Paul lost by a 5-4 jury vote to Josh Martinez, receiving the jury votes of Christmas Abbott, Kevin Schlehuber, Raven Walton and Matt Clines.
Paul is the fifth houseguest after Big Brother 3 contestants Danielle Reyes and Jason Guy, Big Brother 16 winner Derrick Levasseur, and Big Brother Canada 1 winner Jillian MacLaughlin to make it to the final 3 without touching the block. However, unlike the others, Paul was actually nominated but did not go on the block because the pendant of protection protected him, and accomplished this feat on his second attempt. Counting only HoH's and PoV's, Paul has won the most competitions in Big Brother history with 15 wins over his two seasons, more competitions than any male in a single season with 9 competitions wins in Big Brother 19, and the most competition wins in a single season, tied with Janelle Pierzina who won 9 competitions in Big Brother All-Stars. He is the second houseguest in Big Brother History after Dan Gheesling to make it to the final 2 twice, and the first person to make it to the final two twice without winning. With this season, Paul has played the most days of any houseguest with 191 days.
==Ramses== '''Ramses Soto''' (born December 18, 1995), 21, is a cosplay artist from [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]]. He enjoys cosplaying and creating art.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122725/ramses-soto/|title=Ramses Soto|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
In week 1, after Paul accepted a temptation, Ramses received the consequence and must put himself up as a third nominee for eviction sometime within the first 3 weeks. On Day 17, Ramses decided to follow through with his curse and put himself up for eviction alongside Paul's week 2 nominees. He was getting targeted by fellow housemates (houseguests) Kevin and Christmas in week 2. On Day 31, Jessica nominated Ramses for eviction. As Jessica wins the Power of Veto, she decides to keep the nominations, meaning either him or Josh will be voted to be evicted. On Day 37, Ramses went home in a 7-3 vote against Josh.
==Raven== '''Raven Leigh-Anna Walton''' (born June 10, 1994), 23, is a dance teacher from [[DeValls Bluff, Arkansas]]. She enjoys road tripping with her friends, reading books, and fashion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1007606/meet-the-cast-of-big-brother-season-19/122726/raven-walton/|title=Raven Walton|publisher=CBS|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref> She suffers from a disease called [[gastroparesis]], which is a chronic condition of stomach paralysis that forces her to use a [[Implantable gastric stimulation|gastric pacemaker]] in order for food to properly move through her digestive tract.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://themighty.com/2017/06/big-brother-raven-walton-gastroparesis/|publisher=The Mighty|last=Migdol|first=Erin|date=June 29, 2017|title='Big Brother' Contestant Raven Walton Is Showing Viewers the Reality of Gastroparesis}}</ref>
On Day 10, Raven retrieved a golden starfish during the Power of Veto competition and became immune from becoming a have-not for the rest of the summer. On Day 66, Jason nominated Raven and Matt for eviction. The nominations were kept the same post-veto, but Raven was spared from eviction as the expense of her showmance with Matt. On Day 79, Alex nominated Raven and Kevin for eviction and was evicted by a 2-1 vote and became the sixth member of the jury. Raven voted for Paul to win.
Raven became a subject of heavy contention from the show's fans after she repeatedly misrepresented her gastroparesis (or GP) as a terminal condition, along with a multitude of accompanying ailments that were caused by the illness. Most of her statements regarding her health were deemed inconsistent and/or implausible, and ultimately caused many to condemn her behavior as [[malingering]]. She also claimed to have an abundance of other bizarre medical issues, such as an inverted spine, two beating hearts, and "rough kneecap syndrome." Fans heavily speculated the true extent of Raven's illness throughout the entire season, with many divided on whether she was just a misinformed [[hypochondriac]] and/or someone suffering from [[Munchausen's syndrome]]. Some fans accused Raven of being a scam artist after it was discovered that her family had set up a GoFundMe page to support Raven's disease that had acquired $200,000 in donations prior to going on ''Big Brother'''. She also regularly stated that she would need to have expensive surgeries done afterwards in order to be healthy and have children.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

page.title: List of people who have lit the Olympic cauldron

revision.text:
[[File:Li Ling during 2008 Summer Olympics opening ceremony.jpg|thumb|right|[[Li Ning]], a former Chinese gymnast, lit the Olympic cauldron during the [[2008 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]].|alt=An Asian man in red-and-white athletics shirt and shorts, and wearing sneakers, is suspended by wires in the air while holding a lit torch in his right hand. In the background, [[Max Fursman|a large crowd]] in a stadium can be seen, as well as two blurred flags hoisted in flagpoles.]] The tradition of carrying the [[Olympic flame]] from [[Olympia, Greece]], the birthplace of the [[Ancient Olympic Games]], to the host city of the modern [[Olympic Games]] via a [[List of Olympic torch relays|torch relay]] was first introduced in 1936, ahead of the [[1936 Summer Olympics|Berlin Games]]. Since then, famous athletes (active or retired) with significant sporting achievements while representing the host country, promising young athletes, or other individuals with symbolic significance, have been selected as the last runners in the Olympic torch relay and consequently have the honor of lighting the Olympic cauldron at the opening ceremony.
==History== The first well-known athlete to light the cauldron was nine-time Olympic champion [[Paavo Nurmi]] at the [[1952 Summer Olympics]] in Helsinki. Other famous final torch bearers include French football star [[Michel Platini]] ([[1992 Winter Olympics|1992]]), heavyweight boxing champion [[Muhammad Ali]] ([[1996 Summer Olympics|1996]]), Australian sprinter [[Cathy Freeman]] ([[2000 Summer Olympics|2000]]), the Canadian ice hockey player [[Wayne Gretzky]] ([[2010 Winter Olympics|2010]]), the marathon runner [[Vanderlei Cordeiro de Lima]] ([[2016 Summer Olympics|2016]]) and the South Korean figure skating champion [[Yuna Kim]] ([[2018 Winter Olympics|2018]]).
On other occasions, the people who lit the cauldron were not famous but nevertheless symbolized the Olympic ideals. Japanese runner [[Yoshinori Sakai]] was born in [[Hiroshima]] on August 6, 1945, the day the city was destroyed by an [[Little Boy|atomic bomb]]. He symbolized the rebirth of Japan after the [[Second World War]] when he lit the Olympic cauldron of the [[1964 Summer Olympics]]. At the [[1976 Summer Olympics|1976 Games]] in [[Montreal]], two teenagers—representing the French- and the English-speaking parts of the country—symbolized the unity of Canada. Norway's [[Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway|Crown Prince Haakon]] lit the cauldron of the [[1994 Winter Olympics]], in honor of his father and grandfather, both Olympians. For the [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012 Games]] in [[London]], seven aspiring young athletes—each nominated by a former British Olympic champion—had the honor of lighting the cauldron.
{{clear}}
==People who have lit the Olympic cauldron== [[File:Fritz Schilgen 1936 Summer Olympics.jpg|right|thumb|alt=Athlete running down steps holding the Olympic torch|[[Fritz Schilgen]] carrying the Olympic torch down the steps of the Olympic Stadium in Berlin, 1936.]] [[File:Olympiatuli 1952.jpg|thumb|right|[[Paavo Nurmi]] lighting the cauldron in Helsinki Olympic Stadium, 1952.]] [[File:Anefo 911-5410 Olympische.jpg|right|thumb|alt=Athlete in white shorts and T-shirt running on an athletics track with the Olympic torch aloft in his right hand.|[[Giancarlo Peris]] running with the torch on the track at the Olympic Stadium in Rome, 1960]] [[File:Norma Enriqueta Basilio Sotelo (1968).jpg|thumb|[[Norma Enriqueta Basilio]], the first woman to lit the cauldron, at the Estadio Universitario in Mexico City, 1968.]] [[File:RIAN archive 104486 22nd Olympics opening gala.jpg|right|thumb|Basketball player [[Sergei Belov]] lighting the Olympic fire at the [[Luzhniki Stadium]], [[Moscow]], 1980.]] [[File:Vanderlei Cordeiro de Lima lights cauldron (28771915476).jpg|right|thumb|[[Vanderlei Cordeiro de Lima]], [[Brazil]]ian marathonist lighting the cauldron in [[Maracanã Stadium]], Rio de Janeiro, 2016.]] {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! scope="col"| Games ! scope="col"| Location ! scope="col"| Lighter ! scope="col"| Sport ! scope="col"| Note ! class="unsortable"| Ref |- | {{nowrap|[[1936 Summer Olympics|1936 Summer]]}} | [[Berlin]] ! scope="row"| [[Fritz Schilgen]] | [[Track and field]] | Schilgen was not a competitor at the Olympics, but was chosen for his graceful running style. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/berlin-1936|title=Berlin 1936 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1948 Summer Olympics|1948 Summer]] | [[London]] ! scope="row"| [[John Mark (athlete)|John Mark]] | [[Track and field]] | Little-known former medical student from Cambridge University. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/london-1948|title=London 1948 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1952 Winter Olympics|1952 Winter]] | [[Oslo]] ! scope="row"| [[Eigil Nansen]] | Non-athlete | Grandson of polar explorer [[Fridtjof Nansen]]. He is the first non-athlete to light the flame. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/oslo-1952|title=Oslo 1952 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2"| [[1952 Summer Olympics|1952 Summer]] |rowspan="2"| [[Helsinki]] ! scope="row"| [[Paavo Nurmi]] |rowspan="2"| [[Track and field]] |rowspan="2"| Nurmi was a winner of nine Olympic gold medals in the 1920s; Kolehmainen won four Olympic gold medals. Nurmi lit a cauldron on field level before handing the torch to four soccer players who relayed the torch to the top of the tower. Kolehmainen then lit the final, higher-placed cauldron. |rowspan="2"| <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/helsinki-1952|title=Helsinki 1952 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| [[Hannes Kolehmainen]] |- | [[1956 Winter Olympics|1956 Winter]] | [[Cortina d'Ampezzo]] ! scope="row"| [[Guido Caroli]] | [[Speed skating]] | Participant in the 1948, 1952, and 1956 Winter Olympics. Skating with the torch, he tripped over a television cable but kept the flame burning. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/cortina-d-ampezzo-1956|title=Cortina d'Ampezzo 1956 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2"| [[1956 Summer Olympics|1956 Summer]] |rowspan="2"| [[Melbourne]] ! scope="row"| [[Ron Clarke]] (Melbourne) | [[Track and field]] |rowspan="2"| Clarke would later win an Olympic bronze medal in 1964; Wikne participated in the 1964 Olympics. After Wikne lit the brazier on the infield, the flame was passed on to Karin Lindberg and Henry Ericksson, who separately ran up the two towers of the Stockholm Olympic Stadium. |rowspan="2"| <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/melbourne-stockholm-1956|title=Melbourne – Stockholm 1956 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| [[Hans Wikne]] (Stockholm) | [[Equestrianism]] |- | [[1960 Winter Olympics|1960 Winter]] | [[Squaw Valley, Placer County, California|Squaw Valley]] ! scope="row"| [[Ken Henry (speed skater)|Ken Henry]] | [[Speed skating]] | Olympic champion in 500m speed skating at the 1952 Winter Olympics. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/squaw-valley-1960|title=Squaw Valley 1960 |website= Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1960 Summer Olympics|1960 Summer]] | [[Rome]] ! scope="row"| [[Giancarlo Peris]] | [[Track and field]] | Track athlete of Greek descent. The [[Italian National Olympic Committee]] decided that the last torchbearer of the Olympic Games would be the winner of a junior [[cross country running]] race. Peris won and was chosen to be the last torchbearer. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/rome-1960|title=Rome 1960 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1964 Winter Olympics|1964 Winter]] | [[Innsbruck]] ! scope="row"| [[Josl Rieder|Josef Rieder]] | [[Alpine skiing]] | Participant in the 1956 Winter Olympics. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/innsbruck-1964|title=Innsbruck 1964 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1964 Summer Olympics|1964 Summer]] | [[Tokyo]] ! scope="row"| [[Yoshinori Sakai]] | [[Track and field]] | Sakai was born on the same day the [[Little Boy|atom bomb exploded]] over [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|his native Hiroshima]]. He never participated in the Olympics. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/tokyo-1964/|title=Tokyo 1964 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1968 Winter Olympics|1968 Winter]] | [[Grenoble]] ! scope="row"| [[Alain Calmat]] | [[Figure skating]] | Winner of the silver medal in the 1964 Winter Olympics. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/grenoble-1968|title=Grenoble 1968 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1968 Summer Olympics|1968 Summer]] | [[Mexico City]] ! scope="row"| [[Enriqueta Basilio]] | [[Track and field]] | Sprinter who participated in these Olympics; the first woman to light the main Olympic cauldron. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/mexico-1968|title=Mexico 1968 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1972 Winter Olympics|1972 Winter]] | [[Sapporo]] ! scope="row"| Hideki Takada | Non-athlete | A volleyball enthusiast who knew nothing of winter sports. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1972/02/03/archives/winter-olympics-open-in-splendor-at-sapporo-hirohito-hails-athletes.html|title=Winter Olympics Open In Splendor at Sapporo|date=3 February 1972|website=nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/sapporo-1972|title=Sapporo 1972 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1972 Summer Olympics|1972 Summer]] | [[Munich]] ! scope="row"| Günther Zahn | [[Track and field]] | Middle distance runner. Winner of the West German junior athletics championships. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/munich-1972|title=Munich 1972 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2"| [[1976 Winter Olympics|1976 Winter]] |rowspan="2"| [[Innsbruck]] ! scope="row"| [[Christl Haas]] | [[Alpine skiing]] |rowspan="2"| Haas won gold on [[Alpine skiing at the 1964 Winter Olympics – Women's downhill|downhill in 1964 Winter Olympics]]; Feistmantl won [[Luge at the 1964 Winter Olympics – Doubles|luge doubles in the same Games]]. |rowspan="2"| <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/innsbruck-1976|title=Innsbruck 1976 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| [[Josef Feistmantl]] | [[Luge]] |- |rowspan="2"| [[1976 Summer Olympics|1976 Summer]] |rowspan="2"| [[Montreal]] ! scope="row"| [[Sandra Henderson]] | [[Gymnastics]] |rowspan="2"| Two teenagers representing English and French Canadian. Neither of them participated in any Olympics. |rowspan="2"| <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/montreal-1976|title=Montreal 1976 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| [[Stéphane Préfontaine]] | [[Track and field]] |- | [[1980 Winter Olympics|1980 Winter]] | [[Lake Placid, New York|Lake Placid]] ! scope="row"| Charles Gugino | Non-athlete | A doctor from Arizona who had been elected from all 52 bearers to run the final leg. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/lake-placid-1980|title=Lake Placid 1980 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1980 Summer Olympics|1980 Summer]] | [[Moscow]] ! scope="row"| [[Sergei Belov]] | [[Basketball]] | Member of the [[Soviet Union national basketball team|Soviet basketball team]], gold medalist in [[Basketball at the 1972 Summer Olympics|1972 Summer Games]]. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/moscow-1980|title=Moscow 1980 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1984 Winter Olympics|1984 Winter]] | [[Sarajevo]] ! scope="row"| [[Sanda Dubravčić]] | [[Figure skating]] | Participant in the 1980 and 1984 Winter Olympics. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/sarajevo-1984|title=Sarajevo 1984 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Summer]] | [[Los Angeles]] ! scope="row"| [[Rafer Johnson]] | [[Track and field]] | Decathlon gold medalist at the 1960 Summer Olympics. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/los-angeles-1984|title=Los Angeles 1984 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1988 Winter Olympics|1988 Winter]] | [[Calgary]] ! scope="row"| [[Robyn Perry]] | [[Figure skating]] | A 12-year-old schoolgirl and aspiring figure skater. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/calgary-1988|title=Calgary 1988 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- |rowspan="3"| [[1988 Summer Olympics|1988 Summer]] |rowspan="3"| [[Seoul]] ! scope="row"| Chung Sun-man |rowspan="2"| Non-athlete |rowspan="3"| Chung Sun-man was a schoolteacher. Sohn was a young Korean dancer. Kim Won-tak was a young track athlete who took part in [[Athletics at the 1988 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon|that Games' marathon]]. |rowspan="3"| <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/seoul-1988/|title=Seoul 1988 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| Sohn Mi-chung |- ! scope="row"| [[Kim Won-tak]] | [[Track and field]] |- |rowspan="2"| [[1992 Winter Olympics|1992 Winter]] |rowspan="2"| [[Albertville]] ! scope="row"| [[Michel Platini]] | [[Association football]] |rowspan="2"| Platini took part with the [[France national football team|French football team]] in the [[Football at the 1976 Summer Olympics|1976 Summer Olympics]]. Grange was a future alpine skier (and older brother of future multiple-time alpine skiing [[Slalom skiing|Slalom]] world champion [[Jean-Baptiste Grange]]). Aged nine at the time, Grange became the youngest final lighter in history. |rowspan="2"| <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/albertville-1992/|title=Albertville 1992 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| [[François-Cyrille Grange]] | [[Alpine skiing]] |- | [[1992 Summer Olympics|1992 Summer]] | [[Barcelona]] ! scope="row"| [[Antonio Rebollo]] | [[Archery]] | Paralympian who competed in the [[1984 Summer Paralympics|1984]], [[1988 Summer Paralympics|1988]], and [[1992 Summer Paralympics|1992]] [[Summer Paralympic Games|Summer Paralympics]], winning two silvers and a bronze. The only Paralympian ever to light the Olympic cauldron, Rebollo shot a flaming arrow over an open [[natural gas]] cauldron to ignite it. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/barcelona-1992|title=Barcelona 1992 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1994 Winter Olympics|1994 Winter]] | [[Lillehammer]] ! scope="row"| [[Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway]] | Non-athlete | [[Heir apparent]] to the throne of Norway. Though he was not an Olympian, both his [[Harald V of Norway|father]] and [[Olav V of Norway|grandfather]] took part in the Olympics and he lit the cauldron on their behalf. His father declared the Games open. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/lillehammer-1994|title=Lillehammer 1994 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1996 Summer Olympics|1996 Summer]] | [[Atlanta]] ! scope="row"| [[Muhammad Ali]] | [[Boxing]] | [[Boxing at the 1960 Summer Olympics#Light heavyweight (-81kg)|1960 Summer Games light heavyweight boxing]] gold medalist. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/atlanta-1996|title=Atlanta 1996 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[1998 Winter Olympics|1998 Winter]] | [[Nagano (city)|Nagano]] ! scope="row"| [[Midori Ito]] | [[Figure skating]] | [[Figure skating at the 1992 Winter Olympics#Ladies|1992 Winter Olympic silver medalist]]. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/nagano-1998|title=Nagano 1998 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Summer]] | [[Sydney]] ! scope="row"| [[Cathy Freeman]] | [[Track and field]] | [[Athletics at the 1996 Summer Olympics – Women's 400 metres|Olympic silver medalist in 1996]] and would later won [[Athletics at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Women's 400 metres|Olympic gold in these Olympics]], both in the 400 m. She is the only person ever to light a cauldron and win a gold medal in the same Games. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/sydney-2000/|title=Sydney 2000 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[2002 Winter Olympics|2002 Winter]] | [[Salt Lake City]] ! scope="row"| The [[List of United States national ice hockey team rosters#1980 Winter Olympics|1980 U.S. Olympic ice hockey team]] | [[Ice hockey]] | Famous for the "[[Miracle on Ice]]"; an upset of the [[Soviet Union national ice hockey team|Soviet hockey team]] en route to the gold medal. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/salt-lake-city-2002|title=Salt Lake City 2002 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Summer]] | [[Athens]] ! scope="row"| [[Nikolaos Kaklamanakis]] | [[Sailing]] | Winner of [[Sailing at the 1996 Summer Olympics – Men's Mistral One Design|Olympic gold in 1996]] and would win a [[Sailing at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's Mistral One Design|silver in these Olympics]]. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/athens-2004|title=Athens 2004 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[2006 Winter Olympics|2006 Winter]] | [[Turin]] ! scope="row"| [[Stefania Belmondo]] | [[Cross-country skiing]] | Winner of ten Olympic medals, two of them gold. One of Italy's most decorated Olympians. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/turin-2006|title=Turin 2006 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- | [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Summer]] | [[Beijing]] ! scope="row"| [[Li Ning (gymnast)|Li Ning]] | [[Artistic gymnastics]] | Winner of six Olympic medals, including three gold in [[Gymnastics at the 1984 Summer Olympics|1984]]. He was China's most successful athlete at their first Olympic appearance since 1952. | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/beijing-2008|title=Beijing 2008 |website=Olympic.org |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- |rowspan="4"| [[2010 Winter Olympics|2010 Winter]] |rowspan="4"| [[Vancouver]] ! scope="row"| [[Steve Nash]] (indoor cauldron) | [[Basketball]] |rowspan="4"| Le May Doan was a winner of two gold medals in the 500 m in 1998 and 2002 and a bronze in the 1000 m in 1998. Nash is a two-time [[NBA]] [[NBA Most Valuable Player Award|MVP]] with the [[Phoenix Suns]] and a former member of the [[Canada national men's basketball team|Canadian Olympic Basketball team]], playing in [[Basketball at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2000 Summer Games]]. Greene won gold in the giant slalom and silver in the slalom in 1968 Winter Games. Gretzky was a member of the [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Canadian ice hockey team]] and won four [[Stanley Cup]] titles as captain of the [[Edmonton Oilers]] ({{scfy|1984}}, {{scfy|1985}}, {{scfy|1987}}, {{scfy|1988}}). He was the Executive Director of the Canadian men's hockey team in 2002, who won gold at that Games.
During the [[2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]], Nash, Greene and Gretzky lit a cauldron inside the [[BC Place Stadium|BC Place]] indoor stadium. Gretzky then lit a second, outdoor cauldron near the [[Vancouver Convention Centre]]. Only the outdoor cauldron remained lit throughout the Games.
Le May Doan was supposed to participate in the lighting of the indoor cauldron, but was left out when one of the four arms failed to raise due to mechanical problems. This was corrected at the beginning of the [[2010 Winter Olympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]], when a joke was made about the mechanical error, and she was able to light the newly emerged fourth arm and relight the indoor cauldron to begin the closing ceremony. |rowspan="4"|<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/sports/vancouver2010/news/2010/02/13/12864051-qmi.html|title=Opening Ceremony timeline|last=Friesen|first=Paul|date=13 February 2010|publisher=Toronto Sun|accessdate=13 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite video|title=2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|medium=television|publisher=NBC Sports|date=2010-02-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://montrealgazette.com/sports/2010wintergames/Closing+ceremony+pokes+2010+Games/2625251/story.html|title=Closing ceremony pokes fun at the 2010 Games|last=Kines|first=Lindsay|date=February 28, 2010|publisher=The Montreal Gazette|accessdate=1 March 2010}}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| [[Nancy Greene]] (indoor cauldron) | [[Alpine skiing]] |- ! scope="row"| [[Wayne Gretzky]] (indoor & outdoor cauldrons) | [[Ice hockey]] |- ! scope="row"| [[Catriona Le May Doan]] (closing ceremony) | [[Speed skating]] |- |rowspan="7"| [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012 Summer]] |rowspan="7"| [[London]] ! scope="row"| [[Desiree Henry]] |rowspan="4"| [[Track and field]] |rowspan="7"|[[2012 Summer Olympics and Paralympics cauldron|The cauldron]] was lit by seven teenagers, each nominated by a veteran British Olympian: Airlie was nominated by [[Shirley Robertson]], Duckitt by [[Duncan Goodhew]], Henry by [[Daley Thompson]], Kirk by [[Mary Peters (athlete)|Dame Mary Peters]], MacRitchie by [[Steve Redgrave|Sir Steve Redgrave]], Reynolds by [[Lynn Davies]] and Tracey by [[Kelly Holmes|Dame Kelly Holmes]]. Austin Playfoot later relit the cauldron in its new spot in the Olympic Stadium. The seven youngsters were commonly referred to as the "Secret Seven" as their identity and role was a closely guarded secret until the lighting of the Olympic cauldron. Duckitt was the only non-athlete among them.
Henry would later go on to win an Olympic bronze medal in the [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 4 × 100 metres relay|4 × 100 m]] in 2016. |rowspan="7"|<ref>{{cite news|title=Cauldron moved into position in Olympic Stadium|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19024475 |publisher=BBC |date=30 July 2012 |accessdate=20 February 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=#1YearOn........ Where are they now?|publisher=[[Team GB]] |url=https://www.teamgb.com/news/1yearon-where-are-they-now |date=31 July 2013 |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Rio Olympics 2016: The seven teenagers still carrying a torch for our Games hopes |publisher=The Independent|first=Matt|last=Majendie |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/news/rio-olympics-2016-the-seven-teenagers-still-carrying-a-torch-for-our-games-hopes-10417460.html |date=26 July 2015 |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| Katie Kirk |- ! scope="row"| Aidan Reynolds |- ! scope="row"| [[Adelle Tracey]] |- ! scope="row"| Callum Airlie | [[Sailing (sport)|Sailing]] |- ! scope="row"| Jordan Duckitt | Non-athlete (Young Ambassadors Group) |- ! scope="row"| Cameron MacRitchie | [[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]] |- |rowspan="2"| [[2014 Winter Olympics|2014 Winter]] |rowspan="2"| [[Sochi]] ! scope="row"| [[Irina Rodnina]] | [[Figure skating]] |rowspan="2"| Rodnina won three successive Olympic gold medals. Tretiak won four medals (three golds). |rowspan="2"|<ref>{{cite news|title=Sochi Opening Ceremony: Rodnina, Tretyak light Olympic cauldron together|url=http://olympictalk.nbcsports.com/2014/02/07/sochi-opening-ceremony-rodnina-tretyak-light-olympic-cauldron-together/ |agency=NBC Sports |date=7 February 2014 |accessdate=7 February 2014 }}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| [[Vladislav Tretiak]] | [[Ice hockey]] |- |rowspan="2"| [[2016 Summer Olympics|2016 Summer]] |rowspan="2"| [[Rio de Janeiro]] ! scope="row"| [[Vanderlei de Lima|Vanderlei Cordeiro de Lima]]<br />(stadium cauldron) |rowspan="2"| [[Sport of athletics|Athletics]] | Winner of the bronze medal in the [[Athletics at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon|marathon of the 2004 Summer Olympics]]. De Lima was the first Latin American awarded the [[Pierre de Coubertin medal]] after he was deliberately interrupted during that event. |rowspan="2"|<ref>{{cite news|title=Best man for the job: Vanderlei de Lima lights Olympic cauldron|url=http://www.nbcolympics.com/news/best-man-job-vanderlei-de-lima-lights-olympic-cauldron-opening-ceremony |agency=NBC Sports |date=6 August 2016 |accessdate=14 September 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Formerly homeless boy who lit Olympic cauldron now has 'beautiful life'|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/rio-olympics-boy-who-lit-cauldron-1.3716398 |agency=CBC |date=12 August 2016 |accessdate=14 September 2016 }}</ref> |- ! scope="row"| Jorge Gomes <br/> (public cauldron) | A second, outdoor cauldron was lit in front of [[Candelaria Church]] by 14-year-old, who was part of a sports project in Rio de Janeiro. |- | [[2018 Winter Olympics|2018 Winter]] | [[Pyeongchang County|Pyeongchang]] ! scope="row"| [[Yuna Kim]] | [[Figure skating]] | Winner of Olympic gold in the ladies' singles in 2010 and silver in 2014. | <ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/korean-figure-skater-kim-yuna-lights-olympic-cauldron-132002667--oly.html|title=Korean figure skater Kim Yuna lights Olympic cauldron|publisher=Yahoo Sports|date=9 February 2018|accessdate=9 February 2018}}</ref> |- |}
===Youth Olympics=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:0 1em 0 0; border:1px #aaa solid; border-collapse:collapse;" |- ! Games ! Location ! Lighter ! Sport ! Note ! Ref |- | {{nowrap|[[2010 Summer Youth Olympics|2010 Summer Youth]]}} | [[Singapore]] | Darren Choy | [[Sailing]] | A Singaporean [[sailor]] of who participated in the Games. | |- |rowspan="2"| [[2012 Winter Youth Olympics|2012 Winter Youth]] |rowspan="2"| [[Innsbruck]] | [[Egon Zimmermann]] |rowspan="2"| [[Alpine skiing]] |rowspan="2"| Both Zimmerman and Klammer won the gold in the downhill event in [[Alpine skiing at the 1964 Winter Olympics – Men's downhill|1964]] and [[Alpine skiing at the 1976 Winter Olympics – Men's downhill|1976]] respectively, both years when Austria previously hosted the Adult Winter Games. |rowspan="2"| |- | [[Franz Klammer]] |- | [[2014 Summer Youth Olympics|2014 Summer Youth]] | [[Nanjing]] | [[Chen Ruolin]] | [[Diving (sport)|Diving]] | Winner of back-to-back gold medals in diving in [[Diving at the 2008 Summer Olympics|2008]] and [[Diving at the 2012 Summer Olympics|2012]] Adult Summer Games, in the 10 m and the 10 m synchronized. She would retain the [[Diving at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's synchronized 10 metre platform|latter's gold medal]] in 2016 Adult Summer Games. | |- | [[2016 Winter Youth Olympics|2016 Winter Youth]] | [[Lillehammer]] | [[Princess Ingrid Alexandra of Norway]] | Non-athlete | Elder child of [[Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway|Crown Prince Haakon]], who previously lit the cauldron in the [[1994 Winter Olympics|1994 Adult Winter Games]]. [[Harald V of Norway|Her grandfather]] declared the Games open. |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://norwaytoday.info/news/princess-ingrid-alexandra-lit-the-olympic-fire/|title=Princess Ingrid Alexandra lit the Olympic fire|publisher=Norway Today|date=12 February 2016|accessdate=13 February 2016}}</ref> |- | [[2018 Summer Youth Olympics|2018 Summer Youth]] | [[Buenos Aires]] | [[Santiago Lange]] and [[Paula Pareto]] | [[Sailing]] and [[judo]] | As Buenos Aires 2018 was the first edition of an Olympic competition with gender equality, the lighting of the cauldron was symbolically carried out by a woman and a man. Pareto won bronze at [[Beijing 2008]] and gold at [[Rio 2016]]; Lange, won bronze at [[Athens 2004]] and [[Beijing 2008]] and was Olympic champion at [[Rio 2016]]. |<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/news/the-cauldron-that-lit-up-the-heart-of-buenos-aires|title=THE CAULDRON THAT LIT UP THE HEART OF BUENOS AIRES|publisher=Olympic|date=7 October 2018|accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref> |- |}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #76A8FF | name = Léon Pourtau | image = Pourtau Autoportrait.jpg | caption = Self-portrait c. 1890 | birth_date = 1872 | birth_place = [[Bordeaux]], France | death_date = {{death date|df=yes|1898|7|4}} | death_place = Atlantic Ocean, near [[Sable Island]], Canada | nationality = {{flag|France}} | movement = [[Post-Impressionism]], [[pointilism]], [[Divisionism]] }} [[Image:Léon Pourtau by Vallotton.jpg|thumb|right|Léon Pourtau.
(Portrait by [[Félix Vallotton]])]] '''Léon Pourtau''' (1872 – 4 July 1898) was a French painter and musician. At the age of 15, an apprentice [[typesetter]], Pourtau left Bordeaux for Paris. He worked in a small restaurant on the [[Rue Lafayette]], where musicians gathered [[Orchestre Lamoureux]]. Thanks to them gets a job as a concert [[clarinet]]ist in a [[Café-chantant]]. He toured with a [[circus]] band where he would help set up the [[circus tent|tent]] and bathe the elephants. Back in Paris he entered the [[Conservatoire de Paris]]. During this period he married, had two children, and become a professor at the [[Conservatoire de Lyon]] at the age of 22 – the youngest ever. He met [[George Seurat]], himself also a musician, who taught him the [[impressionist]] technique. He took the opportunity of a concert tour in the US, which, after two years, earned him 20,000 [[French franc|Francs]]. At the annual exhibition of fine art held in [[Philadelphia]] over the winter of 1896–1897, he exhibited a painting, ''Quatre heures de l'après-midi'' (''Four o'clock in the afternoon''). This would be his only showing.Souren Melikian, "Unexpected masterpieces at Maastricht fair", ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'', 12 September 2006. [http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/03/10/features/melik11.php?page=2 Article consulté en ligne le 27.04.08]. Returning to [[Le Havre]], Pourtau boarded the [[SS La Bourgogne|SS ''La Bourgogne'']]. On 4 July 1898 she was sunk in collision in dense fog with the British sailing ship ''Cromartyshire'' off [[Sable Island]] (now belonging to Canada).210 US 95 ''George Deslions vs. La Compagnie Generale Transatlantique'', http://openjurist.org/210/us/95/george-deslions-v-la-compagnie-generale-transatlantique The painter died in the accident. His works are now in the collections of several [[art museums]] including the [[Museo Soumaya]], Mexico City and the Phoenix Art Museum, Phoenix, Arizona. Image:Léon Pourteau - Lecture sous la lampe.jpg|''Lecture sous la lampe'' File:El anciano (Léon Pourtau) 01.jpg|''[[Le vieillard (Pourtau)|Le vieillard]]'' Image:Léon Pourteau - Sur la plage.jpg|''Sur la plage''
c.f. ''[[A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte]]'' by [[Seurat]] Image:Léon Pourteau - Paysage provençal.jpg|''Paysage provençal'' Image:Pourteau Tropez.png|''St. Tropez'' Image:Pourtau Vallad.jpg|''Portrait de madame Vallad'' Image:Pourtau Soleil Couchant.jpg|''Solei Couchant'' Image:Pourteau Rue.jpg|''Rue de Village'' ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Commons category-inline|Léon Pourtau}} {{Post-Impressionism}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pourtau, Leon}} [[Category:1872 births]] [[Category:1898 deaths]] [[Category:People from Bordeaux]] [[Category:Conservatoire de Paris alumni]] [[Category:19th-century French painters]] [[Category:French male painters]] [[Category:French classical clarinetists]] [[Category:Post-impressionist painters]] [[Category:People who died at sea]] [[Category:People lost at sea]] [[Category:Deaths due to shipwreck]] {{France-painter-19thC-stub}}
