revision.text:
{{notability|date=February 2017}} {{BLPrefimprove|date=February 2017}} [[File:Richard Stephenson by Gage Skidmore.jpg|right|thumb|Stephenson in 2018]] '''Richard J Stephenson''' (born c. 1940) is an American [[investment banker]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-cancer-treatment-center-founder-divorce-trial-met-20161017-story.html|title=Cancer center founder's ex-wife seeks $400K/month as divorce trial opens|publisher=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> He is the founder and chairman of [[Cancer Treatment Centers of America]] (CTCA), a for-profit network of five hospitals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/business/careers/fl-cancer-treatment-ceo-resigns-20151019-story.html|title=Cancer Treatment Centers CEO resigns|publisher=sun-sentinel.com|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Stephenson is a graduate of [[Wabash College]] and [[Northwestern University School of Law]].<ref name="chicagotribune.com">{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1991-10-05/entertainment/9103310011_1_cancer-treatment-centers-graduate-wabash-college|title=Alicia Valentine, R.j. Stephenson|publisher=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
==Career== Stephenson led an investment group that in 1975 purchased a hospital in [[Zion, Illinois]] and renamed it American International Hospital.<ref name="chicagotribune.com"/><ref name="reuters.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-cancer-ctca-idUSBRE9250L820130306|title=Special Report: Behind a cancer-treatment firm's rosy survival claims|date=6 March 2017|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016|via=[[Reuters]]}}</ref>
Stephenson founded CTCA in 1988<ref name="reuters.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-cancer-ctca-idUSBRE9250L820130306|title=Special Report: Behind a cancer-treatment firm's rosy survival claims|date=6 March 2017|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016|via=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> "following his mother’s death from bladder cancer, [and he] ... holds investments in a broad portfolio of other businesses, including finance and real estate companies", according to a 2012 profile in the ''[[Washington Post]]''.<ref name=WaPo1226>{{cite news|title=FreedomWorks tea party group nearly falls apart in fight between old and new guard|first=Amy |last= Gardner|publisher=[[Washington Post]]| date=2012-12-26}}</ref>
==Personal life== Stephenson is married to Dr Stacie J. Stephenson, a physician, integrative medicine lecturer, and philanthropist.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cancercenter.com/press-center/leadership/richard-stephenson.cfm Profile] at [[Cancer Treatment Centers of America]] * [http://www.newsmeat.com/fec/bystate_detail.php?st=&zip=60010&last=STEPHENSON&first=Richard Campaign contributions] at Newsmeat
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stephenson, Richard J.}} [[Category:People from Barrington, Illinois]] [[Category:Wabash College alumni]] [[Category:Northwestern University Pritzker School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Tea Party movement activists]] [[Category:American health care businesspeople]] [[Category:American real estate businesspeople]] [[Category:American investment bankers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

{{BLP Sources|date=November 2017}} '''Ruby Karp''' (born August 30, 2000) is an American writer and comedian.
==Writing== Karp began writing professionally in 2011 at the age of 10 when Molly McAleer, co-founder of [[HelloGiggles|Hello Giggles]], asked her to contribute to the website by writing "Ruby's Corner", a weekly column that covered a variety of topics involving her observations and life experiences. She has also written articles for [[Mashable]] titled "I'm 13 and None of My Friends Use Facebook", which went viral,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2013/10/30/teens_on_facebook_younger_teens_using_site_less_facebook_admits.html|title=Sorry, Slate's 31-Year-Old Correspondent Was Wrong About Facebook|date=Oct 30, 2013|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|last1=Oremus|first1=Will|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref> and "How 13-Year-Olds Really Use Snapchat".<ref>{{cite web|last=Shontell|first=Alyson|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/how-kids-are-bullied-on-snapchat-2014-6|title=A 13-Year-Old Describes How Kids Are Bullied On Snapchat|date=June 26, 2014|website=[[Business Insider]]|accessdate=November 1, 2017}}</ref> In 2017, she published her first book, ''Earth Hates Me'', an inside look at being a teenager.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2017/10/04/teens-advice-for-coping-with-disappointment-suck-it-up-buttercup/|title=Teen’s advice for coping with disappointment: Suck it up, buttercup|date=April 4, 2017|publisher=[[New York Post]]|last1=Shea|first1=Molly|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refinery29.com/2017/10/175531/ruby-karp-teen-girls-ya-book-tina-fey-fan|title=Teen Author Ruby Karp Wants You To Live By The Hannah Montana Method|date=April 4, 2017|website=[[Refinery 29]]|last1=Romero|first1=Ariana|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.today.com/parents/read-excerpt-earth-hates-me-ruby-karp-t117002|title=One teen girl shares her call to end 'slut-shaming'|date=October 4, 2017|website=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]|last1=Karp|first1=Ruby|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref> She has also written for [[Refinery29]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refinery29.com/2015/05/87002/famous-authors-high-school-memories|title=Celebrating ''Prep'' 10 Years Later|date=May 7, 2015|website=[[Refinery 29]]|last1=Stanberry|first1=Lindsey|accessdate=Nov 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refinery29.com/2015/05/87002/famous-authors-high-school-memories#slide-2|title=Celebrating Prep 10 Years Later|publisher=|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref> as well as the "Sparklife" section of the education-oriented blog ''[[SparkNotes]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://community.sparknotes.com/blog/contributor/ruby-karp|title=SparkLife: Posts by ruby karp|website=community.sparknotes.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref>
==Comedy== On her third birthday, Karp found herself onstage at [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre|UCB]] as a guest on ''Talk Show with [[Paul Scheer]] and [[Jake Fogelnest]]''. Since then, she's performed monologues at ASSSSCAT, a [[Harold (improvisation)#Related forms|monoscene]] with [[Chris Gethard]], and appeared in an alien costume in a performance of the ''Broad City Live'' show in 2012. In 2004, she appeared on the first episode of ''Shutterbugs'' with [[Aziz Ansari]] and [[Rob Huebel]] on the MTV sketch comedy television show ''[[Human Giant]]''. In 2008, Karp spoke about being a feminist with [[Amy Poehler]] on her web series ''Smart Girls at the Party'' when she was 7 years old. She performed in a variety of shows at UCB and, in February 2011, started hosting the story-telling show, ''Hello Giggles Presents Very Important Things''. This show has since become the current, monthly stand-up show, ''We Hope You have Fun''. She has performed stand up at other UCB shows including ''Fresh Out'', ''Adulting'', and ''Andy Blitz and Andy Blitz's Friends''.
==Speaking== Karp won a [[The Moth#StorySLAMS and GrandSLAMS|MOTH Story Slam]] when she was 12 years old at Housing Works. She spoke about being a feminist at [[:TED (conference)#TEDx|TEDxRedmond]] in September 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tedxredmond.com/2013-speakers/|title=2013 Speakers - TEDxRedmond|website=tedxredmond.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref><ref name="JerEcho">{{cite web|last=Baumann|first=Ameila|url=http://www.jerecho.org/2015/01/28/the-future-of-feminism-ruby-karp/|title=The Future of Feminism: Ruby Karp|date=January 28, 2015|website=JerEcho|accessdate=November 1, 2017}}</ref> She was an ambassador for [[Dove (toiletries)|Dove]] on positive body image and spoke at the [[United Nations|UN]] on this topic on September 25, 2014.<ref name="JerEcho" /><ref>{{cite web|last=Florindi|first=Marissa|url=http://www.multivu.com/players/English/7316151-dove-legacy-5th-annual-women-self-esteem-weekend-united-nations/|title=Dove Encourages Women to Pass Their Positive Beauty Legacy Down To The Next Generation|date=September 30, 2014|type=Press release|publisher=[[Multivu]]|agency=[[Edelman (firm)|Edelman]]|accessdate=November 1, 2017}}</ref> She hosted the second annual ''Student Voice Live'' on September 20, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.stuvoice.org/single-post/2014/09/17/Student-led-nonprofit-paves-the-way-for-change-with-second-annual-Student-Voice-Live-summit|title=studentvoice|website=studentvoice|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref> In September 2017, she moderated the B-Fest panel at [[Barnes & Noble|Barnes and Noble]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/barnesandnoble/videos/10155401272505020/|title=Barnes & Noble|website=www.facebook.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref>
==Personal== Karp is a senior in high school and lives with her mother in New York City. Her mother, [[Marcelle Karp]], is a [[TV producer]] and a co-founder of the women's lifestyle magazine ''[[Bust (magazine)|Bust]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bennett|first=Jessica|author-link=Jessica Bennett (journalist)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/23/fashion/selfies-the-uglier-the-better-technology.html|title=With Some Selfies, the Uglier the Better|date=February 21, 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=November 1, 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.rubykarp.com Official Website] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QQPDNPkV_1E Feminism Activism: Ruby Karp at TEDxRedmond] (2013) * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OJqTAVJB_x8 The Feminist: Smart Girls at the Party with Amy Poehler feat. Ruby Karp] (2008)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Karp, Ruby}} [[Category:2000 births]] [[Category:21st-century women writers]] [[Category:American feminists]] [[Category:American sketch comedians]] [[Category:American women comedians]] [[Category:Upright Citizens Brigade Theater performers]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox comic strip |title= Sanmao
三毛 |image= [[Image:Sanmaopic.jpg|200px]] |caption= Sanmao |author= [[Zhang Leping]] |url= |rss= |atom= |status= |first= 1935 |last= |syndicate= |publisher= |genre= [[manhua]], [[pantomime comics|pantomime comic]], [[gag-a-day]] |rating= }} '''Sanmao''' ({{zh|c=三毛|p=Sānmáo}}) is a [[manhua]] character created by [[Zhang Leping]] in 1935. He is one of the world's longest running cartoon characters and remains a landmark as one of the most famous and beloved fictional characters in China today. The name Sanmao means "three hairs" in [[Chinese language|Chinese]]. While the character has undergone a number of transitions over time, he has always been drawn with the trademark three strands of hair, which implies malnutrition as a result of poverty. ==History== [[File:Sanmaonewspaper1948.jpg|thumb|200px|Sanmao in a 1948 Shanghai newspaper. He is a street acrobat in this segment. The poster on the electricity pole reads "Celebrate Fourth of April Children's Day."]] Most Chinese comic books prior to Sanmao featured adults and the Sanmao stories were also unusual in that they lacked dialogue and could therefore be classified as [[pantomime comics]]. When Zhang Leping created the manhua comic series, his main goal was to dramatize the confusion brought about to society by the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]]. He wanted to express his concern for the young victims of the war, particularly the orphans living on the streets. Most of the changes in the characters would come after World War II during the liberation in 1949. Sanmao's image has also been evolving throughout time, and in some modern continuation of the comics, he is depicted as a healthy, normal student.China Daily. "[http://www2.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2005-07/28/content_464182_4.htm China Daily] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205063513/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2005-07/28/content_464182_4.htm |date=2007-02-05 }}." "Sanmao Chinas favorite son turns 70." Retrieved on 2007-01-09. The character has also been portrayed as living through some of the most important periods in Chinese history and to futuristic space explorations. ==Story== The comic takes place mainly during the 1930s and early 1940s and is set in Old Shanghai in its "golden era". Sanmao lived mostly in misery and stark poverty against a backdrop of war, [[colonization]], and [[inflation]]. ==Adaptations== The character made his first appearance in [[Comic]] and was later adapted into different formats.Sanmao Official Website. "[http://www.sanmao.com.cn/world/dimension/movie14.html Sanmao]." "Production Listing." Retrieved on 2007-01-09. {|class="wikitable sortable" ! width=15% | Chinese Name ! width=20% class="unsortable" | English Name ! width=7% | Year ! width=20% class="unsortable" | Type ! width=10% class="unsortable" | Location ! width=7% | Produced due to ! width=15% | Channel Name ! width=15% | Film Studio Name |- | {{lang|zh-cn|三毛欢乐派}} || || 2006 || Online game || China |- | {{lang|zh-cn|三毛流浪记}} || [[Wanderings of Sanmao|Adventures of San Mao]] || 2006 || Cartoon || China

"Sanmao: Classic Cartoons and Chinese Popular Culture" In ''Asian Popular Culture'' edited by John A. Lent (1995). *Cunningham, Maura. "Sanmao Saturday: Introducing [[Zhang Leping]] and His Sanmao the Orphan Comics", blog 30 Aug 2014.{{cite web|url=https://mauracunningham.org/2014/08/30/sanmao-saturday-introducing-zhang-leping-and-his-sanmao-the-orphan-comics/|title=Sanmao Saturday: Introducing Zhang Leping and His Sanmao the Orphan Comics|date=30 August 2014|publisher=}} *Cunningham, Maura. "Sanmao Learns from [[Lei Feng]]", blog 5 March 2013.{{cite web|url=https://mauracunningham.org/2013/03/05/sanmao-learns-from-lei-feng/|title=Sanmao Learns from Lei Feng|first=|last=mauracunningham|date=5 March 2013|publisher=}} == Influence == * The renowned Taiwanese writer [[Sanmao (author)|Chen Ping]] (1943–91) chose "San Mao" as her pen name out of her deep sympathy for the lonely, homeless boy. * The Hong Kong movie star [[Sammo Hung Kam-Bo]] was given the name Sammo because of his supposed resemblance to Sanmao. ==See also== * ''[[The Adventures of Sanmao the Waif]]'' (1949): A live-action movie adaptation. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www2.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2005-07/28/content_464182.htm "Sanmao, China's favorite son turns 70"] - ''[[China Daily]]'' *[http://www.sanmao.com.cn/ Sanmao website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060413181835/http://www.sanmao.tv/ Official Sanmao website] *[http://asiaobscura.com/2011/07/chinas-all-time-favorite-and-all-time-darkest-comic-book-sanmao.html Sammao comic strips, photos, movie clips and history] AsiaObscura.com [[Category:Manhua titles]] [[Category:1935 comics debuts]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1935]] [[Category:Gag-a-day comics]] [[Category:Pantomime comics]] [[Category:Fictional orphans]] [[Category:Fictional beggars]] [[Category:Fictional homeless people]] [[Category:Fictional child soldiers]] [[Category:Fictional Chinese people]] [[Category:Child characters in comics]] [[Category:Male characters in comics]] [[Category:Manhua adapted into films]] [[Category:Comics adapted into animated series]] [[Category:Manhua adapted into television series]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
According to [[Northern Paiute|Paiute]] [[oral history]], the '''Si-Te-Cah''', '''Saiduka''' or '''Sai'i''' are a legendary tribe whose mummified remains were allegedly discovered under four feet of [[guano]] by guano miners in what is now known as [[Lovelock Cave]] in [[Lovelock, Nevada]], United States. Although the cave had been mined since 1911, miners did not notify authorities until 1912. The miners destroyed many of the artifacts, but archaeologists were still able to retrieve 10,000 Paiute artifacts from the cave. Items included tule duck decoys, sandals, and baskets, several dating back over 2000 years. ==Name== {{unsourced section|date=April 2018}} "Si-Te-Cah" literally means “tule-eaters” in the language of the [[Paiute people|Paiute]]{{dn|date=April 2018}} Indians. [[Schoenoplectus acutus|Tule]] is a fibrous water plant. In order to escape harassment from the Paiutes, the Si-Te-Cahs were said to have lived on [[Reed boat|rafts]] made of tule on the lake.
==Oral history== According to the Paiutes, the Si-Te-Cah were a red-haired band of [[cannibalism|cannibalistic]] giants.<ref name=nvmag>Johnston, Charlie. [http://nevadan.wordpress.com/2009/10/31/lovelock-cave-%E2%80%93-the-1929-book/ "Prehistoric Storage: Nevada’s ancient caves contain a "hole" lot of Native American history."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110113060428/http://nevadan.wordpress.com/2009/10/31/lovelock-cave-%E2%80%93-the-1929-book/ |date=2011-01-13 }} ''Nevada Magazine.'' July/August 2011. Retrieved 18 Nov 2012.</ref> The Si-Te-Cah and the Paiutes were at war, and after a long struggle a coalition of tribes trapped the remaining Si-Te-Cah in Lovelock Cave. When they refused to come out, the Indians piled brush before the cave mouth and set it aflame. The Si-Te-Cah were annihilated.
[[Sarah Winnemucca|Sarah Winnemucca Hopkins]], daughter of Paiute [[Chief Winnemucca]], wrote about what she described as "a small tribe of barbarians" who ate her people in her book ''Life Among the Piutes: Their Wrongs and Claims'' - she wrote that "after my people had killed them all, the people round us called us Say-do-carah. It means conqueror; it also means "enemy." "My people say that the tribe we exterminated had reddish hair. I have some of their hair, which has been handed down from father to son. I have a dress which has been in our family a great many years, trimmed with the reddish hair. I am going to wear it some time when I lecture. It is called a mourning dress, and no one has such a dress but my family."<ref>Hopkins 75</ref> Hopkins does not mention giants.
==Archaeology== [[Adrienne Mayor]] writes about the Si-Te-Cah in her book ''Legends of the First Americans''.<ref name="Mayor2005">{{cite book|last=Mayor|first=Adrienne|title=Fossil legends of the first Americans|year=2005|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton, N.J|isbn=0-691-11345-9}}</ref> She suggests that the 'giant' interpretation of the skeletons from Lovelock Cave and other dry caves in Nevada was started by entrepreneurs setting up tourist displays and that the skeletons themselves were of normal size. However, about a hundred miles north of Lovelock there are plentiful fossils of mammoths and cave bears, and their large limb bones could easily be thought to be those of giants by an untrained observer. She also discusses the reddish hair, pointing out that hair pigment is not stable after death and that various factors such as temperature, soil, etc. can turn ancient very dark hair rusty red or orange. Another explanation for the 'giant' interpretation of the skeletons may also come from the fact that some of the first remains unearthed by the guano miners in 1911-12 were described as “giant".<ref>Loud and Harrington</ref>
A written report by James H. Hart, the first of two miners to excavate the cave in the fall of 1911, recalls that in the north-central part of the cave, about four feet deep, "was a striking looking body of a man “six feet six inches tall.” His body was mummified and his hair distinctly red."<ref>Loud and Harrington 87</ref> Unfortunately in the first year of mining, some of the human remains and artifacts were lost and destroyed. "The best specimen of the adult mummies was boiled and destroyed by a local fraternal lodge, which wanted the skeleton for initiation purposes."<ref>Loud and Harrington 5</ref> Also, several of the fiber sandals found in the cave were remarkably large, and one reported at over 15 inches (38 cm) in length was said to be on display at the Nevada Historical Society's museum in Reno in 1952.<ref>Nevada State Journal, Reno, Nevada. Sunday, August 3, 1952 Page 6.</ref><ref>Nevada State Journal, Reno, Nevada. Sunday, February 22, 1953 p. 9.</ref><ref>Reno Evening Gazette, Reno, Nevada. Thursday, Sep. 25, 1913 p. 1.</ref>
The Paiute tradition asserts that the Si-Te-Cah people practiced cannibalism, and this may have had some basis in fact. During the 1924 excavation of the cave, a series of three human bones were found near the surface towards the mouth of the cave. "These had been split to extract the marrow, as animal bones were split, and probably indicate cannibalism during a famine."<ref>Loud and Harrington 13</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== * {{cite book|last=Reader's digest|title=Mysteries of the unexplained|year=1982|publisher=Reader's Digest Association|location=Pleasantville, N.Y.|isbn=0895771462|pages=41–42|edition=Repr. with amendments|others=[chief contributing writer, Richard Marshall ; contributing writers, Monte Davis, Valerie Moolman, Georg Zappler]|editor=Carroll C. Calkins}} * Hopkins, Sarah Winnemucca. [http://digital.library.upenn.edu/women/winnemucca/piutes/piutes.html''Life Among the Piutes: Their Wrongs and Claims''.] Boston Stereotype Foundry, 1882. * {{cite journal|last=Loud|first=Llewellyn L.|author2=M. R. Harrington|date=15 February 1929|title=Lovelock Cave|journal=University of California Publications in American Archaeology and Ethnology|volume=25|issue=1|pages=1–183|publisher=University of California at Berkeley|url=http://nevadan.wordpress.com/2009/10/31/lovelock-cave-%E2%80%93-the-1929-book/|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110113060428/http://nevadan.wordpress.com/2009/10/31/lovelock-cave-%E2%80%93-the-1929-book/|archivedate=13 January 2011|df=}}
==External links== *[http://hometown.aol.com/afmayor/ Adrienne Mayor's homepage] *[http://www.plpt.nsn.us/story.html Stone Mother, a Paiute Legend] *[http://www.plpt.nsn.us/story.html Paiute Indian Legends] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071015061448/http://www.burnspaiute-nsn.gov/Legends.html Paiute Legends and Stories] *[http://www.onlinenevada.org/lovelock_culture Lovelock Culture]
[[Category:Native American history of Nevada]] [[Category:Paiute]] [[Category:Pre-statehood history of Nevada]] [[Category:Fictional cannibals]] [[Category:Giants]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:The kid (''Blood Meridian'')}} '''The kid''' is a nameless central character in the 1985 historical novel ''[[Blood Meridian]]'', by [[Cormac McCarthy]]. The first sentence of the novel opens with "see the child", which tells the reader the significance of this character. These words also serve to advise the reader of the dissimilar nature of the kid in relation to the novel's antagonist, [[Judge Holden]], and the members of [[John Joel Glanton]]'s gang. When viewing the novel as a [[bildungsroman]], the story follows the maturation of the kid who had developed distinct values just before the end of the book.<ref name=blm1> {{cite book | last =Bloom | first =Harold | title =Introduction for "Blood Meridian" | publisher = Modern Library Edition | edition = | year = 2001 | location =New York | pages = v-xii | language = | url =http://ebookstore.sony.com/ebook/cormac-mccarthy/blood-meridian/_/R-400000000000000263626#readExcerpt}}</ref><ref name=clemment>{{cite thesis |type=Graduate |first=William Dean|last=Clement |date=2009 |title="The Last of the True:" The Kid's Place In Cormac McCarthy's Blood Meridian |publisher=[[University of Montana]]|location=Missoula, Montana|url = http://etd.lib.umt.edu/theses/available/etd-06112009-110830/unrestricted/Clement_Thesis.pdf | accessdate =August 4, 2012}}</ref>
He is the focal point for the first six chapters, where he leaves Tennessee, rides with the [[Filibuster (military)|filibusters]], and is jailed in Chihuahua City. There he meets Toadvine for the second time, eyes Holden for the second time, and joins Glanton's gang. However, in chapters seven through nineteen the focus is no longer exclusively on the kid. In this section of the book he disappears from the action and then reappears. The final chapters again focus on the kid.<ref>{{cite journal |first = Bernard A.| last = Schopen | title = 'They Rode On': Blood Meridian and the Art of Narrative | journal = Western American Literature | publisher=[[University of Nevada, Reno]]|location=Reno, Nevada|volume = 30 | issue = 2 | pages = 179–19 |date=Summer 1995|accessdate =August 4, 2012}}</ref>
Unlike Holden, the kid's physical description is sparse and bereft of details. All that is known is that he is "pale and thin", but he does have "big wrists, and big hands". In contrast to his outwardly violent lifestyle, his eyes are "oddly innocent". The kid's interior life is not explicitly expressed throughout the novel, and when he speaks it is very brief.<ref name=clemment/>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Cormac McCarthy}}
[[Category:Cormac McCarthy characters]] [[Category:Characters in American novels of the 20th century]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1985]] [[Category:Child characters in literature]] [[Category:Fictional criminals]] [[Category:Fictional thieves]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox engineer |image = Bundesarchiv Bild 146-1980-009-33, Walter Dornberger.jpg |image_size = |caption = Portrait of Major General Dr. Walter Dornberger taken during captivity, 1945 |name = Walter Dornberger |nationality = [[Germany]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1895|09|06|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Giessen|Gießen]], Germany |death_date = {{death date and age|1980|06|27|1895|09|06|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Sasbach (Ortenau)|Obersasbach]], Germany |education = |spouse = |parents = |children = |discipline = |institutions = [[Peenemünde Army Research Center]] |practice_name = |significant_projects = [[V-1 flying bomb]]
[[V-2 rocket]] |significant_design = |significant_advance = |significant_awards = }} [[Image:Dornberger-Axter-von Braun.jpg|thumb|Dornberger (on the left, with hat) together with [[Wernher von Braun|von Braun]], after their surrender to Allies in Austria, May 1945]] Major-General Dr. '''Walter Robert Dornberger''' (6 September 1895 – 27 June 1980) was a [[German Army (Wehrmacht)|German Army]] [[artillery]] [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]] whose career spanned [[World War I]] and [[World War II]]. He was a leader of Nazi Germany's [[V-2 rocket]] program and other projects at the [[Peenemünde Army Research Center]]. Dornberger was born in [[Giessen|Gießen]] and enlisted in 1914.{{cite book |last=McGovern |first=J. |title=Crossbow and Overcast |date=1964 |publisher=W. Morrow |location=New York |page=18 |ref=harv}} In October 1918, as an artillery lieutenant Dornberger was captured by [[United States Marine Corps|United States Marines]] and spent two years in a French [[prisoner of war]] camp, mostly in solitary confinement because of repeated escape attempts. In the late 1920s, Dornberger completed an [[engineering]] course with distinction at the [[Technical University of Berlin|Berlin Technical Institute]],{{cite book |last=Middlebrook|first=Martin|title=The Peenemünde Raid: The Night of 17–18 August 1943|date=1982|publisher=Bobs-Merrill|location=New York|page=19}} and in the Spring of 1930,{{cite book |last=Dornberger |first=Walter |authorlink=Walter Dornberger |title=V2--Der Schuss ins Weltall |trans-title= |date=1952 |publisher=Bechtle Verlag |location=Esslingan |language=German |pages=17, 20, 26, 36}}
{{cite book |last=Dornberger |first=Walter |authorlink=Walter Dornberger |title=V2 |date=1954 |publisher=Viking |ref=harv}}
Dornberger's detailed account of the V2 project was one of the first to be published by a major participant. Dornberger graduated after five years with an MS degree in [[mechanical engineering]] from the ''[[Technical University of Berlin|Technische Hochschule Charlottenburg]]'' in Berlin.{{cite book |last=Ordway |first= Frederick I., III |authorlink=Frederick I. Ordway III |last2=Sharpe |first2=Mitchell R. |title=The Rocket Team |series=Apogee Books Space Series |volume=36 |date=1979 |publisher=Thomas Y. Crowell |location=New York |isbn=0-69001656-5 |ref=harv |pages=21, 26, 27, 40}}; edition for pagerefs unknown; 1979, 1982, 2003, 2008 editions. In 1935, Dornberger received an [[Honorary degree|honorary doctorate]], which [[Karl Heinrich Emil Becker|Col. Karl Emil Becker]] arranged as Dean of the new Faculty of Military Technology at the TH Berlin.{{cite book |last=Neufeld |first=Michael J. |title=The Rocket and the Reich: Peenemünde and the Coming of the Ballistic Missile Era |date=1995 |publisher=The Free Press|location=New York |ref=harv}}, pp.  19, 33, 55. ==Rocket development== In April 1930,{{cite book |author=Heashall|title=Hitler's Rocket Sites|date=1985|publisher=St Martin's Press|page=12}} Dornberger was appointed to the Ballistics Council of the [[Reichswehr|German Army]] (''[[Reichswehr]]'') Weapons Department as Assistant Examiner to secretly develop a military liquid-fuelWarsitz, Lutz: [http://www.pen-and-sword.co.uk/?product_id=1762 ''The First Jet Pilot - The Story of German Test Pilot Erich Warsitz'' (p. 23), Pen and Sword Books Ltd., England, 2009] rocket suitable for mass-production that would surpass the range of artillery.{{cite book |last=Klee |first=Ernst |last2=Merk |first2=Otto |title=The Birth of the Missile: The Secrets of Peenemünde |origyear=1963 |year=1965 |publisher=Gerhard Stalling Verlag |location=Hamburg |asin=B001REHJ98 |ref=harv |page=117}}; The 1965 translation is Publisher: E. P. Dutton, New York – not Stalling; another translation?; citations may be to German edition; https://books.google.com/books/about/The_birth_of_the_missile.html?id=owgNMSQVl_EC.{{cite book |last=Collier|first=Basil|title=The Battle of the V-Weapons, 1944-1945 |origyear=1964|date=1976|publisher=The Emfield Press|location=Yorkshire|isbn=0-7057-0070-4|page=24}} In the spring of 1932, Dornberger, his commander (Captain Ritter von Horstig), and Col. Karl Emil Becker visited the ''[[Verein für Raumschiffahrt]]'' (VfR)'s leased ''Raketenflugplatz'' (English: "Rocket Flight Field") and subsequently issued a contract for a demonstration launch. On 21 December 1932, Captain Dornberger watched a rocket motor explode at Kummersdorf while [[Wernher von Braun]] tried to light it with a flaming [[gasoline]] can at the end of a four meter long pole. In 1933, ''Waffenamt Prüfwesen'' (''Wa Prüf'', English: "Weapons Testing") 1/1, under the ''[[Waffenamt|Heereswaffenamt]]'' (Army Weapons Department), commenced work under the direction of Colonel/Dr. Ing. h. c. Dornberger. Dornberger also took over his last ''military'' command on 1 October 1934, a powder-rocket training battery at [[Königsbrück]]. In May 1937, Dornberger and his ninety-man organization were transferred from [[Kummersdorf]] to [[Peenemünde]].{{cite book |last=Braun |first=Wernher von |authorlink=Wernher von Braun |last2=Ordway III |first2=Frederick I. |title=Space Travel: A History|date=1985|publisher=Harper & Row|page=45}} In September 1942, Dornberger was given two posts: coordinating the [[V-1 flying bomb]] and [[V-2 rocket]] development programs and directing active operations.{{cite book |last=Collier|first=Basil|title=The Battle of the V-Weapons, 1944-1945 |origyear=1964 |date=1976|publisher=The Emfield Press|location=Yorkshire|isbn=0-7057-0070-4 |page=20}} The first successful test launch of a V-2 was the third test launch on 3 October 1942. In the early morning of 7 July 1943, [[Ernst Steinhoff|Dr. Ernst Steinhoff]] flew{{Harvnb|Neufeld|1995|p=191}} von Braun and Major-General Dornberger in his [[Heinkel He 111]] to Hitler's ''Führerhauptquartier'' "[[Wolf's Lair|Wolfsschanze]]" headquarters and the next day Hitler viewed the film of the successful V-2 test launch (narrated by von Braun) and the scale models of the [[Blockhaus d'Éperlecques|Watten bunker]] and launching-troop vehicles:{{cite book |last=Garliński|first=Józef|authorlink=Józef Garliński|title=Hitler's Last Weapons: The Underground War against the V1 and V2|date=1978|publisher=Times Books|location=New York|pages=73, 74}} {{quote|This third day of October, 1942, is the first of a new era in transportation, that of space travel ... |source=speech at Peenemünde 3 October 1942|author=Walter Dornberger }} {{quote|I have had to apologize only to two men in my whole life. The first was [[Walther von Brauchitsch|Field Marshal von Brauchitsch]]. I did not listen to him when he told me again and again how important your research was. The second man is yourself. I never believed that your work would be successful. |source=Apology to Major-General Dornberger, 8 July 1944{{cite book|last1=Piszkiewicz|first1=Dennis|title=The Nazi Rocketeers: Dreams of Space and Crimes of War|date=2006|publisher=Stackpole Books|location=Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania|isbn=9780811733878|page=94}}|author= Adolf Hitler}} In January 1944, Dornberger was named Senior Artillery Commander 191 and was headquartered at Maisons-Lafitte near Saint Germain, and in December 1944, Dornberger was given complete authority for anti-aircraft rocket development (''Flak E Flugabwehrkanonenentwicklung'').{{Harvnb|Ordway|Sharpe|1979|pp=61, 214}} On 12 January 1945 on Dornberger's proposal, [[Albert Speer]] replaced the Long-Range Weapons Commission with "Working Staff Dornberger".{{Harvnb|Dornberger|1954|p=260}} In February 1945, Dornberger and staff relocated his headquarters from Schwedt-an-der-Oder to Bad Sachsa, then on 6 April 1945, from [[Bad Sachsa]] to ''Haus Ingeborg'' in Oberjoch near Hindelang in the Allgäu mountains of Bavaria.{{Harvnb|Ordway|Sharpe|1979|p=301}}{{Harvnb|Dornberger|1954|pp=266, 271}} Before going to the Alps, General Dornberger had hidden his own papers near Bad Sachsa,{{harvnb|McGovern|1964|p=184}} which were recovered by the [[332nd Engineer General Service Regiment|332nd Engineer Regiment]]. On 2 May 1945, Dornberger, von Braun, and five other men departed from Haus Ingeborg and travelled through [[Gaicht Pass]] and towards the little Austrian village of Schattwald. They met American soldiers who convoyed the group to the Tyrolean town of [[Reutte]]{{Harvnb|Klee|Merk|1965|p=110}} for the night.{{cite book |last=Huzel |first=Dieter K |title=Peenemünde to Canaveral |date=1960 |publisher=Prentice Hall |page=187}} Other sources place them being arrested by Patton's Third Army on May 3, 1945 near Prague, Czechoslovakia.{{According to whom|date=February 2017}} At an [[internment]] camp after the war, known as "[[Combined Services Detailed Interrogation Centre|CSDIC]] Camp 11", the British bugged Dornberger, who in conversation with ''Generalmajor'' [[Gerhard Bassenge]] (GOC Air Defences, Tunis & Biserta) said that he and Wernher von Braun had realized in late 1944 that things were going wrong and consequently was in touch with the [[General Electric]] Corporation through the German Embassy in [[Portugal]], with a view to coming to some arrangement.C.S.D.I.C Report Entitled G.R.G.G. 341 dated 7 August 1945 (summary of Dornberger's revelations) ==Post World War II== In mid-August 1945, after taking part in [[Operation Backfire (WWII)|Operation Backfire]], Dornberger was escorted from Cuxhaven to London for interrogation by the British War Crimes Investigation Unit in connection with the use of [[Slavery|slave labor]] in the production of V-2 rockets; he was subsequently transferred and detained for two years at Bridgend in South Wales.{{Harvnb|Ordway|Sharpe|1979|p=343}} Along with some other German rocket scientists, Dornberger was released and brought to the [[United States]] under the auspices of [[Operation Paperclip]], and worked for the [[United States Air Force]] for three years, developing [[Missile|guided missiles]]. From 1950 to 1965 he worked for the [[Bell Aircraft|Bell Aircraft Corporation]] where he worked on several projects, rising to the post of Vice-President. He played a major role in the creation of the [[North American X-15]] aircraft and was a key consultant for the [[Boeing X-20 Dyna-Soar]] project. He also had a role on the creation of ideas and projects, which, in the end, led to the creation of the Space Shuttle.{{cite book|author=Paul Dickson|title=A Dictionary of the Space Age|pages=199|year=2009|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press}}{{cite web|url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4402/ch4.htm|title=SP-4402 Origins of NASA Names|publisher=[[NASA]]}}{{cite web|url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4221/ch2.htm|title=The Space Shuttle Decision|publisher=NASA}} Dornberger also developed Bell's [[GAM-63 RASCAL|ASM-A-2]], the world's first guided nuclear air-to-surface missile developed for the [[Strategic Air Command]].{{cite news |author= |title=PERSONNEL: Changes of the Week, Nov. 25, 1957 |journal=Time Magazine |volume=LXX |issue=22 |pages= |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,891876,00.html |date=November 25, 1957 |page=116}} Dornberger advised Germany on a [[European Space Agency|European space program]].{{Cite magazine |last=Ley |first=Willy |author= |last2= |first2= |date=June 1964 |title=Anyone Else for Space? |department=For Your Information |url=https://archive.org/stream/Galaxy_v22n05_1964-06_modified#page/n69/mode/2up |magazine=Galaxy Science Fiction |pages=110–128 |type= }} During the 1950s he had some attrition with von Braun and was instrumental in recruiting several engineers out of the Huntsville's team for Air Force projects. The most remarkable of them was [[Krafft Arnold Ehricke|Krafft Ehricke]], who later created the [[Centaur (rocket stage)|Centaur rocket stage]] and actively participated in several more Defense projects. Following retirement, Dornberger went to Mexico and later returned to Germany, where he died in 1980 in [[Baden-Württemberg]]. ==Works== * {{cite book |last=Dornberger |first=Walter |authorlink=Walter Dornberger |title=V-2, der Schuss ins Weltall: Geschichte einer grossen Erfindung |date=1952 |publisher=Bechtle Verlag |location=Esslingen |language=German |trans-title=V-2, the Shot into Space: History of a Great Invention |oclc=175065526 }} *{{cite book |last=Dornberger |first=Walter |authorlink=Walter Dornberger |title= V-2 |date=1954 |publisher=Viking Press |location=New York |oclc=1223668}} ==Awards and decorations== * [[Iron Cross]] (1914), 1st and 2nd Class * Knight Second Class of the [[Order of the White Falcon|House Order of the White Falcon]], with Swords * [[Wound Badge]] (1918) in Black * [[Wehrmacht Long Service Award]], 4th to 1st class * [[War Merit Cross]], 1st and 2nd Class with Swords * [[War Merit Cross|Knights Cross of the War Merit Cross]] with Swords (29 October 1944) ==See also== *[[Arthur Rudolph]] *[[List of German inventors and discoverers]] *[[Aggregat (rocket family)]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Commons category-inline|Walter Dornberger}} * {{cite web|title=C.S.D.I.C - Island Farm, Prisoner of War Camp: 198 / Special Camp: XI-Bridgend, South Wales.|url=http://www.islandfarm.fsnet.co.uk/|work=Islandfarm.fsnet.co.uk|access-date=5 January 2012}} * {{cite web|title=Some of the Prisoners Held at Special Camp 11 - Generalmajor Dr. Walter Robert Dornberger|url=http://www.specialcamp11.co.uk/Generalmajor_Dr_Walter_Dornberger.htm|work=Specialcamp11.co.uk|access-date=5 January 2012}} {{wikiquote}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dornberger, Walter}} [[Category:1895 births]] [[Category:1980 deaths]] [[Category:People from Giessen]] [[Category:People from the Grand Duchy of Hesse]] [[Category:Military personnel from Huntsville, Alabama]] [[Category:Major generals of the German Army (Wehrmacht)]] [[Category:German military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:German aerospace engineers]] [[Category:American aerospace engineers]] [[Category:German physicists]] [[Category:American physicists]] [[Category:Rocket scientists]] [[Category:NASA people]] [[Category:Hessian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Research and development in Nazi Germany]] [[Category:Prussian Army personnel]] [[Category:Reichswehr personnel]] [[Category:Recipients of the Knights Cross of the War Merit Cross]] [[Category:Recipients of the Iron Cross (1914), 1st class]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the White Falcon]] [[Category:Operation Paperclip]] [[Category:20th-century American engineers]]

revision.text:
{{short description|16th-century English comic actor and dancer}} {{other people}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[Image:Will Kemp Elizabethan Clown Jig.jpg|250px|thumb|right|William Kempe (right) from ''Nine Days Wonder'' (1600)]] '''William Kempe''' (died 1603), commonly referred to as '''Will Kemp''', was an English actor and dancer specialising in comic roles and best known for having been one of the original players in early dramas by [[William Shakespeare]]. Roles associated with his name may include the great comic creation, [[Falstaff]], and his contemporaries considered him the successor to the great [[Jester|clown]] of the previous generation, [[Richard Tarlton]]. Kempe's success and influence was such that in December 1598 he was one of a core of five actor-shareholders in the [[Lord Chamberlain's Men]] alongside Shakespeare and [[Richard Burbage]], but in a short time (possibly after a disagreement among the members of the troupe) he parted company with the group. Despite his fame as a performer and subsequent intent to continue his career, he appears to have died unregarded and in poverty circa 1603. ==Life== In a 1615 lawsuit brought by Thomasina (née Heminges) Ostler, widow of [[William Ostler]], against her father, [[John Heminges]], the recently deceased actor William Kempe was referred to as a gentleman (''Willelmo Kempe nuper de Londonia generoso defuncto''),{{Harvnb|Wallace|1909|p=7}}. and it has been suggested that he was a member of the Kempe family of [[Olantigh]], a property {{convert|1|mi|km}} north of [[Wye, Kent|Wye]] in [[Kent]]:
Kemp's parentage is unknown, though it has been conjectured that, despite his plebeian performance persona, he was linked in some way to the Kempes of Ollantighe, near Ashford in Kent, who were a wealthy Catholic dynasty. Sir Thomas Kempe (1517–1591) did indeed have a son named William;{{Harvnb|Richardson III|2011|p=276}}. however, the claim that this William Kempe was the actor cannot be correct, since he was buried at Wye church on 27 March 1597 (Honneyman, 125–9; Bannerman, 3; private information, A. Findlay) . Nonetheless, this putative connection might help explain the otherwise surprising story—dramatized in the play The Travailes of the Three English Brothers (1607) by Day, Rowley, and Wilkins—that when William Kemp the actor was in Italy in 1601 he had an encounter with the celebrated traveller Sir Anthony Shirley: for Sir Anthony and his two equally famous brothers were related to the Ollantighe Kempes through their mother, who was Sir Thomas Kempe's daughter. Possibly, then, the actor had some tie of kinship to Ollantighe, at an outlying point on the family tree; or perhaps in recommending himself to Shirley he was just opportunistically taking advantage of the name he shared with Shirley's mother.{{Harvnb|Butler|2004}}.
Kempe first enters the historical record as a performer with [[Leicester's Men]] at [[Essex House (London)|Leicester House]] in May 1585The Earl made a special payment of ten [[shilling]]s for this performance. and continued in this service after [[Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester|Leicester]]'s departure for the [[Low Countries]] to take part in the [[Eighty Years' War]]. Leicester's nephew, [[Philip Sidney]], sent letters home by way of a man he called "Will, my Lord of Lester's jesting player" and it is now generally accepted this was Kempe. Sidney complained in a letter to [[Francis Walsingham]] that "Will" had delivered the letters to [[Lettice Knollys|Lady Leicester]] rather than Sidney's wife, [[Frances Walsingham]]. After a brief return to England, Kempe accompanied two other future Lord Chamberlain's Men, [[George Bryan (16th-century actor)|George Bryan]] and [[Thomas Pope (16th-century actor)|Thomas Pope]], to [[Elsinore]] where he entertained [[Frederick II of Denmark]]. Kempe's whereabouts in the later 1580s are not known, but that his fame as a performer was growing during this period is indicated by [[Thomas Nashe]]'s ''An Almond for a Parrot'' (1590). Nashe dedicated this work to Kempe, calling him "vicegerent general to the ghost of Dick Tarlton."{{cite book |title = William Shakespeare: A Compact Documentary Life |authorlink = Samuel Schoenbaum |last = Schoenbaum |first = Samuel |year = 1987 |page = 184 |publisher = Oxford University Press |isbn = 0-19-505161-0 }} Similarly, the title-page of the [[book size|quarto]] of ''A Knack to Know a Knave'' advertises Kempe's "merriments". (Because title-pages were a means to draw attention to a book, the mention of Kempe suggests that he had become an attraction in his own right.) Critics have generally viewed the scene in which Kempe performs as rather flat (Collier, 97) and it is assumed that the scene provided a framework within which Kempe could [[improvise]]. Entries in the [[Worshipful Company of Stationers and Newspaper Makers|Stationers' Register]] indicate that three jigs (short comic plays) perhaps written by Kempe were published between 1591 and 1595. Two of these have survived. By 1592 Kempe was one of [[Lord Strange's Men]], listed in the [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Council]] authorisation for that troupe to play seven miles out of London. In 1594, upon the dissolution of Strange's Men, Kempe, along with Burbage and Shakespeare, joined the Lord Chamberlain's Men and remained with that company until early 1599, when a still-unclear sequence of events removed him from the company. Although he had been a sharer in the plans to construct the [[Globe Theatre]], he appeared in no productions in the new theatre, which was open by mid-1599, and evidence from Shakespeare's ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'', in which there is no promised continued role for Falstaff, and ''[[Hamlet]]'', containing its famous complaint at improvisational clowning (Act 3, Scene 2), indicates some of the circumstances in which Kempe may have been dropped.James Shapiro, (2005). ''1599, A Year in the Life of William Shakespeare''. Faber and Faber, London. pp.42–49. Kemp played his last role for Shakespeare in 1598.Robert Hornback ''The English Clown Tradition from the Middle Ages to Shakespeare'' 1843843560 - 2013 "nd of the stupid puritan stereotype generally, that Shakespeare wrote his own strict, stupid puritan clown for Kemp — for whatever reason, Kemp's last Shakespearean role — in 1598. Like the “foolish Mayre or foolish justice” ... ==Final years== [[File:Kemp's Men, Chapelfield Gardens - geograph.org.uk - 167501.jpg|thumb|left| [[Wood carving]] of Kempe in Chapelfield Gardens, [[Norwich]]]] After his departure from the Chamberlain's Men in early 1599, Kempe continued to pursue his career as a performer. In February and March 1600, he undertook what he would later call his "Nine Days Wonder", in which he [[morris dance]]d from London to [[Norwich]] (a distance of over a hundred miles) in a journey which took him nine days spread over several weeks, often amid cheering crowds. Later that year he published a description of the event to prove to doubters that it was true.The year Kempe gives was 1599 [[Old Style and New Style dates|Old Style]], which has caused some later confusion. That Kempe's jig took place in 1600 (New Style) is established by a record of the payment of his prize money by the Norwich City Corporation. However, his activities after this famous stunt are as obscure as his origins. On evidence from ''[[The Travels of the Three English Brothers]]'', he is assumed to have made another European tour, perhaps reaching Italy, but by 1601 he was borrowing money from [[Philip Henslowe]] and had joined [[Worcester's Men]]. The last undoubted mention of him occurs in Henslowe's diary in late 1602. Parish records record the death of "Kempe, a man" in ''[[Southwark St Saviour|St. Saviour]]'', [[Southwark]], late in 1603. While this is not necessarily the comedian, the record fits his departure from the documentary record. ==Performance style== In his time, Kempe was as famous for his [[Jig (theatre)|stage jig]]s as for his acting in regular drama. The jig, a kind of rustic cousin to [[commedia dell'arte]], featured as many as five performers in a partially improvised song-and-dance routine. Jigs had plots, often bawdy, but the emphasis was on dancing and physical comedy. Two of Kempe's jigs survive in English, and two more in German. Examples of the jigs may be seen in the manuscript collection of [[John Dowland]] (now in the [[Cambridge University Library]]). A famous 17th century jig called [[Kemp's Jig]]{{cite web|title=Mathew Holmes lute books: Kemp's jig|url=http://cudl.lib.cam.ac.uk/view/MS-DD-00002-00011/194|publisher=Cambridge Digital Library|accessdate=11 December 2014}} was named after Will Kempe and was published in the first book of [[John Playford]]'s ''[[The English Dancing Master]]'' of 1651. The tune has received a number of modern renditions, including those by [[Profile (Jan Akkerman album)|Jan Akkerman]] and [[Gryphon (album)|Gryphon]]. As an actor, Kempe is certainly associated with two roles: [[Dogberry]] in ''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]'' and Peter in ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]''. (In the quarto text of the latter, and in both quarto and [[First Folio]] text of the former, he is identified in speech prefixes and stage directions.) From these hints, a list of Kempe's parts has been deduced which, if conjectural, is not improbable: Costard in ''[[Love's Labours Lost]]'', [[Nick Bottom|Bottom]] in ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'', Lancelot Gobbo in ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'', and Cob in [[Ben Jonson]]'s ''[[Every Man in His Humour]]''. [[Falstaff]] is a more ambiguous case. Though Falstaff presents some features of an Elizabethan dramatic clown, his character is higher in class and more complex than the other roles with which Kempe is associated. ==In period fiction== *Kempe appears as a character in ''[[Parnassus plays|The Return from Parnassus, or The Scourge of Simony]]'', possibly written during his lifetime or very shortly after his death. In it he praises Shakespeare for outdoing university-educated playwrights. ==In modern fiction== ===Film and TV=== *In the 1978 TV series ''[[Will Shakespeare (TV series)|Will Shakespeare]]'' Kempe is portrayed by [[Derek Royle]] as an oafish alcoholic. He is ousted from the troupe and replaced by [[Robert Armin]] when they think he has betrayed their involvement in the [[Essex Rebellion]]. In fact Armin is the informer, who has framed Kempe to replace him. *In the 1998 [[John Madden (director)|John Madden]] film ''[[Shakespeare in Love]]'', he is played by veteran [[character actor]] [[Patrick Barlow]]. *In 2005's TV-film ''[[A Waste of Shame]]'' he is portrayed by [[John Voce]]. *In the 2007 [[Doctor Who]] episode "[[The Shakespeare Code]]", Kempe is played by [[David Westhead]]. *In the 2016 [[BBC]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Upstart Crow]]'', Kempe is played by [[Spencer Jones (actor)|Spencer Jones]] as a parody of modern comedian [[Ricky Gervais]]. ===Literature=== *Kempe is a key character in [[Kevin Sylvester]]'s 2015 novel for young adults ''Neil Flambé and the Bard's Banquet'', published by Simon & Schuster Books *Kempe appears in Ann Young's 2002 novel for young adults ''The Nine Days Wonder'', published by East Hall Press. *In [[Neil Gaiman]]'s 1991 graphic novel [[The Sandman: Dream Country]], Kempe is depicted in the issue ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' a short story about Shakespeare's first performance of the play. *Kempe also appears in ''[[King of Shadows]]'', a 1999 children's fiction book which shows Kempe as a clown dancing a Nine Days' Morris. *In [[Harry Turtledove]]'s [[alternate history]] 2002 novel ''[[Ruled Britannia]]'' Kempe is one of the main characters. His off-stage personality is indistinguishable from the characters he plays on stage, and his antics provide much of the humour in the novel, which is set during a time of grim peril. *In J. B. Cheaney's 2004 novel ''The True Prince'' along with more of the [[Lord Chamberlain's Men]]. *''Kempe's Jig'' is referenced in [[Geoffrey Hill]]'s poem "After Reading ''Children of Albion'' (1969)" from his ''A Treatise of Civil Power'', published in 2007. ===Stage=== *Kempe was the title character in Dan Roentsch's play ''Will Kemp''.https://books.google.com/books?id=zuYCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32&dq=%22dan+roentsch%22+%22will+kemp%22&source=bl&ots=Q-qTsDS5Mt&sig=14WNgEIw-OijU_2GKCyLscghp94&hl=en&sa=X&ei=FkidUa-NOaXY0gGC3ICQAQ&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q="dan roentsch" "will kemp"&f=false *[[William Gibson (playwright)|William Gibson]] depicts Kempe as a moody tragedian in his 1968 play ''[[A Cry of Players]]'', a significant departure from Kempe's actual performance style. In 2008, comedian [[Tim FitzHigham]] re-enacted Kemp's Nine Day's Wonder by Morris dancing from London to Norwich, forming the basis of his play The Bard's Fool, performed at the [[Edinburgh Fringe]].{{cite web | title=Tim Fitzhigham The Bard's Fool | work=Chortle | url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/shows/edinburgh_fringe_2008/t/16406/tim_fitzhigham%3A_the_bards_fool |accessdate=15 June 2014}} ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *{{Cite book |title = Kemp, William (d. in or after 1610?) |last = Butler |first = Martin |publisher = [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] |url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/15334 |accessdate = 30 December 2012 |year = 2004 |ref = harv }} {{subscription required |date=December 2012}} *{{Cite book |title = Magna Carta Ancestry: A Study in Colonial and Medieval Families, ed. Kimball G. {{Infobox person | name = Zang Shiyi
臧式毅 | image = Zang Shiyi.jpg | alt = | caption = Zang Shiyi, Speaker of the Manchukuo Senate | birth_date = October 1884 | birth_place = [[Shenyang]], [[Manchuria]], [[Qing Empire]] | death_date = November 13, 1956 | death_place = [[Fushun]], [[China]] | citizenship = Manchukuo | other_names = Tsang Shih-i | known_for = | occupation = }} {{Chinese name|[[Zang (surname)|Zang]]}} '''Zang Shiyi''' ({{zh|c=臧式毅|p=Zāng Shìyì|w='''Tsang Shih-i'''}} [[Hepburn romanization|Hepburn]]: ''Zō Shikiki''; October 1884 – November 13, 1956) was a Chinese general and Governor of [[Liaoning]] Province at the time of the [[Japanese invasion of Manchuria|invasion of Manchuria]] in 1932. ==Biography== Zang was born in [[Shenyang]] county of [[Liaoning]] Province in 1884. He traveled to Japan on a scholarship to the [[Tokyo Shimbu Gakko]] and subsequently graduated from 9th class of the [[Imperial Japanese Army Academy]], with a specialty in the [[cavalry]], in 1909. On his return to China he joined the pro-republican forces in [[Nanjing]] during the [[Xinhai Revolution]]. After the founding of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] in 1914 he became an instructor at the [[Baoding Military Academy]], where he soon caught the attention of Adm. Sheng Hung Leih, who appointed him to his staff. He rose to [[Chief of staff (military)|Chief of Staff]] for the [[Kuomintang]] forces in [[Jilin|Kirin Province]]. He participated in the [[Zhili–Anhui War]] in 1920 and the [[First Zhili–Fengtian War]] of 1923. Together with [[Yan Yuting]], he subsequently became Chief of Staff of the business administration section of the Kuomintang [[National Revolutionary Army]] headquarters in [[Nanjing]]. After the death of [[Manchuria]]n [[warlord]] [[Zhang Zuolin]], Zang supported the [[Chinese reunification (1928)|Chinese Reunification Movement]] and was appointed governor of [[Liaoning]] Province in 1930. After the [[Mukden Incident]] Zang initially refused to cooperate with the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] and was imprisoned. However, he later decided to defect and was re-appointed governor of Liaoning Province (renamed [[Liaoning|Fengtien]] Province) on 16 December 1931. He was part of the Northeastern Administrative Committee or "[[Self-Government Guiding Board]] that made plans for a new State of [[Manchukuo]] to be established in February 1932. In 1932 Zang was re-appointed governor of Fengtian Province of Manchukuo, a position he retained after the administrative reorganization of the [[provinces of Manchukuo]] from four to ten provinces in October 1934. In March 1935 he was Emperor [[Puyi]]'s first choice to replace [[Zheng Xiaoxu]] as Prime Minister of Manchukuo (although [[Zhang Jinghui]] was appointed instead at the insistence of the Japanese [[Kwantung Army]] leadership). From 21 May 1935 Zang served in the largely ceremonial role as Speaker of the Manchukuo Senate—a post which he held until the collapse of Manchukuo in August 1945. He later served as Vice Minister for Home Affairs. In 1940 Zang was appointed ambassador to the [[Reorganized National Government of China]] headed by [[Wang Jingwei]]. Following the [[Soviet invasion of Manchuria]], he declared an emergency session of the Manchukuo legislature to promulgate the abdication of Emperor Puyi on 17 August 1945, effective 18 August, and attempted to open negotiations with the [[Soviet Union]]. However, the Manchukuo capital of [[Hsinking]] fell to the [[Red Army]] on 20 August 1945, and Zang was captured ten days later. He was initially held in custody in [[Siberia]], but was extradited to the [[People's Republic of China]] in 1950, where he died of illness in captivity at the [[Fushun War Criminals Management Centre|War Criminals Management Centre]] in [[Fushun]], Liaoning, on 13 November 1956. ==References== *{{cite book | last = Rana | first = Mitter| year = 2000 | title = The Manchurian Myth: Nationalism, Resistance, and Collaboration in Modern China | publisher = University of California Press| isbn = 0-520-22111-7}} *{{cite book | last = Yamamuro | first = Shinichi| year = 2005 | title = Manchuria Under Japanese Domination | publisher = University of Pennsylvania Press| isbn = 0-8122-3912-1}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/PTO/IMTFE/IMTFE-5.html IMTFE Judgement: Japanese Aggression Against China] *[http://rulers.org/chinprov.html Rulers: China Administrative divisions: Liaoning] *[http://ww2db.com/image.php?image_id=5051 Photo at World War II Database] {{DEFAULTSORT:Zang, Shiyi}} [[Category:1884 births]] [[Category:1956 deaths]] [[Category:People of the Xinhai Revolution]] [[Category:Politicians from Shenyang]] [[Category:People of Manchukuo]] [[Category:Chinese collaborators with Imperial Japan]] [[Category:People extradited from the Soviet Union]] [[Category:People extradited to China]] [[Category:Chinese people who died in prison custody]] [[Category:Prisoners who died in Chinese detention]]
